name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The following is the debate on the Commission's declaration on the preparation of the Summit on Climate Action and the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals in New York (2019/2809(RSP)).

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a pleasure to be here this morning as we prepare for the forthcoming Climate Action and Sustainable Development Goals Summits in New York.  Regarding the Climate Action Summit, the Commission adopted on 11 September a Communication to the European Parliament and the Council in preparation for the Summit, to present the European Union’s impressive track record on climate policy and our commitment to accelerated climate ambition. The high attendance of European Union leaders at the Summit – including the President of the European Council Donald Tusk – will enable the European Union to recall and explain comprehensively and coherently where Europe stands today and where it wants to go. The European story is one of ambition, real action, unity and determination, and yet one that recognises the richness of approaches applied by the individual Member States and adds value to them. The European Union narrative for the Summit will build on the following elements. First, the solid progress made on the preparation and finalisation of our long-term strategy for climate neutrality by 2050. Second, the over-delivery of our nationally determined contribution (NDC) through a comprehensive body of detailed laws and measures. And third, the planning and organisation to monitor and review the actual implementation and the continuing adequacy of our goals and targets. Last June a large majority of European leaders supported the Commission proposals to make Europe climate neutral by 2050 – a project that means radical transformation of our economy and our society. This is exceptional progress, considering the scale of the challenge. The European Union has been increasing its climate ambition since 1990 and will continue to do so. The European Union reduced its emissions by 22% between 1990 and 2017, while our GDP grew by 58%. Full implementation of our new 2030 legislation, adopted with very large support in Parliament and the Council, would yield another 23% reduction between 2018 and 2030: twice as fast. The adoption of a 2050 objective, together with the governance mechanisms that we have put in place, will ensure that we will continue this acceleration, on a fast track but in a gradual and manageable manner, towards climate neutrality. When fully implemented, we estimate that the measures for 2030 will enable the European Union to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 45% compared to 1990 levels, which goes further than the European Union’s stated objective in its nationally determined contribution, to cut emissions by at least 40% by 2030. Delivering on the 2030 targets will have benefits well beyond 2030. It will ensure the European Union is also going in the right direction towards 2050. At the same time, the European Union is already using its budget to ensure that investments are aligned and actively contributing to the climate goals – we have a 20% climate mainstreaming target in the current European Union budget, amounting to around EUR 200 billion of funds over the 2014-2020 period to support the low carbon transition. In the multiannual financial framework for 2021-2027 that is being discussed in Parliament and in the Council, the Commission has proposed that 25% of the whole budget, or an expected EUR 320 billion, will be specifically climate-relevant, and the rest will be compatible with our climate objectives. The climate and energy transition towards climate neutrality begins with a massive investment challenge, one that we must meet already in the coming years: investment in a clean energy system; in clean industry and clean mobility; in maintaining and restoring our land, to make sure that it not only continues to provide us with food, feed and fibres, but also helps us absorb the greenhouse gas emissions we will not be able to eliminate. We know, of course, that the scale of this investment is beyond the capacity of the public sector alone, and that the private sector will have a major role to play. To attract enough private investment, the European Union is already putting in place the conditions and incentives for investors to fund projects aligned with the climate goals, such as the European Union Action Plan on financing sustainable growth and the associated legislative package. We must focus on adaptation and resilience as well, and on disaster risk reduction, both in Europe and elsewhere. To do this, we will be able to build on the work done under the European Union’s Adaptation Strategy and on our international cooperation efforts in supporting our partner countries.  To this end, the European Union is stepping up its outreach and cooperation, financial and technical, to all partner countries. Nationally determined contributions will be at the core of our support, especially in critical sectors such as renewable energy and energy efficiency, urban development or agriculture and forests. Not only is the European Union the world’s leading donor of development assistance with EUR 74.4 billion in 2018, it is also the world’s largest climate finance donor, providing over 40% of the world’s public climate finance. The European Union and its Member States’ contributions have more than doubled since 2013, exceeding EUR 20 billion annually. The European Union remains fully committed to continuing to scale up the mobilisation of international climate finance, including through enhanced ambition by its investment facilities and the European Investment Bank. Likewise, the European Union’s array of legally binding trade and cooperation agreements will continue to include robust provisions to promote climate action and implement the Paris Agreement. The rapidly changing climate is a global problem and it calls for global responsibility. We in Europe are doing our part. We have acted and we continue to act, but to meet our long-term temperature goals we know we must do more and act faster still. On all this, we have a strong message to communicate at the Summit. We also know that the task does not end here. No matter how much we have done so far, and how much we have strengthened our ambition and speeded up our efforts in these past few years – the years in which I have had the honour of being in charge of climate action and energy policy, and therefore part of this effort – the Summit in New York can only conclude that more is needed. Europe will answer this call to action. Following the elections to the European Parliament and the political guidelines of the President-elect, it is very clear that the European Union will continue to work to raise its ambition further – as always, ‘in a responsible way’ – but with undiminished determination. My expectation is that we will continue to take further bold actions, building on our solid and significant achievements so far, and that we will develop, in a not too distant future, the model for a climate-neutral, modern, competitive and prosperous European economy and society. This must also be a model that our partners in the rest of the world will want to emulate, and that will therefore enable us collectively to avert the climate disasters that would await us otherwise. Let me turn now to the Sustainable Development Goals Summit (SDG Summit). It is of great political importance. It closes the first four-year cycle of the High-Level Political Forum.  The Commission welcomes that heads of state and government will, with all relevant stakeholders, for the first time have the opportunity to review progress in the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the 17 Sustainable Development Goals. The Summit should provide political leadership, guidance and recommendations for acceleration progress towards the Agenda. The SDG Summit should endorse a political declaration that includes a clear call for accelerated action.  The political declaration includes in particular the commitment to: maintain the integrity of the 2030 Agenda and to persevere on the 2020 targets; more concrete language on climate change, including on the synergies between implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement; more concrete language on broader environmental protection including new references to marine ecosystems and sustainable consumption and production. The Commission supports the key messages in the Global Sustainable Development Report, notably: despite significant action underway across the world, the current rate of progress is not adequate to reach the SDGs; some trends even remain negative, including rising inequalities, global warming, biodiversity loss and increasing waste from human activity; and accelerated action is required, as dynamics show that some countries seem to distance themselves from the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement. Let me conclude here by thanking you for your continuing strong support for European Union climate action, which enabled us to tell this positive story on the international stage and to encourage our international partners to enhance global climate ambition and real action. This is what our citizens expect from all of us, including the young generation that is mobilising all over Europe and the rest of the world for a better future.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Thank you, Commissioner, for your intervention and for the information you have given us about the message that the Commission intends to send at the important New York summit. It is precisely the subject that we are going to discuss next with the speeches of colleagues. I give the floor to Mrs McGuinness.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I am very conscious when I stand up here that the Secretary-General of the UN has said, ‘bring an action plan and not a speech’. The best we can do in this Chamber this morning is bring a speech and a commitment to honour commitments that Europe has signed up to, but also to acknowledge that though we speak well, we don’t always deliver. I am very conscious when I start with the Sustainable Development Goals that there are four of them, in particular, where we are actually going backwards, for example, Sustainable Development Goal 2 on hunger. We were making great progress, but as the FAO have pointed out, we are now going backwards and over 820 million people don’t have enough to eat. There is rising inequality, Commissioner, as you have just stated, so Goal 10 is not being met. On biodiversity and climate, we are also not doing or putting into place actions which will allow us to meet these objectives.  Let me just mention again – on the hunger issue, because it is a very real problem and a challenge for us all to have policy coherence both in Europe and, indeed, globally – the Lancet report, which many of us are familiar with, talked about sustainable intensification. I think even in this House we do not have a consensus as to what that might look like, or how that might evolve, so we do need to have deeper discussions in this Parliament between committees on these issues. One of the things that I hope for is that the new Parliament, which is now in session, will allow for greater coordination between committees.  On climate, we know that there are huge problems looming, and the younger generation are pushing us really forward to do more, but we also have to challenge ourselves and the younger generation to make sure we are ready for the changes in consumption and production patterns that will be required to meet all of these very noble but attainable objectives.  Just to mention two issues again – on oceans and on land. We have strong policies in Europe. We need to impress upon our colleagues in the UN next week that multilateralism is vital. The tragedy is that it’s now weaker than it was when it we signed up to these goals. I hope our delegation will impress that it is working together, both within Europe and the rest of the world, so that we will make our greatest change and I certainly, as one of the leaders of the delegation, will stress that very objective.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, timing is everything and the Climate Action Summit and the Sustainable Development Goals Summit are critical in helping us address the global climate emergency we are facing. The European Union needs to agree on a climate plan that provides an overall level of ambition, ensuring that the required transition takes place and providing the necessary financial means, together with the horizontal policies that need to be set. As things stand today, even if all the 2030 pledges were to be fully implemented, we would not be on track to achieve the Paris Agreement targets. The European Union has the potential and the duty to act ambitiously before 2030 and to adopt and implement a vision for a future climate-neutral and fossil-fuel-free environment. We require clear decarbonisation strategies by different sectors. We require action plans that clearly show how these strategies will be achieved and how they will be financed. They will require changes in sectors like transport, building, industry, agriculture and forestry. Climate change is a global challenge and solutions need to be global too, as the Commissioner himself indicated. But the European Union needs to continue in its leadership role, whilst providing support to the most vulnerable countries that are mostly affected by climate change. We need collective action and, as part of Parliament’s delegation to the Summit, I want to hear a strong European voice that is not afraid of putting forward ambitious programmes, because weak commitments would undermine our communities, our industries, our economies, our youth and our children. It is only through EU leadership that we can speed up global action on the Sustainable Development Goals and climate change goals and the EU should not shy away from its responsibilities.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, indeed, climate change ⸻ it has already been demonstrated⸻ it is not a question of ideology, but of survival. And we must act quickly, urgently, making unprecedented decisions and actions in our history. If we do not, the world is heading towards an increase of more than three degrees Celsius by the end of the century and we will have missed any opportunity to act. But now we can. That is why the convening and appeal by the Secretary-General of the United Nations to ensure that next week — the most important week of the United Nations — a Summit on Climate Action and another on the Sustainable Development Goals is absolutely key. Because it does so at a fundamental moment: one year after all the signatory parties to the Paris Agreement submit, they have to submit their national commitments; concrete decarbonisation commitments to prevent this increase in temperature and that by 2050 we will not exceed a degree and a half of increase. Also at a time like this year, when we have seen how climate devastation in the form of drought, fires, floods have been news every day. The European Union can lead this change at a summit that has already been said to be not for speeches, but for action. The European Union can do it. It has a clear commitment to neutral climate action by 2050. In this House, recently, the Commission's designated president announced the first European climate law, a great political ambition, accompanied also by a great ambition for financing, noting that the European Investment Bank must become part of a climate bank. Therefore, as a member of the European Parliament's delegation at this summit, I think we need to be aware that today, in the global world, in the field of multilateralism, only the European Union can lead this process of change. We can and I sincerely believe that we must.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner. This Friday will be the start of a week of action, a week of global action, of many citizens on the streets, and they have been referred to many times already, but they are asking for much more action than the world is taking right now, including Europe.  Commissioner, I know this is probably going to be one of your last plenaries, but to be very honest, you must have noticed that your speaking notes on climate action of Europe have not changed that much over the last two years. They have always referred to the fact that we have a 2030 package in place, that we are trying to get to carbon neutrality but still have not achieved it, and that we’re the only continent achieving something. I don’t think this is the speech that people are asking for. People are asking for more action; people are asking for politicians to listen to science, and we’re not doing that. The science is very clear: we have 10 years. Ten years to make sure that we are preparing for a new economy – and we have to deliver on that. That means that Europe needs to increase its ambition. I think that there is a bit of change with the new Commission potentially, but I think it’s also very important that we do want to know what exactly they are going to say, what exactly are they going to do in that climate law? I think there you have an important role, because if I talk to the people of your DG, I don’t feel that there is this urgency. There will maybe be a climate law and then there will be a long set of deliberations on what to do after that. We expect Europe to increase its ambition to at least -55% next year, before Paris starts. That’s what people are asking for, the minimum to change; otherwise, the people on the streets will again be disappointed by the lack of action by the world, and certainly also by Europe.

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr. President, Mr. Guterres, the current Secretary-General of the United Nations, said last month that in the fight against climate change, fine speeches were not enough. We are now waiting for action. There is no denying today that international organizations, led by the IMF, World Bank and WTO, bear a heavy responsibility for the ecologically predatory system we live in. It is all these organizations that have laid the foundations of the wild globalization of the most absurd excesses. It is the free trade treaties they have encouraged that are throwing more and more ultra-polluting container ships into our seas, often to process products that we could make close to home. What about the European Union, which will promote an agricultural, health and ecological disaster by signing a trade treaty with Mercosur. It must be made clear, in the globalist and Europeanist bodies, in terms of ecology as elsewhere, it is the hypocrisy that prevails on all levels. It is claimed to be concerned about climate change, without questioning the commercial disruption that feeds it. I will end with these words inspired by Bossuet, famous French writer: God laughs at men who deplore the effects of which they cherish the causes.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Colleagues, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. The Commissioner's speech said: ambition, determination. Fortunately, there was a phrase: 'real action'. That is why I want to ask a question. Are we prepared for discussion after a real analysis of the actions, but also of the capabilities of individual countries? Do we have real investment planned for the coming years? Finally, for all this to be real, do we have real sources of funding? The Commissioner has said a huge amount of more than EUR 320 billion for environmental action, but he has forgotten to say that the Commission has not prepared a budget for the transition. It is Parliament that has drawn attention to this and proposes little: EUR 5 billion. At the same time, I would like to ask whether such ambitious plans will not cause emissions to increase – and not reduce – if other economies do not join us, because the european Union as a whole will move to countries where we can afford a carbon-intensive economy at lower standards.

name: Petros KOKKALIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, next week the Secretary-General of the United Nations is waiting for us in New York to present our plan on how to stop the increase in carbon dioxide emissions by 2020 and reduce them to zero by 2050. The voice of science is united, it is clear and it has sounded an alarm. An alarm that has dominated the youth of Europe and the whole world. The response to the climate emergency therefore requires nothing less than the radical transformation of our economy and society. We have one last chance to implement a regular and fair transition, implementing the 17 sustainable development goals and the political programme of the Paris Agreement that claim – at the same time as tackling climate change – the eradication of poverty and extreme inequalities. The political declaration of the conference explicitly states that we know the world we want and we have a way to go there. So let us do this by incorporating the 17 sustainable development objectives into the Multiannual Financial Framework and the European Semester. We expect nothing less than for the new programme that Vice-President Timmermans is preparing for a new green social contract. And this, ladies and gentlemen, is not done by voting against yesterday's request for a resolution condemning the Amazon disaster.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in this debate the real elephant in the room is the continuous granting of direct and indirect subsidies to fossil fuels, in total contradiction to the objectives of greater ambition declared by the European Union: 5 300 billion dollars in 2015 worldwide, according to the International Monetary Fund, 231 billion in the European Union. The Commission itself recognises EUR 55 billion a year and confirms that it has not diminished at all over time. At the New York Summit, we must go with concrete proposals, say 'stop' fossil subsidies and abandon them completely in the medium term, propose redesigning taxation, because it is simply absurd to treat goods that have different production processes and impacts on the environment and climate in the same way. And we have to go and say that we do not need tariffs to defend European, American or Chinese products, but rather we need fiscal leverage with transparent criteria and environmental objectives, which is all consistent with the idea of open markets and competition, to really reward those who innovate.

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: – Mr President, the European Union and its Member States are the leaders in development cooperation and that role is becoming even more important in these political times. The European Union was the driving force at the UN when the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) goals were shaped, and that is something to be proud of, but now it’s time for more action and more progress, especially on all SDG goals.  I am very pleased to see that the Commission President-elect seems ready to take more action and that all new Commissioners should contribute to the SDG goals, but we need a broader commitment if we’re going to succeed in reaching the SDG goals and therefore I really look forward to going to the Summit next week and co-chairing the delegation, because I think that the EU has a role, that we need to make sure to steer the policy in the right direction, and that means that we need to stand up for multilateralism and also a result-orientated European Union development policy.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: – Mr President, a week ahead of the assembly in New York, the sustainable development goals (SDGs) are on everybody’s lips. Business people are talking about them, and politicians all over the globe. But what does it mean in real terms? Are we on track? No, we are not. We are missing our goals in the global south because of a lack of resources, and we are far behind in the global north, in many cases because of a lack of political will and decisive action. That has to be changed radically. Yes? Especially in the low-income countries, we would need some USD 530 billion a year to make meaningful progress on the SDGs. But what sounds so huge is not more than 0.5% of global GDP. So why are we not ready to invest this amount of money for proper heating, water supply, health care and decent nutrition for the kids in our poorest areas of the world? Even where we see pragmatic progress in the north, it is far from enough. As long as we have spillovers – where we clear rainforests for the production of meat and palm oil for the global north, where we see the production of our clothes under the poorest conditions – we will see rising problems. Ich glaube, dass der entscheidende Schlüssel zum Kampf um den Fortschritt für die Nachhaltigkeitsziele der Kampf gegen Ungleichheit und Ungerechtigkeit ist. Nur wenn wir in unsere Gesellschaften investieren und die Menschen in die Lage versetzen, ihr Schicksal selber in die Hand zu nehmen, mit starken Institutionen, mit multilateralem Ansatz und mit einer Politik für bessere Erziehung in die nächste Generation, werden wir eine Chance haben. Das erwarten wir vom nächsten Gipfel.

name: Catherine CHABAUD
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, next week, when some of us will be at the United Nations to mobilize for climate action and the sustainable development goals, at the same time in Monaco, climate experts will unveil the special report 'Ocean and Cryosphere'. This report, which we requested four years ago, together with my friends from the Ocean and Climate platform, promises to be very alarming. Dear friends, in his own way the ocean is burning. Yet for years, climate negotiations have ignored its crucial role in balancing the climate and providing essential services to humanity. Thanks to photosynthesis of plant microorganisms, the ocean provides half of the oxygen in the atmosphere; it is the other lung on the planet. It absorbs a quarter of greenhouse gas emissions. Marine and coastal ecosystems, such as mangroves and coral reefs, provide food security for three billion people. They are a bulwark against the rising ocean and the violence of extreme weather events. The frequency and intensity of cyclones are a consequence of deep ocean warming. Coral death is due to increased temperature, deoxygenation and ocean acidification. And I am concerned about what this new report will tell us. In 2015, we managed to make the voice of the ocean heard at COP 21 in Paris. It has finally become an emerging issue that is mobilising the European Commission, thanks in particular to the work of Commissioner Vella. And Chile has dubbed the next COP 25 the "Blue COP". But the good health of the ocean must be one of the objectives of climate negotiations, especially since it is also part of the solution. We need to finance the restoration of marine and coastal ecosystems, reduce emissions from shipping, develop marine energies without destroying habitats, etc. As the world's leading maritime space, Europe has a tremendous responsibility and leadership to take. This is a challenge that we can meet and that awaits the future Vice-President in charge of the Green Blue Deal and the future Commissioner for the Environment and the Ocean - and I welcome this title. A ocean, finally, which I call for to be recognized as a common good of humanity.

name: Aileen McLEOD
text: – Mr President, on Friday, thousands of young people will march across Scotland, just as millions of others will do across the world, to demand that we, their elected politicians, implement ambitious climate action now. They are looking to us to stand up and deliver policies that meet the needs of our planet. As a member of the delegation to the UN Climate Summit, we must take to it the strong message that we, across the EU, will meet the challenge laid before us and take bolder actions that will get us on track to meet the Paris Agreement and achieve the 1.5 degrees goal. That is what is expected of us and that is what we must deliver. My country, Scotland, has already declared a climate emergency. We are taking bold and meaningful action to end our contribution to climate change and we will end that within a generation. We need all countries across the EU and beyond to step up to the plate. The EU has a moral duty to lead that process and to stimulate the global ambition that we urgently need, and you’ll have Scotland’s support in doing so.  (Applause)

name: Sylvia LIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the While in December, the climate circus in Chile is once again meeting with some 25 000 participants – participants, many of whom live on the supposed climate rescue and are travelling halfway around the world, with millions of kilometres of air travel behind them, and I do not know how many tonnes of evil CO2 are emitting, the very CO2 whose existence is then so hypocritically effectively lamented in the media and can be used so well politically; not to mention the millions of euros of waste that have previously been squeezed out of hard-working tax-paying citizens. So, as climate wardens gather in the most beautiful holiday destinations – Marrakech, Lima in Peru, South Africa, Bali 2007 and so on – and discover new horror scenarios on the drowning horizon, they ensure at home that air travel becomes more and more impossible for citizens, cars are restricted as a means of free individual transport and, of course, the evil meat-eating is forbidden – to name just a few. By the way, if there are any questions about this: yes, I will be in Chile this time in December, but CO2 is certainly not my biggest problem there. Thank you very much, dear EU audience, I have finished today.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The European Union already has the most ambitious climate policy in the world, which is why I do not believe that we should make further declarations in New York about raising the level of ambition. Please note that the European Union's overly restrictive climate policy has already led to a decline in the competitiveness of European industry. Do you not see, for example, what is happening in the steel industry? Well, before our eyes we are flooded with cheap steel from China. The European Union's excessive climate policy leads precisely to the fact that industry is moving beyond the borders of the European Union. Due to the "flight" of emissions, there is also a "flight" of jobs, and thus unemployment increases. We are talking about climate targets, so we should also talk about energy poverty. Fifty-four million people in the European Union suffer from energy poverty. Please pay attention to this too. I am most in favour of protecting the climate, but the climate transition must be fair, it must take into account the diverse energy mix of Member States, such as Poland, which has a coal-based energy mix. Therefore, a fair transition fund is needed.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, the best factor for competitiveness is to be a pioneer in this change. The winners for the future, both in companies and in public finances, are those who are able to adapt their production to the future, to the limits that climate change requires of us. In his speech, the Commissioner mentioned the emission reduction target. The emission reduction target for 2030 is not enough for 45%, says scientific data. The emission reduction shall be at least 55 %. This is an example of the fact that, although we have fine words, our level of ambition is not yet sufficient. We are forced to base our objectives on scientific knowledge. At present, the progress of sustainable development is hampered by four phenomena: increased inequality, the progress of climate change, the increase in the waste problem and the persistence of biodiversity deactivity. The decline in biodiversity is accelerating at a worrying rate. It should be remembered that, although biodiversity is an intensitive value, it is also a question of resiliation with this planet, that is, how this planet is able to adapt to the inevitable warming that is ahead of us. It is absolutely essential to break the plug between economic growth and perceived prosperity and the use of virgin resources. We must now respond to those young people who are standing in the streets and demanding a future for themselves and for us to do so.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The President-elect of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, said: "I am inspired by the passion, conviction and energy of the millions of young people who make their voices heard on our streets and in our hearts." I can only support Ursula von der Leyen in making her walk with us. We want to be climate neutral, and we also want to increase the European Union's 2030 target. However, I would like to warn all of us together not to practice self-abuse, so to speak. The European Union has also been at the forefront of climate protection. As far as I can see, as the only major economic community in the world, as the only major emitter, we have already adopted laws that exceed what we promised in Paris. That is not enough, and we must continue to work on this. But we should focus more on other big polluters and consider how we can enter into a dialogue, because unfortunately I do not see the discussion that we are having here in Europe that we already have laws that overachieve the objective and still want to go further. We need to work harder on this. And in order to convince the others, we must also go down a path, as Ursula von der Leyen has pointed out, where we take those affected with us, where we decarbonise the industries and do not drive the industries out of Europe. I believe that this is the right way to go: to bring climate protection and jobs together. Then we can set an example for the world and assert ourselves as a whole.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, the number of people suffering from hunger continues to grow. Biodiversity loss is reaching alarming proportions and climate change is accelerating while multilateral cooperation is under threat. The summit will take place exactly one year before countries must strengthen national climate commitments in line with the Paris Agreements. These countries have developed their own climate action plan, in accordance with the Paris Agreement, but the sum of these plans is insufficient to limit the rise in global warming to a level well below 2 degrees. They must therefore strengthen their strategy to achieve the goals set out in the Paris Agreement and enhance their ambitions to combat climate change. Climate action and environmental protection are key tools in the fight against poverty, in the fight against famine around the world, and in migration issues. It is also essential that these measures, the measures that will be taken, be supported by all and that efforts are not put solely on the most socio-economically fragile populations, both in our countries and in the less developed countries. I therefore urge States to take strong and adequate measures that will reduce inequality, not increase it. We cannot be content with mixed ambitions, it is time to be courageous and give ourselves the means to build positively for the future. The time is for concrete actions and more for procrastination.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Mr President, to paraphrase former French President Jacques Chirac, the house is burning. But 17 years after the Johannesburg summit, there is a difference: the world has its eyes on it and it will be the case again next week in New York thanks to the initiative of the UN Secretary-General, Guterres. So, of course, and the Commissioner has pointed out, Europe as a whole is in the nails in its ambitions and in its results. We are doing better even with 23 per cent reduction in emissions already today. And yet 2019 has seen again and again the climatic episodes: hurricanes, floods, fires. Everyone knows that the Paris targets are not enough, the United Nations Environment Programme estimates that efforts to limit warming to 2 degrees will have to be tripled and for one and a half degrees it is 5 times squarely. In New York, therefore, it will be a question of determining the means together to go faster, to go stronger. And above all, knowing that we represent only 9 per cent of global emissions, to show others, to the major polluting countries, by example, that raising climate ambition is boosting our economies and not the other way around. This is the whole meaning of Madame von der Leyen's Green Deal, 100 days for a law that will have to be exemplary, indispensable.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this summer the planet has sent us emergency signals. The Amazon is burning, the whole planet is suffocating. Many young people express anger and fear at climate change. Scientists and researchers keep warning. Faced with this reality, we can no longer speak! We can't take empty words anymore! Disillusionment! We now need concrete action and action. It is time for Europe to be exemplary. As I recall, no State in the European Union respects the Paris Agreements. Then wake up! All sectors must be involved, and therefore, as early as this week, at the ICAO General Assembly, an ambitious taxation of aviation must be defended. Europe has a unique opportunity to make its voice heard. I hope that you will finally seize the opportunity and I say to you: if you do nothing, tomorrow you will be not only accountants, but guilty of criminal inaction.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, climate change alarmists also pollute more than some tell us who are accusing us of skeptics. And I don't say it, but scientific studies published by the University of Michigan last year say so. And you only have to see the way of life of characters like Al Gore, Leonardo DiCaprio or even some of those who are present here. Ladies and gentlemen, no one more concerned with the conservation of the natural environment than the political option I represent, driven by an extraordinary love for our homelands. But I'm afraid we're not talking about this here today. Today, here, and in a few days at the United Nations, what will be talked about is a political agenda that disguises ideology in science, replaces superstition, turning it into a revealed truth, and eliminates all scientific debate, replacing it with a girl's crying at high-end times. This on the climate agenda will only benefit large globalist companies, destroying European industry, condemning millions of Europeans unemployment, and preventing development in Africa, with a doctrine essentially, in our view, deeply inhumane. There is talk in this Parliament of billions of euros, but European citizens are not told that this money will come out of their pockets.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Mr President, we are going to stop spinning around the pot. We know that hundreds of thousands of young people across Europe have demanded an ambitious and social climate policy, and we are still not necessarily improving on that. We are still not where we need to be and we are really abandoning these young people in this way. If we want to respond today to rising inequality on the one hand and the lack of effective climate action on the other, we must first and foremost break with the austerity policy and allow massive public investment in our infrastructure.  Secondly, let us please ensure that these millionaires across the continent start paying their taxes. Let's make them pay their taxes and use that money for people and the planet. And finally, let us break with that emissions trading that allows multinationals to make profits at the expense of the climate. Then maybe we'll get there, because we know it: if the planet was a bank, she'd already be saved.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, the Sustainable Development Goals are extremely important in order to bring a better and more sustainable future for all of us. Despite important progress being made, for example in SDG 3 (health) in terms of reducing child and maternal mortality and in other areas, there is still a lot to be done in climate, biodiversity, reducing inequality and hunger.  Climate will be for sure the most debated issue in the Summit, but I would also like to draw your attention to SDG 10 (reducing inequality). Worldwide, the majority of countries do not implement this SDG into their development plans, whether we are discussing health policies or economic growth, or even sustainable development. Nowadays we can no longer just discuss inequalities in low income countries; this is also a challenge in high and middle-income countries. Economic growth is very important, but concentrating only on economic growth will not reduce inequalities. We need dedicated policies in order to achieve this goal.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the whole of the international community is coming together next week to discuss the fight against climate change and the objectives of sustainable development. A meeting that has to serve to deal with something that is no longer a future threat, but a present emergency. And a meeting that has to serve, above all, to move from rhetoric to action. From rhetoric to action, because in 2015 we approved as an international community the Paris Agreements to limit the growth of temperature on Earth. Well, the last four years have been the four years recorded as warmest in history. And this is also multiplying the climate catastrophes that we have also experienced recently in Spain, in the form of floods. Secondly, not only to move from rhetoric to action, but to ask for and demand leadership from the European Union in this area. That we can and should. In the ecological transition, in the decarbonization of our economy and in the reduction of emissions. We aim at a 40% reduction by 2030. We will have to set more ambitious goals and make them a reality. And thirdly, to call for this necessary ecological transition to be a fair ecological transition. Because, like any transformation ⸻and this requires it in terms of infrastructure, mobility and energy⸻ it will need shock absorbers to protect our jobs, to have socially and equitably an exit to this transition and to be able to send a message that ecological transition and social justice go hand in hand. Let's do it now that we're still on time.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Mr President! I would like to start by thanking the Commissioner for his tireless work to promote the green transition during the last term of office.  After all, the european elections before the summer were a climate change vote. Young and old citizens across Europe manifested themselves and declared that this issue is so important that it is now that it is the case and that it is urgent. Therefore, there is also good reason to look at whether we are delivering what we need from the European Union. In fact, we are coming to the summit next week without really agreeing on the ambition we should have, namely a totally climate-neutral European Union by 2050. So we really still have a lot of homework to do to lead the way, and we simply have to do that.  This summit should really be about increasing our ambitions and the European Union taking the lead in this area. I have high hopes for the new Commission and von der Leyen's good plans. This must involve a higher target for 2030 and a binding climate target, and it is urgent to implement all the excellent work that Commissioner Cañete has done in the last period.  Let me conclude by thanking the Commissioner once again, because this is perhaps one of the last times we have the pleasure of seeing him in plenary. Great congratulations on all the great, good work of the last period. It's urgent, we have a lot more to do.

name: Michael BLOSS
text: – Mr President, on 24 May, just before the election of this European Parliament, millions of young people went on climate strike. They have been striking, Commissioner, because you are not acting. The International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report and the scientists have told us that we are able to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees. Their main message is that we don’t have time and we need to act now, yet nothing has been done. You will go to the UN Climate Summit empty handed. You will not come with new, more ambitious climate targets. I’m sorry, this is a failure. Therefore, this Friday, millions of children and adults will again go on strike. They are striking because you are not able to deliver. They have one message, it’s simple, and I want you to hear it. They say ‘Climate action now!’ (Applause)

name: Izabela-Helena KLOC
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. This week, media around the world will be flooded with unprecedented news from the New York Climate Summit. It is clear that environmental policy has become a mainstream political issue. We hear it all over the world. The UN says that these events , and I quote here, "together they will send strong signals and give the excitement of the race to the top among the countries. This is necessary in order to achieve the objectives of the Paris Agreement.' So much for the UN. However, As an ELECTED MEMBER in Silesia, I would like to remind the Representatives of the Council and the Commission and the Commissioner that we should carefully select the pace of this race. The pursuit of a sustainable future must go hand in hand with solidarity, with social groups and regions, those most affected by accelerated changes in the structure of European economies. In New York, you will also represent socially vulnerable citizens of countries that need much more time for the energy transition. Please don't forget them.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Mr President, dear Commissioner, the work you do at the forefront of a portfolio as difficult as Energy and Climate Change has meant a before and after for all Europeans. You have been the architect, the engine of putting Europe leading the fight against climate change to leave a better planet for all future generations. The Paris Agreement has been vital and it is right to say here today that without your efforts it would not have been achieved, as you have also achieved energy union, decarbonisation and action. Your five years at the head of the police station are defined by one word: success; success that can only be achieved by working with passion, with your negotiating capacity and with your vision. We Spaniards always leave a mark where we are going, but the imprint of your time on the Commission will be as indelible as that of our dear Loyola de Palacio. As a Spaniard I tell you, with all my heart, thank you. We're proud to have a commissioner like you, and so let's continue in action at the New York summit next week.

name: Seb DANCE
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that it has been two years since the report on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that I was rapporteur for passed this Parliament. We called for three things: raising ambition for mainstreaming SDGs throughout the institutions of the European Union and, crucially, status reports on how far we are from delivering on the SDGs by 2030. I have to say that, in these two years, it’s been somewhat disappointing. I don’t think that failure for action is a personal one. I think it’s systemic. I think we have to look very carefully at how the European Union’s institutions are set up to deliver and mainstream those SDGs, which is why I was actually pleasantly surprised by the Commission President-designate’s comments that we need to have the SDGs mainstreamed throughout all directorates-general (DGs) and the responsibility given to the new Commissioners to deliver just that. But, of the three scenarios that were outlined – let me be very clear here – only scenario one, the first scenario, will get us to the position we need to be in. It’s the only realistic scenario to deliver on the targets and to create a sustainable future. We have to show in this place a strong leadership role, which is so desperately lacking on the world stage, and we have to move on from the idea that the SDGs are something to be done in a tick—box exercise at the end of the day when all of the standard business is done.  Commissioner, I want to thank you personally for your commitment during these years, but please, let’s not overlook the systemic failures and let’s get it right in this next mandate.

name: Valter FLEGO
text: – Dear Chairman, Respected Commissioner, I am very pleased that today we can talk about this important, I will say, crucial topic for our present and future. When we talk about our goal, it must be very clear. To be a world leader in the fight against climate change, not to be second or third, but the first, world leader. And to achieve this, then we, as european parliaments, as representatives of European citizens, are looking for a significant increase in funding in the 2020 and 2021-2027 budgets to fight climate change, for alternative energy sources, but at the same time to create smart, new, green jobs to invest in new technology. We have a very good chance, not to ask for an apology, but a way to make it happen. We have a chance to be a world leader and I'm sure we can take that chance. May we be carried not by economic predatory in all these jobs as some other world leaders, but by responsibility and long-termism. And let us remember, nature can do without man, but man cannot do without nature.

name: Alexandra Louise Rosenfield PHILLIPS
text: – Mr President, a race we can win, a race we must win, but not for us, for our children. I’ve been so inspired by young people from Greta Thunberg to the youth everywhere. We are relying on our kids to drop out of lessons, to take to the streets, to sail across the Atlantic just to make us politicians act, and their impact has been phenomenal. As a result, this Parliament now has an environmental mandate that we all must act on. The 2015 climate plans still put the world on course to warm by at least 3 degrees by the turn of the century. The EU must commit to net zero by 2030. This means investing in a truly green new deal, which could combat poverty, inequalities and the climate crisis, so I will be taking part in Friday’s global climate strike – to demand that the health of our earth is taken seriously for my son Rafi, for the future of us all.

name: Agnès EVREN
text: Mr President, four years after the signing of the Paris Agreement, there is an abysmal gap between the commitments that have been made and the actions taken by the signatory countries, including some major polluters. However, Commissioner, your communication forgets to mention the crucial role of cities in the fight against climate change, when half of the world's population lives there. Buildings that are too energy-intensive, domestic heating still often dilapidated, traffic saturation, green spaces too rare... Globally, cities produce more than 60% of greenhouse gas emissions. That is why, moreover, the UN Secretary-General has identified cities and local action as one of the priority portfolios of action. My question is twofold: how does the European Commission intend to carry and include the voice of European cities on 23 September? And what significant progress could the Commission make to prove its leadership on this fundamental issue?

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: – Mr President, Commissioner. The election campaign that we have just delivered sent a clear message to this Parliament to prioritise sustainable transition more quickly, and also to take a leading role globally in the climate. I carry with me the young people's demand for us in this Parliament to act much more forcefully than we have historically done. The incoming Commission with Ursula von der Leyen has clearly stated that climate will be the main priority, and also biodiversity in the world. That's commendable. But in New York, we're going to have our opportunity to prove that we're serious. This is where we can show that we are also taking global leadership for the climate and for Agenda 2030. Not least because it will not only be fine words, but that there will also be concrete action. For us Social Democrats, the work on sustainable futures (ecological, social and economic) is the driving force and a driving force for the whole of Europe. We must live up to the Paris Agreement and we must show that this is the major and most important priority for Europe. But the same must also be done globally. It is important that we now bring our Member States together and show concrete action in New York, but that we also show that this means taking both the Paris Agreement and The 2030 Agenda seriously and ensuring that it becomes concrete action. We have a chance now in New York. Let us not neglect it. Europe plays a key role in climate change change. Use that key. Make sure that we become the leading continent and that we show the international community that in Europe we have understood the seriousness and we will take political responsibility.

name: Jutta PAULUS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is now almost four years after the Paris Agreement, and it has become clear that what we have decided to do, namely to keep the earth heating below two degrees – preferably at 1.5 degrees – is becoming increasingly difficult to achieve, because emissions have simply not fallen in these four years. Now next week in New York the Climate Action Summit will be held and – sorry, Mr Caete, Mr Liese – I do not believe that we are in the fast lane with the European Union and that we are overachieving our objectives; there can be no question of that at all. We have signed this 1.5 degrees, and if we look at what we have set ourselves for now, that is not enough, according to what science tells us, especially after last year's Special Report, which once again highlighted how large our carbon budget really is, that is, what we can still emit in terms of emissions. That is why it is time – and I expect the new Commission to do so – for all areas to be included: what impact does this have on climate protection? What impact does this have on our emissions? It is not just energy policy that is part of this, but of course transport policy is one of them, and of course trade policy is one of them! What we are doing here is partly counterproductive, and it even ensures that emissions are still rising elsewhere or that the jungle is being cut down. That is why I appeal: let us really take this emergency seriously and do justice to the young people who take to the streets again on Friday! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: blue card question. Thank you very much. It's not exactly a question. It is support for what my colleague is saying. I hear many times from everyone here that Europe and we as the European Parliament can take the lead. Not only can we, but we must take on this role. That is the mandate we have received from European citizens. The question is: how do we as the European Parliament take this responsibility? It's nice to say we have to take the lead. How can we push to take on this leading role as the European Parliament?

name: Jutta PAULUS
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for your question. I think that Parliament can play a very strong role – because it is our role to step on the toes of the new Commission if they don’t take sufficient action and if they are not prepared to step up to the goals we have already agreed upon for 2030, which – we all know – will not be sufficient for what we all want to achieve. I would like to call on all groups in this Parliament who are concerned about the survival of our civilisation. We have to work together as groups. We have to bridge the gaps between our political views because it is our common not only goal, but obligation. It’s our common obligation to step up in action.  (Applause)

name: Edina TÓTH
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The global fight against climate change and the implementation of the Paris Agreement by all parties is one of the greatest challenges of our time, because the impact of climate change is now not only an economic and welfare problem, but in many cases an existential issue. It is to be welcomed that, at the initiative of the UN Secretary-General, world leaders are once again addressing this issue at the highest level. The European Union can rightly be proud of its achievements and commitment in the fight against climate change. The EU's commitment to 2030 is by far the most ambitious of all the major countries. Hungary is firmly committed to this work and objective. This is evidenced by our performance so far, that GDP growth is divorced from our remaining carbon emissions.  However, the fight against climate change is not just up to the EU, which account for less than 10% of the world's greenhouse gas emissions. This challenge can only be addressed if all states have similar ambitions to the EU. In view of this, it is particularly welcome that the new European Commission's designated Responsible Vice-President has made the management of international climate change negotiations a priority in his credentials. On the part of the EP, this task must be closely monitored, as the future of our planet is at stake.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, climate action, as has already been done in sustainable development, has jumped to the heart of political discourse. But apart from the platitudes, apart from some propaganda, some superficiality and even opportunism with which these issues are dealt with so often, what remains? And what remains is, unfortunately, the insistence on the same policies that have compromised the possibility of a development based on a sustainable relationship between man and nature. Some of those who swear to be committed to climate action, some of those who affirm solemn commitments to sustainable development, are the same ones that have opened the door to policies that sow environmental, economic and social destruction, such as those based on free trade, trade and agricultural policies that promote the relocation of production, that destroy the most devious production systems and that increase the flows of matter and energy associated with meeting the most basic needs. Commissioner, has anyone in the Commission done the math on how much the agreement that has just been concluded with Mercosur will cost greenhouse gas emissions? Let's start here, with more sustainable production and consumption models, and stop trying to paint green a system that is intrinsically unsustainable. The fundamental issue is political and social, and not so much technological. Capitalism is not green.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, the European Union is indeed leading the way in tackling climate change. And that is our acquis, Commissioner Cañete, in the years leading this effort. The European Union does indeed lead legislatively, but it also leads in the implementation of the objectives in the Member States. But obviously what's happening isn't enough. The new green agreement to be presented by Vice-President Timmermans must take account of the competitiveness problems of European industry and the need to rapidly change the origin of the electricity it uses, with an emphasis on renewable energy sources. But the "New Green Deal" must also build on a new global alliance to tackle climate change; a global alliance of willing states, including regions and aiming for new sustainable development, with an emphasis on research funding and new technologies. And this money can come from our Multiannual Financial Framework, from state budgets, from financial instruments but also from the private sector. Energy upgraded buildings for all, tackling energy poverty, circular activity in production and first and for all changing the consumer model can be the basis and pillars for new green growth.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the position of Europe, of the European Union, has been very clear on this subject. Sure, we set targets, we set targets for 2030, for 2050. I believe that the next committee, which will be validated soon, must take a pragmatic approach, find appropriate measures, so as not to miss the 2050 target.  But I think this summit is important because, unfortunately, it is not only Europe that is polluting, and if we take important steps, we know well that the globe is affected by pollution in China, in the US... And I believe that at this summit the representatives of the European institutions must stress this, and this summit must end with concrete measures at global level, and of course I think that the United Nations needs to be more involved on this subject. And I also believe, Commissioner, that it is good that the new multiannual financial framework - let's not forget budgets - reflects the fact that we need investment, we need the support of SMEs to adapt to new measures, and without investment, without innovation, without research, we will not be able to meet the targets.

name: Ellie CHOWNS
text: – Mr President, as we’ve heard, this Friday, around the world young people will spill on to the streets to demand that we all step up action to tackle the climate emergency. I’ve personally found their leadership on this issue both humbling and really inspiring. In response to their call, there are three things that we can all do. We must stand in solidarity with the climate strikers, first of all. We must each reflect on our own behaviour and live more lightly on the planet. But, most importantly, as representatives, we must work for systemic change. We in Europe have built our prosperity on the use of fossil fuels and on resource exploitation, a model that we have exported worldwide. The result has been a world facing a climate crisis and unacceptable inequality. We therefore have a special responsibility to show leadership in achieving zero carbon and in tackling global inequality. There’s still insufficient ambition both in this House and in our national parliaments to tackle the climate crisis. Warm words about a Green New Deal need to be translated into policies: no trade policy that encourages deforestation and no investment in fossil fuels; instead, public transport, zero carbon buildings, green agriculture. We in Europe need to put our money where our mouth is and take this opportunity of zero carbon transition to build the societies and economies that our children deserve.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, setting targets and talk of ambitions will not be worth a damn if the policies the EU adopts make things worse rather than better: The IPCC has called for near-term reductions in natural gas production of 15% by 2030 and 43% by 2050, relative to 2020. These kind of reductions are not compatible with the expansion of the current natural gas system, including the building of new, liquefied natural gas capacity and the importation of frack gas from the US.  So why are we are expanding our liquefied natural gas systems? Because Shell, one of the biggest polluters on the planet, successfully lobbied the Commission in the lead-up to the 2014 EU climate pact. The idea that gas is a more suitable transition fuel than an energy approach based on renewables was created by Shell. Commissioner, do you not think that achieving higher reduction targets is unlikely to be achieved unless we challenge neoliberalism?

name: Radan KANEV
text: – Mr President, we are all alarmed by the climate crisis. I would say more – we are worried about the general environmental crisis, which threatens water, forests and the production of enough food both on our continent and on our planet. But we are alarmed by one more thing – the presence of too many words and too few deeds in this policy. The question is: why? My answer is: because no policy can be successful if it is not fundamentally addressed to the needs of the people, that is, to be a policy that saves, not destroys, farmers; which supports, rather than disesties small business; which ensures the preservation of the metal, steel, aluminum industry in Europe; a policy that develops, modernises energy and coal areas, rather than obscuring and depopulating them. In order to have such a policy, I believe we need to address precisely those young people who are protesting and, above all, be leaders in science, innovation and education – something that Europe is not.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, climate change is the greatest challenge that humanity has ever faced. We face a huge challenge of mitigation, adaptation and protection of biodiversity. The scientific consensus on these priorities is unquestionable, but many question the evidence and withdraw from multilateral agreements that are crucial to the defense of the planet.  It is in this context that António Guterres convened the Climate Action Summit in New York as early as next week with the aim of encouraging heads of state to increase their contribution to reducing emissions. In the European Union we have done so from the very first hour. We are, at global level, the economy that has shown the most ambition in combating climate change, an ambition reinforced by the new Commission.  In the previous mandate I was part of the negotiating team of the Energy Union Governance Regulation and we were able to close a strong agreement, and we can now go even further. The challenge of decarbonization is a global challenge. Let us not hesitate to share what we have achieved at the legislative level and let us be quick to achieve this. Commissioner, we have a plan, we have 27 national plans, we have a European Union plan. Let's make them happen!

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this rich and engaging debate, which demonstrates that climate policy and development goals policy are truly at the heart of the European debate. I will start with some words from Mr Peter Liese. Mr Liese says that sometimes we Europeans criticise ourselves too much, but I think that in New York the European Union, thanks to the efforts of this Parliament or the former Parliament, has a very good story to tell. Our energy legislation was approved in this House with 80%, on average, of the votes cast. Our climate legislation was approved here with more than 78% of the votes cast. There was wide support for the efforts that the Commission had put on the table to deliver ambitious climate policy. And where are we now, what’s the story we can tell in New York? We Europeans have the most ambitious nationally determined contribution (NDC) of all those expressed by the parties to the Climate Convention, reducing our emissions by at least 40% by 2030 compared with 1990. But what is most important is that we have all the binding legislation needed to achieve this target and in fact – thanks to Parliament’s ambition – to over—achieve this target, because with the current legislation we will reduce our emissions by 45%. So we have an ambitious target, we have binding legislation, and we have strong governance in the form of integrated national climate action plans. No other party in the world has this. If the government changes in the United States, the policy changes. In the European elections, elections result in different governments every time but the policy remains the same. So we have ambitious commitments, we have strong legislation and we have put on the table a very ambitious climate-neutral study for 2050. In the October Council, 24 Member States endorsed this legislation – there are only four missing at the moment – and I have high expectations that in the December Council this climate neutrality for 2050 will be a reality in the European Union. It will be extremely important: climate neutrality in 2050 is much more ambitious than the pathways of the International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), because the IPCC says that globally we have to become climate neutral after 2060 and before 2080.  We will become the first major economy to become climate neutral in 2050, and that’s a good story to tell, notably because, in the new Commission, the President-elect has committed to proposing a European Green Deal in the first 100 days of her term, and that will include the first European climate law to enshrine the 2050 climate neutrality target. We have a strong story to tell.  In addition, the President-elect wants to reduce emissions by 50% in 2030 and not by 2055. So we will go to New York with a good story. And we will go too with lots of support for developing countries to be able to implement climate action, because what is important is not that the European Union is the most ambitious it has ever been, and that we are delivering and will deliver on our commitments, but that we are also supporting other people in delivering and are doing outreach to convince the world that it has to work in this direction.  We are the biggest donor of climate finance to developing countries, more than EUR 20 billion every year, so we can be proud of what we have done. We have a lot of ground to cover because we have to work to be world leaders, because if we are world leaders – developing renewables, developing energy efficiency, phasing out fossil fuels and creating growth and jobs in the green economy – then the rest of the world will follow us.  So we have a responsibility because if the European Union does not assume the leadership then nobody will assume it – here, in climate policy or on the Sustainable Development Goals. I am pretty sure that the new Commission will take that responsibility on board and that this Parliament will give the next Commission the same degree of support that they gave to me.  When we made proposals, Parliament improved the proposals. Now with the commitments of the President-elect, I’m also sure that this Parliament will raise the level of ambition. Just two comments. Becoming climate neutral is a revolution, an economic and social revolution, bigger probably than the industrial revolution, because it changes the way you produce energy, changes the way you heat and cool, changes how your industry is going to produce goods and the means whereby we transport ourselves. It’s a revolution. Changing the way our agriculture has to reduce methane emissions and the use of fertilisers is a big revolution and it produces different impacts in different territories. The impacts are asymmetrical, but there must be a fair and just social transition, and for that the Just Transition Fund becomes fundamental. I am extremely happy that the President-elect has declared the Commission will support the people in the regions most affected through a Just Transition Fund. This is fundamental because nobody should be left behind in the big transformation that the European economic and social system must envisage in the next few years. So we will be ambitious on climate policy but we also have to look after our citizens, our people, so that this is a socially just and fair transition. A final very specific word on the comment made by Mr Ferreira. He referred to the impact of trade agreements and to Mercosur in relation to climate policy. I just want to say that the European Union is strongly committed to leveraging its trade policy to promote climate action in partner countries and to project our approach to climate policies and standards. We have delivered on this commitment in all the agreements negotiated in the past year. The Mercosur Association Agreement follows this approach. It has an ambitious, dedicated ‘trade and sustainable development’ chapter, including legally binding commitments related to environmental protection and climate change, and with respect to the Paris Agreement it contains the strongest form of commitment. Each party commits individually to effectively implementing the Paris Climate Agreement, including in respect of the nationally determined contributions. This means that withdrawal from the Paris Agreement or a breach of its commitments will also be a breach of the EU-Mercosur Agreement, and the commitment to effective implementation of the Paris Agreement is particularly meaningful where partners have made a strong nationally determined contribution under the Paris Agreement.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Writing. – Only by making the EU climate neutral by 2040 will we stop the climate crisis. To do this, we need to change our society. We need a Green New Deal with massive investment in our climate and for social participation; if we do not do so, we shall ensure that the already devastating costs of damage to the climate are borne by the coming budgets and thus by the younger generations. Member States are doing too little to meet the EU's climate targets. We are far from meeting the goals we have set ourselves – Germany, in particular, should finally begin to act seriously and set an example here. Sham measures and symbolic politics are of no use and are a blow to future generations and to the already socially disadvantaged groups in the population. The costs of short-term profit models are passed on to them in the long term – we do not want to let that happen. Millions of young people have been taking to the streets around the world for months; they are right to demand that we leave the paths we have taken and that we take action and our economy and finally break new ground: for their future and for our planet. From our point of view, fair and forward-looking policies are based on immediate, radical measures for environmentally sound and climate-friendly restructuring at all levels of our action. For this we need Climate Action Now!

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Writing. Today, more than 2 billion, a third of the world's population, are estimated to be completely wealthless and poor, who are increasingly threatened by livelihood and social problems, including climate change. It is estimated that by 2030, an additional 100 million people could be severely deprived and more than 200 million people could be displaced by climate change and climate disasters. This means that climate change could hamper the success of important global efforts to eradicate the world's poor, such as the UN Sustainable Development Goals, which aims to eradicate extreme poverty in 15 years. Impoverished communities and low-income countries are particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change and poor people lose much more than average. They are more vulnerable to natural disasters, such as floods, which can wash away assets and livelihoods and increase the risk of waterborne diseases such as malaria. If we do not act urgently, climate change will catalyse the rise of poverty. We therefore need a platform to combat climate change and poverty and a comprehensive EU strategy against poverty, where we can come up with integrated solutions to address these global problems

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: The following is the debate on Mr Gualtieri's report on the appointment of the President of the European Central Bank (N9-0023/2019 - C9-0048/2019 - 2019/0810(NLE)) (A9-0008/2019). Before opening the debate I would like to inform, and remind those who already know it, that in this plenary session we will test the new system of electronic registration of catch-the-eye and 'blue card' applications.  The information was made available to members. The instructions are in your places and therefore to submit requests for intervention "catch-the-eye" and "blue card" you can use their buttons in the appropriate functions of your electronic voting devices.  While the system is under test, it is still possible to make requests in the old, traditional way, but we invite Members to use the new methodology, which means that they should not forget to bring the voting card with them so that they can participate in the debates through these electronic instruments. I will then start our debate. As you know, the report at the base of our debate was a report by our former colleague Roberto Gualtieri, who in the meantime became Italy's Minister of Economy and to whom we certainly wish the best wishes in the performance of these duties. For the presentation of this report, he was replaced by our colleague Irene Tinagli, who was elected yesterday as President of the ECON Commission, replacing our colleague Gualtieri on this task. We also wish her the greatest successes in the performance of her duties in this very important committee of this Parliament.  It is to her that I give, therefore, the floor at the beginning of our debate. Mrs Tinagli has six minutes of intervention, as she has expressed interest in exhausting her initial and final intervention time in the same opening intervention. Then there is the word mrs Tinagli.

name: Irene TINAGLI
text: Chair of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. – Mr President, with this report the European Parliament delivers its opinion on the appointment of the fourth President of the European Central Bank – an institution which became a fundamental pillar not only for the conduct of monetary policies but also for the whole process of Europe’s economic integration. The nomination of Christine Lagarde as the first woman to serve in this position, which is itself something historic, is happening fortuitously only a few months after the solemn celebration in this Chamber of the euro’s 20th anniversary. The single currency is, first and foremost, a powerful economic tool. Not only is it the natural and indispensable complement to the single market, but it is also, as President Mario Draghi often recalls in his speeches, the prerequisite for preserving monetary sovereignty in an increasingly global and interconnected world. The euro though is more than a mere economic tool: it is, above all, an ambitious political project. It is the cornerstone of a European Union of peace and prosperity and the indispensable instrument for protecting and supporting the European economic, social and political model – as we face the important transformations of our time. Over the past 20 years – despite the imperfection and incompleteness of European economic governance – the single currency has shown amazing strength and resilience, even when confronted with one of the toughest economic crises in history. In addition to the political determination to maintain its integrity, the commitment by the European Central Bank and its Presidents – within their terms of reference, of course – to preserve the single currency through concrete monetary-policy action has made a fundamental contribution to protecting the euro and hence the well-being of all European citizens.
