The 76 written answers provided by the candidate, which are attached to the report being voted on today, as well as the intense hearing before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on 4 September, show, I believe, not only Christine Lagarde’s awareness of the task and the challenges ahead but also her suitability to take up the baton from her predecessors and to keep on pursuing this important mission. The large consensus which the candidate obtained in the committee constitutes, I believe, a good basis for the outcome of today’s vote. However, our task does not end here. In accordance with the Treaties and in line with our committee’s work and that of Parliament as a whole, we will keep on monitoring the activity and decisions of the ECB, inter alia through quarterly monetary dialogues, annual reports and written questions from MEPs. As always, we will be demanding. And we will expect an institution that lives up to the fundamental task it is expected to perform. If we want to reach our ambitious objectives, however, the strength and the stability of the euro is not sufficient. We need to add new institutions, new tools and truly European economic policies to monetary-policy measures. It is imperative to pursue an authentic deepening of our economic and monetary union, as was stated too in the programme presented by Commission President-elect Ursula von der Leyen, which includes measures to ensure the full implementation of the social pillar, as well as growth-oriented revision of European economic governance. In this context, as co-legislator, we are ready to accept the challenge.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, it is always an honour to take part in the deliberations of the European Parliament. Today’s vote on the candidate for the President of the European Central Bank is particularly important as the ECB plays a central role in EU economic policy. The Treaties enshrine the independence of the European Central Bank in its conduct of monetary policy. This is a principle that the Commission defends wholeheartedly as it is crucial for achieving the objective of safeguarding price stability. But independence and accountability go hand in hand. Today’s vote is an important manifestation of the mechanisms by which the ECB is held to account towards the European Parliament. The importance of the debates and the positions expressed by this Parliament are evident from the choice of the Council to propose Christine Lagarde as ECB President. I concur with the view of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) and the ECB Governing Council that Christine Lagarde has all the credentials for the job. Her appointment is moreover a strong signal for gender balance within the ECB, something on which the Parliament has repeatedly taken a clear stance. The ECB’s role in the European economy cannot be overstated. The European Central Bank is tasked by the Treaties to secure price stability, a precondition for a well-functioning monetary area. The ECB’s decisive actions during the financial and economic crisis have averted a serious threat of deflation and allowed the euro area economy to recover steadily in recent years. However, the low inflation environment has become a persistent feature within the most advanced economies since the post-crisis period and monetary policy alone is not able to change that. For a more balanced and effective policy mix monetary policy should be supported by structural reforms and fiscal policy. On the side of structural reforms, we need to use all levers to facilitate the transformation which Europe’s businesses and employees will need to embark on in the coming years amid challenges like climate change, the digital age and global and political uncertainty. As regards fiscal policies, within the limits of fiscal sustainability, fiscal policy can provide a boost to domestic demand and investment. Christine Lagarde also stressed this point in her opening statement in the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee and I could not agree more. In the longer term, I strongly believe that the deepening of economic and monetary union is also essential. In particular, deeper and better connected European capital markets and a completion of the banking union are key building blocks for a stronger and more resilient euro area. So I look forward to hearing your views and continuing our good cooperation with the European Central Bank.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work he has The monetary policy of the European Central Bank has been the topic of intense debate by many observers in recent years. This often gives the impression that the ECB is more economic lyrised than pursuing the primary objective of its mandate, which is to ensure price stability. Last week's decision to reinstate the bond-buying program, to cut interest rates even further, has once again poured oil on the fire. The European Central Bank under Mario Draghi has thus lost a great deal of confidence, as we are now also saying in the published opinion. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats are all the more pleased that Christine Lagarde, at the hearing in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, made her clear about the objectives enshrined in the Treaty. And, dear friends of social democracy, you are not blind and deaf when you comply with the Treaty, but you are faithful to the law. I would ask you to take note of this. In the medium term, however, committing to this goal also means that the European Central Bank must exit ultra-loose monetary policy in the medium term. The European economy, and also some european Union countries, cannot hang permanently on the drip of cheap money. Against this background, it is also laudable that Christine Lagarde has set herself the task of better communicating the monetary policy of the European Central Bank. This is urgently needed. Independence does not mean that you are not accountable for the decisions you have made. But better communication also means that Mrs Lagarde not only explains, but also listens and responds to criticism of monetary policy. These are the main questions for the future. The ECB needs to refocus on its mandate, communicate its decisions better. Because Mrs Lagarde has promised both, we will today, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, vote in favour of the appointment of Mrs Lagarde.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I said that thank you very much for the floor, for this debate, Mr Dombrovskis, for being here. Two weeks ago we had in the ECON Commission the candidate to chair the ECB, in an intervention which we consider clearly satisfactory. Firstly, because candidate Lagarde made a clear bet on maintaining a continuing line with the work that Mario Draghi has done at the ECB in recent years and which has undoubtedly managed to save the euro at very critical times. But in addition, the candidate advocated reviewing the conceptual framework of monetary policy — the monetary policy framework — obviously within the Treaties, Mr Ferber, within the Treaties. But within the Treaties there is sufficient scope to review how to achieve such price stability. And I will also say ⸻learning that Commissioner Dombrovskis is here⸻ that we need a fiscal policy that clearly accompanies monetary policy, because other words we will not be able to lead the cycle.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, we are not here to evaluate Mrs Lagarde's credentials. The reality is that two weeks ago we had a meeting of the Committee on Economic and Economic Affairs where we evaluated her credentials and she passed the review in an extremely satisfactory way. We are here because some Members want to use the opportunity to criticise the actions of the European Central Bank over the past seven years. The reality is that the European Central Bank has been the institution it has been willing to fight, the only one that has been willing to fight a recession and a crisis that would have had unthinkable consequences without its action. And some say, "monetary policy is trying to do too much, the European Central Bank is doing too much." And it is true, it is doing a lot, yes, but the reason is not because the European Central Bank wants it, the reason is because the Member States are not doing their part. Member States , as Mrs Lagarde said in her speech, can do quite a few things. On the one hand, half of the Member States of the European Union have no deficit or are close to zero. Given the context of interest rates, virtually zero, they can invest in their future, not because they are very good and want to do good for other States, but because it is the right thing for their own citizens. Similarly, states that have much less fiscal capacity, like my own country, such as Spain, can also do something. They can fight to make these structural reforms that are now paralyzed—reforms in the education market or labour market—and allow countries to acquire a much higher growth rate. Finally, we, the European Parliament and the European institutions can also do much more. We have paralyzed dossiers that we have to put in place, such as common deposit insurance or common unemployment insurance. We have a lot of things to do to make the growth rate recover. In short, we will vote in favour of Mrs Lagarde, because we think she is qualified. We think she's going to do her part of the job. The question is, will we?

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The discussion about Ms. Lagarde's nomination is actually, I think, a distraction discussion. There is a clear signal, and the appointment of Mrs Lagarde is, in fact, a confirmation of the basic course under Mario Draghi and the ECB. It was the ECB that saved the euro; without the ECB, we would no longer have price stability, because the most unstable currency is also one that no longer has price stability. A crumbling currency is not stable per se. That is why these attacks that the ECB has not fulfilled its mandate are completely out of the business. Instead, we have a situation where the Member States of the euro area are not doing their job, both in those countries that are facing economic problems, which are not making good progress in reforms, in socially just reforms that are also boosting the economy, but also in the surplus countries that are currently reducing debt, rather than giving room for economic development to take off, precisely in the sense of an ecological and social transformation of our economy. We are therefore pleased that Mrs Lagarde has made it clear that the Member States must adopt a common fiscal policy. This is the prerequisite for monetary policy to stop taking the risks associated with over-lax monetary policy. And we also have clear signals: for the first time, a woman at the head of the ECB and a greening of the common monetary policy. These are clear commitments from Mrs Lagarde, and we are pleased about that.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: on behalf of the ID Group. Mr President, colleagues of the bipartisan majority in the European Parliament, which is no longer based on EPP and Socialists, but of the now tripartiete majority in the European Parliament. Despite the extension of your majority, you have only dragged your German and French designations to the EU top positions with all kinds of artifice. For the Macron find Ursula von der Leyen you even had to include the 5 Stelle in your majority game. Yes, even a substantial part of the Poles from the ECR owes her narrow election.  One of the keys to your shaky majority is the appointment of your ECP chairman, in the person of Mrs Lagarde. What we certainly know now is that she will be a slave to your unrealistic eurozone policy. She said she would support the restart of Draghi's helicopter money blindly, so that you, ladies and gentlemen of this majority, will be able to further thrawate this continent under debt and, above all, under public debt, and Mrs Lagarde to your applause which is starting to sound more and more like the orchestra on the Titanic. We will, of course, vote against it.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the ECB, the European Central Bank is actually the most powerful institution in the European Union. But where does this institution stand at the moment? If we look at last week, we see that this institution is also very divided. The euro area itself is already divided between north and south and different countries, institutions, politics between countries and within countries. But last week there was a meeting of the ECB, where Mr Draghi fired a final shot and announced that he would continue to print money, make more debt and so on. And of course keep interest rates as low as possible. Several presidents of European banks, including the Dutch and German national central banks, have opposed this. They represent 60% of the economic value within the euro area: 60% of the economic force has spoken out against Mr. Draghi, but Mr. Draghi continues. I would have liked to have seen what Mrs Lagarde thought of that, but she is not here. She conducts the politics of the empty chair. And who are the losers in this whole game? These are the savers who are seeing their savings reduced. These are the pensioners who are seeing their pensions shrink and these are young people who are not coming to work and you wonder: where should this euro go? There is an imminent recession and the citizens are exposed to these forces without their defense.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what a strange feeling for the newly elected representatives that we are to have this debate on the presidency of the European Central Bank without the single candidate, Mrs Lagarde, deigning to be present. Yet it is now more than ever time to discuss together the role of the ECB and the objectives it must pursue. Because the currency is political and has nothing neutral, neither for the climate nor for inequality. Inequality, the word Christine Lagarde knows well and which she had in her mouth when she was president of the IMF, appears only twice in her questionnaire. On the other hand, price stability appears 26 times. When we talk to her about the climate or the reduction of inequality, she gives us the same answer: price stability. As a result, the ECB has injected more than EUR 2 trillion into the markets, of which only 10% has ended up in the real economy. The rest fueled a speculative bubble. For too long, monetary policy has served the richest. Even Mario Draghi recognized him. Despite the crisis - and the Greek example has tragically demonstrated this - the ECB still does not plan to put its policy at the service of the greatest number. So we heard Christine Lagarde and the European Commission speak in unison about Green Deal. But is it ready to stop funding those responsible for the disaster? No. Is it prepared to end the 63% of private debt buybacks that benefit polluting companies? No. Is it prepared to lend directly to the states to finance the ecological transition? Still not. Is it ready to focus on green financing? No. Above all, there should be no distortion in the sacrosanct market. And never mind if the planet has to pay the price. This obsession with the market is not suited to the emergencies of our time. Let us choose instead a monetary policy in the service of ecological and social transformation, an ECB that ensures that the money reinvested in the real economy stops financing polluting activities, assumes to regulate the market to favour green assets.  That is what we would have said to Mrs Lagarde if she had deigned to be here with us today. This is what our exchanges should be about rather than preparing a pre-run vote for a person convicted in court in his or her country. Count on us not to let our guard down today and throughout the mandate that opens up for a monetary policy that serves what it must serve as a priority: the peoples and the planet.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Madam President, the European Union, capital and governments are worried about a new capitalist economic crisis. They are prepared by shielding the financial system, the banks, the big monopolies, which over the past decade have received hundreds of billions in liquidity injections, money cut from wages and pensions, the rights of the peoples of Europe. The policy of banking integration of the financial area requires clearing banks of red loans, also owing them to private funds, focusing on the hundreds of thousands of micro-debtors across the European Union, blackmailed by auctions and foreclosures, instead of the huge debts of entrepreneurs. The appointment of President of the European Central Bank is not a matter for a person. The Bank of the European Union's current unpopular mission does not change. Whoever takes over will implement the enhanced supervision, the European semesters, the bloody primary surpluses, and any relaxation plans will again concern large companies. This is the capitalist system. The peoples of Europe must organise themselves and fight for their modern needs against the profit and power of monopolies in each country.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, I was a central banker for most of my working life so this is an emotional issue for me, in addition to being an issue of very great importance. We were lucky to have excellent chiefs of the European Central Bank (ECB), such as Jean—Claude Trichet and Mario Draghi, and we must keep the standard high. It was said that the European Central Bank has changed in the last decade and so the profile of the appointment has changed. Instead of looking for top—notch academia economists or experienced central bankers, those who make appointments also look for people not just with strong economic backgrounds but with political skills and experience of the financial sector. From this point of view, Christine Lagarde, for me, is an excellent choice and she has my full support. And I guess her appointment was supported at the lengthy hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, which I had the privilege to chair a few days ago. Still, we have one great risk ahead of us: it seems to me that many ministers and politicians believe that some mysterious magic monetary policy can serve as a replacement for necessary, badly needed economic reforms. That’s not right and I believe Christine Lagarde is well-positioned to stress the importance of policies other than just monetary policy. I hope she will be listened to carefully by ministers.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, I will focus on two issues relating to the future and fair competition. Firstly, the delay in completing the Banking Union with a pan-European deposit guarantee is not so much due to technical issues, which exist but are manageable. It is more due to political opposition from certain Member States. In other words, we now have a Banking Union without joint protection for small depositors. We have a "common house without a common roof". And that's not a technical issue. The states particularly affected by the banking crisis have accepted the first two pillars of the Banking Union at enormous economic and social costs. The second issue concerns European legislation, which requires the elimination of abusive practices, which unfortunately are used and survive, in particular, because of the power that banks have towards borrowers. That is why we expect the European Central Bank to have a more active and active role.

name: Stéphanie YON-COURTIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is very surprising to prejudge the future policy of the ECB, even though its new President, Christine Lagarde, will not take office until a few weeks from now. As you all know here, if Mrs Lagarde is confirmed as head of the European Central Bank, she will have to deal with the Governing Council. They will then be twenty-five around the table, the six members of the ECB's Executive Board and the nineteen governors of the eurozone countries. So it will be, as you know, a collegial operation. Let me remind you that, during her hearing before our ECON committee, Mrs Lagarde described in three points how she viewed the function. First, she reiterated the need to respect the ECB's regulatory framework. It then indicated that it would adapt to the context of the current upheavals with agility and pragmatism. She also said, and this was reiterated by our EPP colleague, Mr Ferber, that there was a need to include civil society, young people, to better inform public opinion. Furthermore, it indicated that the core of its action at the head of the ECB would be based on taking climate risk into account, which will be a macro-economic priority for the ECB. It will therefore have to phase out the financial securities of the polluting companies it holds on its balance sheet. Lagarde also reiterated that fiscal stimulus will be needed, given the short-term challenges for the eurozone. Admittedly, the ECB is currently pursuing a very low interest rate policy, which can be worrying for savers. However, it also allows citizens to borrow, first-time buyers to acquire a property for the first time and businesses to borrow to invest and create jobs. Colleagues, let us be positive, certainly by being vigilant, but also bold, because in addition to being a woman, the first to hold this position, Christine Lagarde presents a strong asset to meet the challenges of the ECB for the next few years, namely her experience at the head of the IMF and the pragmatism that characterizes her. It is therefore up to us to work in a collective and constructive spirit in the economic, social and ecological interest of our citizens and our companies.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, with Germany on the brink of recession, the risk of a tough Brexit and the trade war, asking the European Central Bank to turn up the rates and not continue with its unconventional policies is a real suicide and, moreover, would not continue with the mandate entrusted to it. Therefore, these policies have to continue; of course, compensating for those negative effects that exist: tackging the housing bubble through macroeconomic guidance and also– of course – stop buying carbon-linked assets, which in recent years have not favored the fight against climate change. That must be done. But also, as many of my colleagues have said, the European Central Bank's measures must be offset by fiscal policy. Those States that have room to spend must do so in the face of the coming cycle. And I would also like to ask Commissioner Dombrovskis to open the debate in the Commission on tax rules. It has been requested by the European Public Prosecutor's Council; Even Mr Regling of the EESM said so the other day: that the rules should be revised. Do not give in to some Member States in the face of this debate and provide us with a revision of the tax rules, as envisaged in accordance with the initial will of this next European Commission.

name: Antonio Maria RINALDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would simply like to make a comment. In past years, all the ECB's monetary policy action has failed for a very simple reason: it has not been possible to pass this enormous liquidity capacity on to the real economy. Entrepreneurs across Europe have not enjoyed the huge amount of liquidity even, for example, with quantitative easing operations. We need that. It does not matter whether interest is zero or even negative: European entrepreneurs want to have prompt access to credit. Mrs Lagarde, at a hearing in the ECON Committee, was unable to give sufficient answers to this question. Of course, the ECB's actions are used to save the euro, but certainly not businesses across Europe. Our vote is certain: as far as we are concerned, it will be negative.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: Mr President, Mrs Lagarde, because she will be, is coming to the ECB at a critical time and for three reasons.  Firstly, last Thursday we saw a rather unique spectacle of more than 50% voting against Draghi's policy within the ECB in terms of economic weight, as well as two members of Mr Draghi's executive committee. That's never been seen before. The second point of great importance for Mrs Lagarde, of course, is that the institutional framework for the euro is still not finished. The banking union is not finished. The capital markets union, which is absolutely necessary, must also be further initiated.  Thirdly, and perhaps most importantly, the ECB – and Mrs Lagarde, therefore – must gradually realise that there needs to be more explanation and more explanation of what I call the negative side effects of the policy that has been going on for years and which intensified last Thursday. I refer to the clearly increased risk of financial instability. This policy encourages the formation of bubbles. Secondly, insurance companies, pension funds and banks are finding it increasingly difficult to meet their obligations and will experience this even more with the intensification of policies. The third side effect, of course, is the attack on the savings of the modal citizen. Fourth and often underestimated, but very real: the phenomenon of zombie firms being further strengthened and the misallocation of capital that goes with it.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: – Madam President, this European Parliament is preparing to give a positive opinion to place in the most important position for economic policies in Europe a representative of the economic doctrine of shock and dread, of the economic policy of salvation through recession, which has presided over adjustment programmes with consequences as tragic from an economic and budgetary point of view as it is counterproductive from an economic and budgetary point of view , and it is a pity that many of those who, sooner or later, have criticised these adjustment programmes are available to forget this route on the basis of half a dozen more or less sympathetic public statements.  It is true that it is not the role of the President of the ECB to free the euro zone from a mediocre growth strategy addicted to instruments, in the permanent use of extraordinary monetary policy instruments, but we know that we have a climate crisis today and that we will have an economic crisis in the near future, and we also know from her path that Christine Lagarde will be a force of opposition to the fiscal and public service policies that we will need to have to respond to them.

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Madam President, as a Hungarian-born Belgian economist, the father of the euro, Alexandre Lamfalussy, made it crystal clear that a single currency cannot be successful without a fiscal union, which entails a common social, labour and – most importantly – wage policy.  Twenty years after the introduction of the euro, the EU and the eurozone are characterised by enormous social differences, mass migration of the work force from the periphery to the core countries, high youth unemployment and the demographic decline. If the European Union and the European Central Bank do not deal with structural differences, social problems will lead to increased state debt – with further instability of the euro – and economic austerity will lead to anti-EU sentiment, weakening European cooperation.  This is why I would like to see in this report some references to how the ECB will mitigate this risk of a social disaster and what the policy recommendations are to reduce the wage gap between the periphery and the core countries, and between the old and the new Member States.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Many of us have been able to convince ourselves in the discussions with Mrs Christine Lagarde in recent years, but now also in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs: she is the right person at the right time in the right place. We need for an independent European Central Bank, for an independent monetary policy, for people with experience and independence, with foresight and prudence, with a calm hand and trust, with global responsibility, with a willingness to communicate, the will to justify the decisions in a comprehensible way, and consistency, reliability and clarity. We need a credible, determined speaker or speaker, a general manager of the world's second largest currency, the european union's common currency, our euro. And we have already said it today: let us not make it too easy for ourselves! A successful monetary policy cannot replace the lack of a common euro budget, a completed banking and capital markets union, a common economic policy, budget policy and structural policy. Let us not make it so easy for ourselves by criticising low interest rates and, on the other hand, only distracting ourselves from our own reforms – let us also do our homework!

name: Aurore LALUCQ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is my first term as an MEP, and I must confess that I am indeed a little surprised that Mrs Lagarde is not here to listen to us, that this debate is finally reduced to a succession of speaking time. As a parliamentarian, I admit that I am a little surprised, but that is the way it is. As for Ms. Lagarde, her hearing was very genuinely quite seductive. Two concerns, however. The first is the arrowing of monetary policy. While it was absolutely essential to pursue a generous monetary policy, it is essential to ensure that it does not feed speculation and that it is directed towards green investment in order to avoid a new banking and financial crisis. On this point, we do not have enough guarantees. Another point is crisis management. Eight years is a long time and we will probably go through a banking and financial crisis. However, on this subject, Christine Lagarde did not shine when she managed the Greek crisis. It may have changed, it may have come out of its ideological straitjacket, but we do not have enough, it seems to me, of guarantees on how it will prevent one crisis and how it will manage the next one.

name: Dragoș PÎSLARU
text: – Madam President, the election of the President of the European Central Bank is not only a change of person, but also an opportunity to have a new agenda at European level containing at least three key points.  Firstly, we need a transparent monetary and banking system that restores confidence, increases the confidence of European citizens; a system with zero tolerance for corruption and money laundering and provide a new vision of the important things on the new agenda. It is about climate change, digitalisation and, of course, social inclusion. Secondly, a strong action plan is needed to improve access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises, given today's fragmentation and the fact that today entrepreneurs are discouraged in many European countries.  Thirdly, there is a need to improve and strengthen enhanced support for countries that are not yet in the euro area, for access to this area by meeting the criteria of real and nominal convergence. There is a need for countries such as Romania to strengthen this support to facilitate reforms.  These are the elements of a new agenda that we want from Mrs Lagarde's leadership.

name: Stasys JAKELIŪNAS
text: – Madam President, the financial industry has been playing a destabilising role in the economy for decades now. In some cases it conducts monetary policy itself. I am afraid, on the basis of her hearing and the written answers, that Ms Lagarde doesn’t seem fully to understand all that and all its implications. Massive leverage, reckless lending – mortgage lending especially – at teaser rates, variable rates and lending in foreign currencies, especially Swiss francs, contributed to the consumer abuse and also to the global crisis. Some of the emerging risks have been mentioned already, but I would like to mention the new risks coming with the advent of financial technologies, especially the so—called crypto currencies which are not currencies at all. I’m not sure that Ms Lagarde understands all these emerging risks. Wishing her well and wishing the European Central Bank well, I think there is work to be done by the ECB, as well as other supervisory institutions and Parliament here, in order to prevent a global crisis and to protect our citizens.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today, the plenary elects Christine Lagarde as ECB President. In the ECON Committee two weeks ago, she openly confessed that the ECB had regularly failed to respect the EU treaties since 2010, and that transgressions in the public interest were to be expected in the future, Lagarde said. That alone makes Lagarde the most honest power politician west of Prague. Lagarde's predecessor, Draghiavelli, printed more money and broke more joyful law than anyone anywhere. Nevertheless, the EU grew more slowly than the entire developed world without Japan, and the eurozone grew even more slowly than the rest of the EU. THE DZ-Bank estimates Draghi's expropriation of German savers alone at a whopping 650 billion euros. And because it puts people in the making of their hard-earned money and only enriches Draghi's "cronies," Draghi prescribed the terminally ill euro twice the dose of medicine again last week. The euro has been in intensive care since 2010, and the fact that it is now becoming morphine-dependent does not bother anyone, because the patient never gets away there until the exitus. She honours Mrs Lagarde's boldness by openly admitting the contempt for the law state in the EU. But it does not act in the public interest. The ECB socializes the costs of irresponsible government policy and private greed. The euro is not a public good and, unfortunately, the ECB is no more than a financial servant.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Madam President, with monetary policy relaxed, governments are motivated to make the necessary reforms. When we have a poor economic environment, such as a high level of clientelism, rules where it is not worth working, or a business environment in which it is not worth investing, then we politicians must have the expertise and courage to remedy these shortcomings. We cannot rely on this work at a microeconomic level for us to be solved by loose monetary policy in the long term. With relaxed monetary policy, little is said about its negative side effects, about the devaluation of savings, about surviving and keeping zombie firms and zombie projects alive, which only in difficult times will show how dangerous they are to humans. The European Central Bank would be helped by greater transparency, such as providing information at least to the European Court of Auditors so that independent institutions can also do the benefit of an ECB policy analysis. I fear that the ECB will not improve its functioning even after the change in leadership, and I will vote accordingly.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have tried very hard to find even one reason to support the appointment of Christine Lagarde as President of the European Central Bank, without success, unfortunately. Because Christine Lagarde has been jointly responsible for all those policies that have increased public debt disproportionately in the European Union just to bail out private, German and French banks in the first place. And once that public debt has grown disproportionately, those austerity policies have been justified, which then became the structural reforms that Valdis Dombrovskis first mentioned, which means wage compression, cuts in services, pension cuts: a gigantic work of bottom-up redistribution, where the rich have become richer and the poor are getting poorer. Now they're telling us that things have changed, that they realized they were wrong, but it's too late! We're not going to trust Christine Lagarde. We wait before we see that the changes are real and then, perhaps, we can talk about them again.

name: José Manuel GARCÍA-MARGALLO Y MARFIL
text: – Madam President, I am convinced that the Council has chosen Mrs Lagarde because it is the closest thing to Draghi that you have been able to find on the market. And I am glad, because without Draghi today there would be no euro. And I'm glad, because we're probably on the eve not only of a slowdown, but of a new crisis. And experts say that this crisis will not be a crisis of demand, as was the Lehman Brothers crisis, but a supply-driven crisis, sponsored by geopolitical factors, which I would list in four letters: A, B, C, I; America, Brexit, China, Iran. These geopolitical factors can lead to a breakdown of production chains and a drop in global wealth. And the answer will have to be, in the short term, the monetary policy that Draghi and Lagarde advocate; budgetary policy, especially in those countries that have scope, such as Germany; but, in the medium term, a policy of holistic structural reforms will be needed. And there Parliament has to be.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The policy of the European Central Bank is coming under increasing criticism. Are negative interest rates also threatening small savings? Can loose monetary policy still meet its objectives or are there no new dangers on the horizon? These are issues that are perishering public opinion. Mrs Lagarde told the committee that she wanted to continue the European Central Bank's low interest rate policy. I firmly believe that this is the right thing to do. Interest rate hikes or tighter monetary policy would give the rest to the current state of the economy. Sliding into recession would be inevitable. But – and Mrs Lagarde has also stressed this – the central bank alone cannot sustain the economy and ensure monetary stability in the long run. An expansionary financial and budgetary policy is also urgently needed, and Germany in particular is responsible here. The insistence on the black zero is economically wrong. We need a significant increase in investment, not only to support the economy, but also to meet the challenge of climate change.

name: Engin EROGLU
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We have been living in the eurozone for several years in an interest rate phase that is lower than inflation. In the midst of the banking and economic crisis almost ten years ago, interest rate cuts of more than 2% were explicitly appropriate. However, we have now arrived in a low interest rate phase, a negative interest rate phase of 0.5%. However, some Member States are not taking advantage of this historic opportunity. They talk to each other nicely, but they don't take this opportunity. I would therefore like to draw the ECB's attention to the dangers that we have in this connection, namely that Member States are not able to control their budgets, and that interest-rate savers, like my generation and the generation of future children, can no longer build up sensible retirement provision in the event of this interest burden. The third possibility, which is in the room, is that we will once again get into economic crises. Examples of this are the past economic crises that we have had in the United States, Greece, Ireland and Spain, which have been accompanied by a negative interest rate policy. I would therefore like to make it very clear to the ECB, under new leadership, that please have courage, talk to the Member States and deviate from Mr Draghi's strict course!

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Madam President, Mrs Lagarde announced that, under her presidency, the European Central Bank would, I quote, be 'more transparent and accessible to citizens'. She said the ECB's role was to make itself understood by citizens, not just markets. These are fine speeches for a staunch supporter of total free trade. Beyond the speeches, Ms Lagarde did not think it was important to appear before the elected representatives of the European peoples. By disregarding the only democratic body of the European institutions, Mrs Lagarde's presidency is off to a bad start. It must be remembered that the woman who has been at the head of several major political and economic authorities has never gone through a popular or democratic vote in her own country, France. It should be remembered that Ms. Lagarde was the president of a major International American business law firm and, of course, the Managing Director of the IMF. Therefore, we can think that his gaze and interests are elsewhere, far beyond Europe. Rather than the interests of the people, it is the interest of a global elite, particularly that of the Anglo-Saxon business world, that Mrs Lagarde defends. Its stated desire to make climate change a priority issue for the ECB is a fundamental contradiction in relation to the European Union's global free trade policy.  Finally, more and more European peoples are seeing the ineptitude of the common currency and its damage to purchasing power. The euro area is the world's slowest growing economic zone, yet the European Central Bank is the only central bank in the world to make the fight against inflation its exclusive obsession. It must now tackle the resolution of unemployment, massive investment in job creation and the development of sectors of the future. We had essential democratic questions to ask Mrs Lagarde and we can only deplore her absence and contempt for the European peoples we represent.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, we are discussing the Financial Establishment of Europe here today. Last time we talked about the political establishment, but for what purpose if Mrs Christine Lagarde isn't here? We're talking about the most important position in the European Union, the head of the Central Bank. She's not here. However, I will ask her the same question I asked Mrs von der Leyen last time, whether the European Union, thus formed, will survive the next debt crisis, the next economic crisis. But she doesn't have to answer me. I already know the answer to that question in advance. We looked at her as head of the IMF, as part of a troika of how she worked in Greece. We looked at the austerity measures, we looked at the pension cuts, the fact that people can't get to the drugs, we looked at the destruction of an entire society. And now in this hellish round of the eurozone, which will break again as soon as another crisis comes, you want to squeeze my Croatia in as well. It's not going to work! What we talked about earlier, which is very much related to this theme of financial systems, is the economy, i.e. the transition to green policies. What directs economic policies? Well, the financial system. So in order to move on to green policies, we also need to reform the financial system. We're talking about a green transition, where there's a monetary transition, we need new people with new ideas, and Christine Lagarde is not a new man with new ideas, she's a establishment. It's business as usual and that Duchess of Austerity won't get my support.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. I represent the citizens of Hungary country that does not yet belong to the euro area. He's planning on entering, but learning from the past, only when he's well prepared. This is ongoing, as our economy is strengthening, and thanks to structural reforms, Hungary's economy is currently showing the greatest growth in the UNION, 5.2% being four times the EU average, and citizens can already benefit from this through rising wages.  I would like to ask the future President of the central bank, under his leadership, to pursue a monetary policy that is in the interest of the eurozone and non-euro area countries. We are all part of the single market, so do not let anything happen in the eurozone that makes life difficult for those outside. For example, the proposal for an autonomous eurozone budget is one of them. The new President should consider not to burden non-eurozone countries with resources. Finally, I would ask that new conditions not always be rolled in the way of countries wishing to adopt the euro, it would not be fair to constantly change the conditions.

name: Marek BELKA
text: – Madam President, the President of the European Central Bank is also a caretaker of the euro, as Mr Draghi made clear in 2012. The euro is, along with the common market, the most important asset that the European Union has ever created. The euro is not only an obligation and a constraint on national economic policy but also ‘an exorbitant privilege’, to paraphrase the term used in relation to the US dollar. It is the second global currency. Eurozone Member States do not need to worry about a liquidity shortage in time of crisis and they do not need to waste national resources to accumulate international currency reserves, to name just two of the benefits. The policymakers have to be reminded of this and it has to be preached to the general public. I’m sure that Christine Lagarde’s splendid communication skills can be fully utilised, including in relations with the non-euro countries like Poland. I wish her luck in her job and declare my full support for her.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The record of the ECB's policies under President Draghi is a terrible one: bankrupt governments and speculators have been provided with the cheapest money, and property prices are at record highs. All this has been paid for by the small saver, whose money saved is no longer worth anything, who no longer receives interest and even has to fear being punished with negative interest rates for his refusal to consume. And what comes now, after the dirty deal between "lame duck" Merkel and "Mister national debt" Macron: Give me the Commission, then I get the ECB, then you get the ECB. After this dirty deal, we can prepare for another eight years at the expense of European citizens. Who saves, loses; who manages sustainably is the stupid one. I take the fact that Mrs Lagarde did not rule out the abolition of cash and direct negative interest rates for savers in committee as a dangerous threat. If there is no more cash to hide, it is likely that there will still be the 10% expropriation of all assets, as Mrs Lagarde has already demanded during her time as IMF chief. I'm already horrified.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Madam President, we support Mrs Lagarde and expect her to support us, that is, the Greek economy. We welcome the statement he made in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the future reduction of Greek primary surpluses. This will help our economy work better. We also believe that it should help us to manage non-performing loans more quickly and efficiently. I think that Mr Enria, of the Single Supervisory Mechanism, is going in the same direction. We rely on them to help greek banks in trouble and the real economy. Therefore, Mrs Lagarde can do a lot for the Greek economy. The third thing we expect is for us to be in the quantitative easing programme, which, unfortunately, we lost under the responsibility of the previous government during the Draghi period. But, of course, in order to join the continuing quantitative easing programme, Greek bonds will have to acquire an investment grade. That is exactly what we will seek. The better the Greek economy goes, the better for the eurozone.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, Mrs Christine Lagarde obviously has the qualifications and personal and political experience to be President of the ECB, but the Socialists will vote in favour of her appointment for three fundamental reasons: first, because she advocates the continuity of Mario Draghi's monetary policy, and we need ahead of the ECB who is willing to overcome the resistance to do whatever it takes to save the euro , even if following an unconventional monetary policy; secondly, because it is already being a voice in favour of a budget policy of the Commission and the growth-friendly States; and third, because it presents itself as an ally of Parliament in the reform of economic and monetary union, the completion of the banking union and the strengthening of the democratic legitimacy of European economic governance. That is what Mrs Lagarde has promised this Parliament, and that is what we will demand that you do.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Madam President, mine is another voice in support of the nomination of Madame Lagarde to the governorship of the European Central Bank, even if I disapprove of her political orientation and part of her political record. I agree too that fiscal policy is needed to bolster growth at eurozone level, otherwise Madame Lagarde will face an impossible task. Monetary policy on its own cannot respond to the challenge of sustaining growth and creating worthwhile jobs.  However, I must highlight an issue that is forgotten when the European Central Bank makes decisions: the plight of medium to smaller banks in the euro zone, some operating in the smaller Member States. They are considered systemic banks, or almost systemic banks. Their areas of activity relate to niche national markets in which larger banks have scant interest. They service many SMEs in their home markets which would otherwise struggle to find working capital. These banks are being burdened with the full weight of centrally established regulations on a one-size-fits-all basis under SGP and banking union procedures. They are being rendered less and less profitable, and we shouldn’t view this as a minor problem.

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: – Madam President, firstly I would like warmly to welcome the appointment of Ms Lagarde to the European Central Bank. With her appointment we now have women as presidents of two of the most important institutions in Europe, the ECB and the Commission. This is huge progress for gender equality in Europe. Clearly, major challenges remain, not least in the economic and financial areas. Recently, at the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Ms Lagarde made a very important point: the ECB needs to understand and explain itself to people, not only to the markets. That should be a critical and crucial guiding principle for the ECB: listening to our citizens. Trust in the EU institutions has been below 50% since 2008, a clear sign that the Union was still suffering from the after-effects of the financial crisis. In Ireland, our population went through enormous pain during the crisis, and legacy issues remain. Irish variable mortgage rates are double the eurozone average rates, our banking system is highly concentrated, with little outside competition, and we face the challenges of Brexit. I would conclude by saying that I want to express my appreciation to Ms Lagarde for her help to Ireland during the very difficult years of the financial crisis.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: Mr President, I think that the different points of view in this debate show two things. First of all, the enormous challenge that Christine Lagarde faces. And if anyone's right for this job, it's her. Nineteen Member States in the euro area, 28 (by the way 27) in the European Union with different economies. In the end, it will have to come up with European solutions. The second thing that this debate shows, I think, is that we have rightly chosen an independent European Central Bank, which is not on the leash of politics.  Having said that, I must have one thing at heart: the side effects of the European Central Bank's policies affect people who have worked hard, who have built up their own pensions and who have saved for their old age and for their children. Christine Lagarde indicated in her hearing that she wanted to take into account these side effects of the policy. Mario Draghi then took measures that spared the banks, but not pension funds. So that would be my call in this debate, to also look at the side effects on pension funds. After all, let us be clear: there is a lot of talk these days about the European way of life, and then my question is: is the European way of life building up debt and burdening the next generation with a debt burden that they can never cope with, or is that also valuing the hard-working middle class who are saving for retirement themselves? I hope the latter.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I would like to thank everyone for cooperating with the electronic tests that we have run. I received seven, and I will take everyone who is on the list.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, for me the key question is: what policy will the new ECB President have? Seven years ago, the ECB contributed to the creation and halting of the financial, economic crisis, but then this was continued in full, unfortunately. €260 billion was spent on risky government bonds, and Mr Draghi now wants to step up that policy. Thank God he's leaving.   There is currently cheap enough money at an interest rate of virtually zero, but as a result, people who are in retirement are getting into trouble, saving has become meaningless and several southern Member States in the euro area are not implementing necessary reforms. President of the Dutch Central Bank Klaas Knot has rightly agitated against this with some colleagues: stop this policy. And I hope that Mrs Lagarde will change course.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: – Madam President, contrary to the position of some Members of this Parliament, we consider that it is of the utmost importance the fact that Ms Lagarde pledged to maintain the current monetary policy of the ECB, particularly the non-traditional instruments adopted in these last few years and also as recently as last week. That policy saved the euro and we can’t afford to go back into times of adventure, so we backed the nomination of Ms Lagarde, but I wonder if the hawks of monetarism are biting at several Groups in this European Parliament, namely, but not surprisingly, the PPE.  We do need an active monetary policy of the kind we’ve had from 2014. However, as the candidate for President of the ECB referred, it is also time for fiscal policy to do its part. Countries with strong macroeconomic surpluses have to do more on the eve of a possible stagnation of the European economy. But in the long term, more has to be done. We need to swiftly complete the banking union and need...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Helmut GEUKING
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In principle, responsible politicians should stop publicly talking badly about the euro, because the euro is better than it has been badly talked about here. In the face of this global world, it has no alternative. I say to Mrs Lagarde of the ECB that Draghi's policy in this direction should not continue. I believe that this must be clear to everyone. Unhindered consumption in our society creates new bubbles. These bubbles will have to be removed accordingly by future generations. Mrs Lagarde stands for continuing this policy. However, we should seize our opportunities here, with new impulses, i.e. a new management in the ECB, to start the departure from the current fiscal policy and accordingly to strengthen the savers again and not the debtors, and that we find a balance here in order to ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, the ECB, the IMF and the European Commission were the troika that intervened in Portugal, Greece and Ireland. Ms. Lagarde - who goes from the IMF to the ECB - was a strong supporter of the so-called "expansionist austerity" that inspired troika programmes, programmes whose results were devastating from an economic and social point of view.  Now, in the face of disaster, Mrs Lagarde apologized to multipliers, but did not change her convictions. Not long ago he joined the European Commission's threats to warn Portugal that it could not relax in its fiscal policy by advocating the maintenance or strengthening of budgetary constraints.  Now this is the candidate who, here in Parliament - the right, the Socialists and, surprise, or perhaps not, even the Greens - are preparing to support. There is one certainty that we have: in the next euro crisis, for Lagarde and for those who support it, exhausted that some of the instruments, wages and employment will be the adjustment factors. Now, banking and currency are too serious to be under Mrs. Lagarde's control only... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Honourable Chair, the euro is a strong currency used by as many as 330 million Europeans in 19 countries. This is a currency that covers 16.5% of global gross social income, 30% of world trade. In addition to a strong euro, we also need structural reforms across countries that will ensure a stable policy, both economically and socially, and give even greater stability to life within individual countries. We need strong banking systems in individual countries that will have no claims and ultimately bad banks, as we witnessed in times of crisis. The euro and the Central Bank have already proven themselves in solving the problems in Greece, Ireland, I believe they will face up to the challenges in the years to come, even in the event of a crisis.  Mrs Christine Lagarde is a professional, experienced person who enjoys great confidence, so she will also get my vote in the vote.

name: Erik BERGKVIST
text: Madam President, Members. Europe is facing major economic challenges and, at the same time, we can see that monetary policy has its limitations, and we must bear that in mind. We cannot say, as Mr Trump, that it is the Federal Reserve's fault or that it is the fault of monetary policy. We see today that we have both historically low interest rates in the ECB area and that the aid purchase programmes may not have had the effect we wanted all the time, but even led to increased inequality. You cannot cut the interest rate much more below zero and we also know that it has very little effect. John Maynard Keynes already noted this 80 years ago. What remains then is that we have to take both debates and discussions and think hard in Parliament about how we use fiscal policy. Today it is a little coordinated and sometimes not at all. It can even be counterproductive to monetary policy. If we are to succeed now that we see the economy slowing down and we may even be heading into recession, then we need to find ways of getting a fiscal policy that works with monetary policy in the euro area and throughout Europe. The challenges we face: climate, economy, social issues, migration, requires more cooperation, not less cooperation.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Madam President, I would like to express the regret of the Eurogroup on the left because Mrs Lagarde today decided to be absent and to snobbst the European Parliament. Maybe she's used to the way she acted as head of the International Monetary Fund. But here the European Central Bank must strengthen democratic accountability. We cannot vote for Mrs Lagarde. As the Eurogroup of the Left we will not vote for it because we are opposed to the prescriptions it applied as head of the International Monetary Fund, in countries such as Greece, which have caused an incredible recession, three times unemployment and enormous social pain. We are not convinced that it will implement positive policies. It is true, however, that, in addition to the policies of the European Central Bank, it is also time for the Member States to implement an expansionary fiscal policy in favour of growth.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I will support the appointment of Mrs Lagarde to the European Central Bank, because she is indeed an expert with an international resonate. It is important to me that he advocates the completion of banking and monetary union and also that he wants to explain very complex monetary policy to the people. I think people should understand the fundamental pillars of our monetary policy. The Czech Republic does not yet have a single euro currency, but I see the euro as a valuable and stable currency.  The thesis has been made that fiscal policy should always promote growth. I would like to oppose it with the thesis on the stability of the system, even though the ECB has been using some unconventional instruments recently, for example, the stability of the system is important to me and is linked to Mrs Lagarde's name. So I will definitely support it, and I am very glad that this debate is in her favour today.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course, the European Central Bank is important for the economic development and stability of the currency. Mrs Christine Lagarde has the necessary training and has presented to the committee the powers she holds for the post. I have criticised and many of us have criticised the European Central Bank many times rightly because of the policies it has had. I believe that Mrs Christine Lagarde, if she gets the vote of Parliament, faces new challenges.  I come from a country that is not in the euro area, but nevertheless is recording the second increase in the European Union, and I believe that the management that must be done now at the Central Bank, also taking into account the forecasts of some experts, that a new financial crisis may come, is not to divide the European Union into two: the euro area and the non-euro area. He needs to think about how he can support, especially small ones, small and medium-sized enterprises, and how he can make policies that do not lead to that negative interest that he ... (The President withdrew the speaker's word)... assumed it.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, as this House knows the Commission is not involved in the appointment process of the President of the European Central Bank (ECB). We do, however, have a keen interest in this process and in listening carefully to your views on macroeconomic policymaking in the euro area and in the EU.  We’re happy that the Council named a person with all the relevant credentials to be a successful ECB President. We also welcome the fact that for the first time this person is a woman.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Commissioner, a moment please, because this is very disrespectful. Colleagues who have just entered the Chamber, would you mind listening, or at least sitting down in your seats quietly, without conversation. And perhaps, Commissioner, you could bring your microphone a little closer and we will try and resume your speech.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the new ECB President has a challenging task ahead, both in the immediate future and in the longer term. In the immediate future, in the event that ECB intervention is needed to avert a slowdown in economic activity, we share the view expressed by Christine Lagarde during her hearing that there is a need to reconsider whether the past overburdening of monetary policy can be improved upon by better support of structural reforms and fiscal policy. We also share the conviction that ...

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Commissioner, I am sorry. Colleagues, I do not want to name and shame because I don’t know all of your names, but I would ask you please … Colleagues to my right, I’m really sorry, I am trying to keep order. I’m not going to do ‘Order, order!’ because I’m not in the House of Commons – although I would love to have that same voice and influence. Perhaps you would just please sit down quietly in your seats. Commissioner Dombrovskis is responding to our debate. I won’t resume the debate unless there is quiet. This is just not good enough.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, we also share the conviction that the deepening of economic and monetary union will be beneficial for the functioning of the euro area, making it more resilient and it will also foster the international standing of the euro.  After an exchange of views with the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs earlier this month on the candidacy of Christine Lagarde, it is clear that Parliament also shares this assessment.  I hope that this alignment of views will pave the way to continuing the excellent cooperation among the three institutions, in full respect of their respective roles, under the ECB Presidency of Christine Lagarde.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Vice-President, for your forbearance. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Nicola BEER
text: Writing. Today, as members of the Free Democrats in the European Parliament, together with our Renew Europe Group, we voted in favour of the nomination of Christine Lagarde. Mrs Lagarde brings international experience at the highest level and is undoubtedly qualified for the post of ECB President. We will argue with her about the direction of monetary policy and have clear expectations of her conduct. It is necessary to announce, as short-term as possible, a gradual end to monetary policy that has been too generous for too long. What may have been necessary and right in a crisis must finally be repatriated in order to avoid damage and keep the ECB capable of acting. Ever more and cheaper money has put governments in the Member States in a waking coma and expropriated savers, instead of driving the economy forward, safeguarding and creating jobs. There is now a lack of structural change to stimulate public and private investment in the future. In the face of a looming slowdown in Europe, Member States need to create a better environment for growth, innovation and investment; the FLOODING of the money market by the ECB runs counter to this. That is why, as Free Democrats in the European Parliament, we will be critical of Mrs Lagarde's plans and their implementation and will look at whether it contributes to the renewal of Europe and to ensuring prosperity on the continent.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – According to the latest Eurobarometer survey, 62% of Citizens of the European Union have a positive view of the functioning of the European Economic and Monetary Union and the introduction of the euro. Most countries outside the euro area aim to become a member of the euro area as soon as possible, meeting the conditions for introduction. Taking into account the current situation in the world economy, where economic growth is constantly declined, thereby increasing the risk of another economic crisis, it is even more urgent to join the single currency. However, there are Member States where the introduction of the euro is seen not as a fulfilment of the obligation arising from the EU Treaties, but as a political issue. While Romania, Croatia and Bulgaria have explicit target dates for the introduction of the euro and are doing their utmost to join the euro area, there are Member States, including Hungary, who, although also committed to joining the single currency, do not yet have a target date for implementation. It is in the common interest of the European Union and EU citizens not to stay out of the eurozone for political reasons.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. Mrs Lagarde: in assessing her appointment as President of the ECB, we cannot fail to recall her role in the International Monetary Fund over the last eight years. You have imposed and endorsed economic policies which have aggravated the situation of countries in difficulty. We still have in mind the Crisis in Greece and the IMF's indications that they have increased unemployment and poverty by cutting public spending, from health to pensions. But the opposition to his appointment also stems from the few answers he gave us at the hearing. The failure of monetary policies in recent years with regard to the ECB's statutory objective is clear to all. The long-awaited inflation target below but close to 2% is getting further and further away, signalling a sharp slowdown in the euro area economy. Despite the accommodative monetary policy of recent years – rate cuts, LTRO, TLTRO, quantitative easing – the malfunctioning of transmission channels from monetary policy to the real economy is evident. The result is that it has flooded the banking system with liquidity, saving the Euro and the banks, but leaving businesses and citizens on their knees. You have not provided any evidence to suggest a change of course. That is why my vote and that of my group are against.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Othmar KARAS
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on foreign interference in the democratic processes of the Member States and Europe and corresponding disinformation (2019/2810(RSP)).

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, almost four months have passed since the European Parliament elections, which were combined in several Member States with other elections. No major interference campaign was identified, but fact—checkers and academia have nonetheless flagged malicious activity from foreign sources to influence turnout and voter preferences. We have to be constantly prepared. We should make sustained efforts to raise awareness, increase preparedness and strengthen the resilience of our democracies to hybrid threats, including disinformation. This is a priority for our presidency. Long-term efforts are needed to enhance the resilience of our democratic societies since disinformation and hybrid threats in general are a permanent part of our security environment. The evolving nature of the threats and the growing risk of malicious interference and online manipulation associated with the development of artificial intelligence and data-gathering techniques require continuous assessment and an appropriate response. The Council welcomes the Commission’s intention to conduct an in-depth evaluation of the implementation of commitments made by online platforms and other signatories under the code of practice. The Council is monitoring the implementation in its working parties and will be ready to examine action that could be proposed by the Commission by the end of the year. Before the end of the year, we expect the Commission report on the 2019 European Parliament elections, which should pay particular attention to preparedness and resilience, geared to withstanding interference in elections. More broadly, it will be interesting to hear the thoughts of the Commission on possible further initiatives it might take. We attach great importance to this subject, as has been repeatedly underlined by the European Council, including in the new Strategic Agenda. The EU institutions and the Member States have an important role to play, in terms of their respective remits, in the protection of democratic processes. This requires concerted efforts by the EU and the Member States and also by civil society and the private sector. Our response has to be comprehensive, with the focus on both the internal and external dimensions of the threat. Since the conclusions the Council adopted in March on securing free and fair European elections, which welcomed the Commission electoral package and the Joint Action Plan Against Disinformation, much has been done both by the EU institutions and in individual Member States: the organisation of regular meetings of the European Election Cooperation Network, in which Member States share expertise and good practice and jointly identify threats; the setting up of the Rapid Alert System whereby national contact points in Member States rapidly share information on disinformation campaigns; the enhancement of strategic communication on European values and policies; the strengthening of the European media ecosystem by facilitating networks of independent fact-checkers; the promotion of media and digital literacy and awareness-raising activities to protect the integrity of the electoral process, together with the private sector and civil society; the assessment of cyber-threats in the electoral context and of the measures to address them and preserve the integrity of the electoral system; the monitoring, as already mentioned, of the implementation by social media platforms of the code of practice; and, finally, cooperation with the relevant international actors. So much has been done. To contribute to these efforts, the Romanian Presidency prepared a report to the last European Council on countering disinformation and on the lessons learned from the European elections. Continuing that work, one of the top priorities of our presidency is to enhance the resilience of our democratic societies against foreign interference, through coordinated and coherent action across all relevant policy fields in order to strengthen the comprehensive security of our citizens. I want to underline that all this work to protect our open, democratic societies must be carried out while fully respecting the fundamental rights of our citizens, including freedom of expression. In this context, our presidency places particular emphasis on strengthening the EU’s capabilities in countering hybrid threats and building resilience in the EU and Member States. Already in July, a permanent Council working party with a horizontal mandate was established and held its first meeting. It is also essential to continue developing partnerships, especially our cooperation with NATO. The Helsinki-based European Centre of Excellence for countering hybrid threats also contributes to fostering cooperation in this field. Disinformation strategies by foreign state and non-state actors are also deployed beyond our EU borders. Alongside tackling the problem within the Union, the Action Plan Against Disinformation outlines our significant interest in working with partners in the EU’s eastern and southern neighbourhood and in the Western Balkans. Exposing disinformation and strengthening media, information and digital-literacy skills in our neighbourhood are key elements in this regard. We need to act together in a structured and coordinated way in order to tackle these challenges. Protecting elections is at the core of defending our European values.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, respect for democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law are the three common values which bind the Union together. We should not take them for granted. President—elect von der Leyen has announced that protecting European democracy will be a priority for her Commission. She underlined that our democratic systems have come increasingly under attack from those who wish to divide and destabilise the Union. Therefore, we need to do more to protect ourselves from external influences. The spread of disinformation and the influence of dark money affect policymaking processes by skewing public opinion and distorting the debate. Domestic and foreign actors can exploit this to manipulate policy, societal debates and behaviour in areas such as climate change, migration, public security, health and finance. Manipulation can also diminish trust in science and empirical evidence. The conduct of free and fair elections is primarily the responsibility of Member States. Nevertheless, a European approach is necessary, given the cross-border dimension of efforts to manipulate democracy and the importance of joining efforts to address the threats. What affects one Member State can affect all. Through the electoral package in September 2018, the Commission took determined action to support Member States’ efforts to protect the integrity of elections and combat disinformation. Implementing the package, the Commission encouraged national electoral networks to identify best practices for the management of risks to the electoral process. Cooperation between Member States was fostered by the newly established European cooperation network on elections, which allowed exchange of best practices and creation of operational links between Member States. The network met four times in the run—up to the elections and had a first stocktaking meeting immediately after the elections.  It brought together representatives from the national networks, who had fruitful exchanges among themselves and with representatives of other institutions, including Parliament and civil society. Its activities cover all aspects of this complex area, from exchanges on awareness—raising for citizens and cooperation with platforms, to the mapping of legal instruments applicable to foreign funding. It also included a table—top exercise at European level to help Member States assess and potentially strengthen their resilience to cyber—attacks. Member States engaged actively in the European cooperation network and expressed their desire for both the national and the European networks to continue their work beyond the European elections in order to support Member States’ efforts to increase the resilience of their electoral systems. Our preliminary assessment on the implementation of these efforts in the context of the recent European elections is quite encouraging. The coordinated EU approach helped to ensure stronger preparedness and coordination in the fight against manipulation and disinformation. As was done for previous elections, we are currently conducting a thorough examination of the conduct of the elections to the European Parliament. We are also cooperating with international partners through a range of forums, including NATO and the G7, as well as with individual states. This reflects a comprehensive and coordinated approach among democracies to tackle disinformation and foster resilient electoral processes. International cooperation ensures that the tools and unique capabilities of all actors act in unison, in full respect of fundamental rights, in particular the freedom of expression and of association.  As announced by President—elect von der Leyen, the Commission – if confirmed by Parliament – will aim to put forward a European democracy action plan addressing the threats of external intervention in our European elections. If confirmed in the vice—president role by this House, I will coordinate the work on this plan. Building up the resilience of our democratic systems and countering of disinformation and fake information are necessities of our current situation. Not less important, the freedoms of expression and of the press in the landscape of media pluralism will also be pursued and protected by the next Commission. In all these efforts – again, if confirmed in my future role by this House – I will work closely with Parliament, with the Member States, with citizens and with stakeholders on protecting and nurturing democracy in Europe.

name: Julian King
