text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I’m going to focus on the challenge of disinformation. As we’ve already heard, fortunately during the recent European parliamentary elections, there was no large-scale, coordinated disinformation attack. But that does not mean, unfortunately, that those elections were a disinformation free zone. They were not. There are myriad reports from across Europe of different sorts of disinformation. For example, to take an example from another Member State, let’s take an example from Germany. There are well-researched reports that show that online promotion for one of the German parties represented up to 86% of all party activity on Facebook. Four times the comments, six times the shares of all other political parties combined. Many of these likes and shares came from a cluster of 80 000 suspicious accounts, with random two-letter first and last names, that each mutually liked hundreds and thousands of pieces of content. Large-scale automated propaganda and disinformation is unfortunately a fact. It’s a fact of our modern political life, and if the platforms can’t figure out that thousands of coordinated accounts with random two-letter names are suspicious, then we have a problem.  I don’t know about you but I don’t think we can accept this as the new normal. We need to do more to work together to close down the space in which hostile and bad actors are trying to do this disinformation and to build our resilience to make it harder to do and to allow us to resist its impact. Which is why we, together with the Member States and a number of other partners, have been working on at least four areas.  First, as has been mentioned, we’ve established a rapid alert system bringing the EU institutions and the Member States together to work to spot and tackle coordinated disinformation campaigns. We’re working to reinforce this mechanism. We’re doing a series of consultations at the moment to enhance how we do information exchange between the Member States, the institutions and with the platforms, as well as civil society researchers, and to build a strengthened hub for research and analytics of disinformation. Second, over the past two years in fact, we have mobilised a community of fact checkers, researchers and civil society, to help detect and analyse disinformation campaigns and to discuss how we design our responses. To boost the impact of this work, of this community, we will soon deploy a new European online platform to bring together 38 fact-checking organisations from across 17 Member States, working on this platform funded through the Connecting Europe Facility programme. But if they’re going to do this work effectively, we also need the platforms to play their part. We need them to provide secure access to data for these trusted fact checkers and researchers to enable them to do their research, to enable us together to unlock better responses. All the time, of course, making sure that we respect the necessary ethical and professional standards, which brings me to the third point we’ve been working on. We’ve pushed the big Internet platforms to sign up to a code of practice on disinformation, as has already been set out. We finalised that work in September last year. The initial signatories – Facebook, Google, Twitter, Mozilla, trade associations from the advertising sector – have, I’m glad to say, now been joined also by Microsoft.  So this is a serious group of people. They took together a list of commitments – 15 different commitments – and we are monitoring the performance against those commitments. By the middle of September – anytime now – we are going to see the signatories deliver their own self assessment to us. Then we are going to work with a number of third-party consultants to deliver an independent third-party review of performance against those commitments by the middle of October.  Building on those reports, we’d expect to communicate our overview of where we are on implementation of the code before the end of October. Then the final step, our full assessment, will come in the form of a Commission communication which is planned to be published at the beginning of next year after further consultations with independent experts as well as Member States in the European Regulators Group for Audiovisual Media Services. As Commissioner Jourová, as I and as Commissioner Gabriel have said on a number of occasions, should the results prove unsatisfactory we think that we need to look – or be ready to look – at further actions, including, if necessary, the possibility of regulation.  Indeed there have already been a number of proposals, legislative and otherwise, put forward in various Member States. For example the UK Government has set out its intentions in the Online Harms White Paper, while in France there’s a push for a framework to make platforms more accountable.  We encourage the Member States in these efforts and stand ready to assist where we can.  Fourth and finally, we have worked to empower citizens, including by promoting, as we’ve heard, media literacy and increasing awareness across society on the positive impact of EU policies, Union values, to strengthen our citizens’ resilience against the negative effects of disinformation. Overall I think I’d have to say that we’ve done some good work. We’ve come some way, but frankly there remains a lot still to be done, which is why, like Věra Jourová, I’m very pleased to see that the incoming Commission, the incoming President-elect, have underlined the importance of this work. In addition to the point that’s already been mentioned, if confirmed it’s in the programme, the President-elect has said that she wants to bring forward legislation for a coordinated European approach on the human and ethical implications of AI, which would be very relevant to this debate, and she’s proposed a new digital services act to upgrade liability and safety rules for digital platforms, services and products – again, very relevant to this debate.  And these efforts, combined with the others that we have been discussing, are going to be absolutely key if we are to ensure a prosperous, safe and democratic digital future for all our citizens. (Applause)

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, this debate is about fundamental European values. It’s about the rule of law, freedom and our democratic elections. I think it’s very important that this Parliament, after this debate, comes together with a very strong resolution. It’s very important that in Europe we stand up for free and democratic elections without interference from foreign states. Unfortunately, that is not the situation in Europe today and I think it’s important that the European Parliament is not afraid to talk very clearly about this. It is very well known that Russia in particular is conducting a low intense information war against Europe. Their state—sponsored media and their troll factories try to undermine democratic debates in Europe. But we also see other totalitarian states, such as China, Iran and North Korea, trying to weaken our democratic decision—making. I think it is important that we try to defend our values and make sure that, if you are aggressive towards our democratic institutions, there must also be consequences.  In this plenary we disagree a lot. It’s called democracy. It is OK to disagree, but I think it’s very important that we agree that if we leave democratic decision—making open to foreign interference, we will also lose our self—determination. So I think it’s important that we come together in a common resolution in the coming weeks and stand up for European values.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, in a democracy, fair and free elections are crucial and yet, unfortunately, they are not self—evident and cannot be taken for granted. In recent years, millions of Europeans have been exposed to massive disinformation campaigns during election time as a result of foreign interference. Cyber—attacks have risen to an unprecedented level, with dangerous access to strategic infrastructure and data. Crucial electoral rules on the financing of political parties by third countries have been either breached or circumvented. In July, Italian media revealed a plan by Russians to fund Matteo Salvini’s League. That is only the latest incident and, as we know, this goes well beyond just Russia or just Italy. This House was vocal on the issue of interference during the last parliamentary term and so was the European External Action Service and the Commission. I am happy to hear that the Finnish Presidency is also taking it up as one of its priorities. I’m proud that the S&D Group managed to gain widespread political support for this important topic to be on the agenda this week. I’m also pleased to hear that there is widespread support for seeking a strong resolution: we need serious answers on how to prevent third parties from undermining our democratic systems. To address this challenge effectively, my Group proposes to establish a special parliamentary committee so that European democracy, in which elections are always free and fair, is and remains self—evident and once again can be taken for granted.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam Minister, you started your speech by explaining and rejoicing that the European elections had gone well and that there had been no attack at that time - and I am indeed pleased that the European elections went well. However, elections in general, and European elections in particular, are not all democracy. And what Mr King and Mrs Jourova have explained very well is that our democracy, as we see it in Europe, is in danger. It is in danger, indeed, because of the misinformation phenomena that you have noted and which you have been right to point out, Commissioner. But it is also in danger through the funding of political parties - this has just been mentioned and it is very important to say this - that is to say the foundation of democracy in Europe. We know that foreign powers that do not want good in the European Union - we talked about Russia, it is not only Russia, but Russia, it is clear, it is established, it is defined - have financed, to the tune of one billion euros, information elements, funding of our political parties, mainly those who want to destroy the European Union and who end up in the extreme right of this Chamber. , in Italy, France and elsewhere. So we do have to fight the financing of political parties and the resolution is very important. We must give ourselves the means and the means to StratCom, which has three million euros a year. Three million euros... five million - this has been increased, you are right, Commissioner, to raise it - but in the face of a billion. Let us be serious, let us give ourselves the means to be able to act on the elements of misinformation. Let us give ourselves the means to ban foreign funding of our European democracy and our political parties, and give ourselves the means of technological independence.  Because if we have to systematically turn to the outside European Union in order to be able to control, we are facing a major difficulty: that of independence and our ability to act.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I would like to express my thanks to the Finnish Presidency for taking this issue so seriously. I would also like to thank the Commission for your intensive attention to this issue. The Europe that protects must, first and foremost, protect its own values, and that also means its democracy, and European sovereignty. That is what this debate is about. We do not just have to be careful and careful in one direction. There are not only proven attempts at interference from Russia, but also by Mr Erdogan from Turkey. China's totalitarian leadership would like to take advantage of economic dependencies, and reactionary circles from the United States have already tried to interfere in European democracy to our detriment. I believe it is part of a major dispute between a developing authoritarian international and the international commitment to democracy. In order not to lose this, however, we must not only look at what others want to interfere with us, but we must ourselves ensure that there are no dividing lines in Europe that can be exploited by others – this is also part of this defence of our democracy and sovereignty.

name: Marco CAMPOMENOSI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today's speech is quite surreal. Some of the references made at the beginning on the importance of cybersecurity are favourable to us: it is a very important issue, think of NATO, Israel, what role they can play in this regard. However, here is someone who perhaps pretends to be able to continue to play the game that has entrenched you behind your nine majority votes for Mrs von der Leyen, because the one who talks about fake news is you, or rather who spreads them is exactly you. Often many of these cases that have been mentioned have been denied by the same media that had pulled them out, not to mention what happened in Italy, that is, absolutely nothing has happened and we will soon be sure of this too, there are courts that will clarify. But what is behind your need? There is an excuse for perhaps being able to clog up the Internet, to curb the freedom of the Internet – we saw this with the absurd debate on the copyright directive, at the end of the last parliamentary term. Because? Because you no longer understand the citizens, you no longer understand the voters. So there's a Brexit vote and it surprises you, there's a vote on the US presidential election and it surprises you, there's a vote for the European Parliament that sees our forces double and you don't understand why. Because? Because you're locked in here and you have no relation to the reality of the facts.  Moreover, these are your documents, this is the Bureau of this Parliament: in 2018 you allocated EUR 33.3 million for – you do! – influence the European elections. Say that we must not only take the voters to the polls but also convince them to support the European project, which gives meaning to the European Parliament itself. From what pulpit can you talk about external interference!

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I fully agree with the thrust of this resolution. However, I do not share this obsessive, I would say compulsive, search by the European Parliament for an enemy. That's something I don't understand.  Let me explain: I believe that it is necessary to defend our democratic, social and economic security with better infrastructure and better legislative instruments – I am also thinking of the 5G revolution, which is coming and which clearly needs to be governed very carefully, selecting the economic partners well. I said, however, that, if I understand the merit of this resolution, I find it difficult to understand the method, because I think it is much more important to focus our attention on strengthening the European agencies that are competent in this matter than to digress in the compulsive search for enemies against which to lash out politically.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Liberals – the centre right and left – struggle to believe that they are losing segments of elections to the far right and, much like the Democrats in the US, are more interested in endlessly talking about Russian interference than addressing their own failings. The real electoral interference in the US was the Democratic Party stealing the election from Bernie Sanders and putting forward a figure that made Trump sound OK. The real source of the swing to the right in Europe is not outside interference. It’s a decade of crushing austerity, the neo—liberalisation of the labour sector, the rise of inequality and the theft of the economic resources of the global south through financial imperialism, coupled with our imperialist military campaigns that create the conditions that drive people out of their homes looking for a liveable existence.  America has been meddling and interfering in other countries’ elections and democratic processes for over a hundred years and has done so in a ruthless and brutal manner that makes the alleged Russian interference in the 2016 elections in America look like child’s play.

name: Miroslav RADAČOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, after listening to each other and studying the reports on disinformation and hybrid wars, I got the impression that we should all wear uniforms, get on planes, attack Moscow.  I do not think it is right that, both in this report and in other reports, Russia should be regarded as the primary enemy of the European Union. Dividing Europe into East and West is unacceptable, it is a road to hell. Europeans are not devils, Europeans are homo sapiens. Already the great people of Europe – Charles de Gaulle, Michail Gorbachev, John Paul II – talked about Europe from the Urals to la Manchu. Dividing Europe with sanctions, missiles is unacceptable. It is unacceptable and let us remember history. Millions of silenced Jews in concentration camps, millions of artichaught Slavs, that was the reason for Europe's division into East and West. The European House is one and the common. Such reports are unacceptable because they are for militants, militantly tuned people, and you know what this has led to in history.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Trying to influence decisions and elections in the European Union is no longer a phenomenon that we could attribute purely to science fiction novels. After electoral manipulation in the USA and also in France, this phenomenon has now also arrived in Austria. Only a few weeks ago, a hacking attack took place on the headquarters of the Austrian People's Party. An unimaginable amount of data of 1.3 gigabytes was stolen and at least partially passed on – just a few weeks before the elections to the National Council. Essential, of course, is a complete and rapid investigation. Indeed, political opponents have questioned the authenticity of this attack. For the highly specialized police investigators, however, it is now clear that this is a large-scale and professional hacking attack. First tracks lead to foreign servers. It is clear to me that partisan calculus must be put aside when it comes to such a serious intervention. This is not just an attack on the Austrian People's Party, but on democracy as a whole. Disinformation prevents free formation of wills and thus jeopardises a democratic election decision. That is why I consider today's debate and the resolution that will soon be too decisive and to be adopted to be so essential, because it is now necessary to find European solutions here to protect our elections from such criminal activities. It is about nothing less than our fundamental values, about our way of life in Europe. We must defend this with all our vehemence and by all means.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, judicial investigations and journalistic investigations into the existence of foreign influences, particularly in Russia, are increasing, but not only, behind campaigns aimed at polluting the electoral debate and democratic processes in Europe. Think of the case of the Front National in 2014, the Austrian FPO and, lastly, the investigation into Russian funding for the League's election campaign in Italy, about which Matteo Salvini has not yet reported in Parliament, after repeatedly lying about his relations with the fixer Gianluca Savoini and without having provided all the information even to the government of which he was a member , as the Prime Minister Conte has reported. We will be fully clear about attempts to destabilise Europe. Today, some European politicians act as national executors of these manoeuvres, they speak as representatives of the people, but they are passes of foreign powers, puppets. We will no longer allow these enemies of our sovereignty, Marine Le Pen or Matteo Salvini, to lie to the citizens and to work against the interests of Europeans. The measure is full! This Parliament must give a mandate to a special committee to investigate attempts to influence democratic processes in Europe in order to defend the citizens' right to a public and electoral debate free from interference, because those who are accomplices will now have to be accountable to this House and to all Europeans, at last!

name: Dragoş TUDORACHE
text: – Mr President, I would first like to thank Commissioner Jourová and Commissioner King for their earlier interventions, and in general, I would like to welcome the European Commission's efforts to counter external interference in the European elections on 26 May. Our democracies depend on the credibility of electoral processes and that is why we must prepare ourselves with effective measures to manage the obvious risks we have.  I fully support the intervention of my colleague Durand before, which called for increased funding for the structures we have created to counter the external forces that are investing systematically and proactively to undermine our political cohesion at national and European level. Commissioner King warned us in LIBE last week that the number of pro-Kremlin disinformation activities has doubled this year compared to the same period last year.  Moreover, the net number of fake social media accounts is steadily increasing, reaching 20 million on Facebook this year alone. I welcome the Commission's initiative to bring IT giants to the same table. I look forward to the evaluation at the end of this year and look forward to legislative proposals.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, we live in stable, resilient, liberal democracies. Ten years ago, I would probably have signed a statement like this for all members of the European Union and I would have believed that this is something that, in the course of my lifetime, was not going to change.  Today, I would honestly be more cautious about this statement. Yes, we still live in stable, resilient democracies, but honestly these democracies are under attack. Disinformation is being spread, scapegoating, for example, minorities and marginalised groups. There are smear campaigns against, for example, sexual and reproductive rights or the Istanbul Convention, partly funded through very blurry channels with money from abroad, not only Russia, but also, for example, the United States. These tactics are already showing their consequences. They are destabilising our democratic decision-making processes. We have to stand up for our rights and our democracies through empowering civil society, but also through taking steps to defend our discussion space without at the same time undermining the very basis of our democracies, which is freedom of speech.  (Applause)

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Mr President, the EU should strengthen its freedom of expression if we are really on the side of democracy. It is clear that not only Russia, but also the United States and China want to influence european elections in their own way. A few years ago, Obama went to blackmail the British with trade agreements so as not to vote wrong. The blackmail didn't work. It is an underestimation of voters to claim that Brexit, the election of Trump and the victory of numerous nationalist parties are due to conspiracy theories, hatred, Russia and social media taxes. The victory is because the people genuinely want to put an end to harmful immigration, stop Islamisation, they want to defend the sovereignty of nation states, their borders, culture and Christian values. They want to put their own people first. Regardless of whether these things are good or bad for the mainstream parties, that is why we nationalist parties are being voted on. And the real reason and the need for this debate here today is for the Liberals to lose elections, and you refuse to accept nationalist parties being voted on for the right things. That is why you in the EU want to go down the road of censorship. You want a politically correct truth commission that pre-censors. This will tell the people what they should think and what they want. Democracy is not in crisis and democracy will not die if the Liberals lose elections.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, with due respect to all measures taken within the portfolios of Commissioner Jourová and Commissioner King, I would like to stress that we discuss the external aspect of EU relations, namely foreign interference into our democratic processes.  Yes, we have to strengthen resilience and further build democracies, but we have to know the policies of external actors. During the eighth legislature we presented reports on this, naming predominantly the Russian Federation, but also actors like China, Iran and North Korea. Their actions, a low intensive information war, are many times tailored-made – cut and made – vis-à-vis each Member State. So building our cooperation is very important. Yet in order to act successfully, we have to know narrative policies, I would like to praise East StratCom, located within the European External Action Service (EEAS).

name: Alexandra Lesley PHILLIPS
text: – Mr President, online payment systems, social media and informal campaigns do indeed open doors to people who want to abuse democracy across the political spectrum, but something else is also afoot: an appetite to spread conspiracy for political ends and a desire to delegitimise election results because the loser doesn’t consent. I have seen both Leave campaigns for Brexit face numerous court cases and accusations long since debunked. A young campaigner in the UK was threatened with prison for two years before charges were dropped. My own party, at the whim of an embittered ex-Prime Minister claiming we received foreign money, had our offices raided, only for that investigation to be terminated because no evidence was found. The list goes on. It’s patently clear to me that the biggest threat to democracy is opportunism and the gender-driven conspiracy by politicians themselves to discredit campaigns that they don’t favour. It’s irresponsible, it’s feckless and it creates mistrust between the voter and the result, laying fertile ground for extremism. Like the boy who cried wolf before calling foul, check your facts or you become the problem, not the solution. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Julie WARD
text: blue-card question. – Would Ms Phillips please comment on the secret campaign work she did for the disgraced data-mining and campaigns consultancy Cambridge Analytica during the Kenyan presidential election in 2017, for which I was an election observer for this Parliament, and also comment on the subsequent lies she told about her involvement in that?  Cambridge Analytica was hired by President Kenyatta’s governing Jubilee Party prior to the campaign which reignited tribal divisions in the country, resulting in dozens of politically motivated killings and the mysterious torture and murder of Chris Msando, the head of IEBC, the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Alexandra Lesley PHILLIPS
text: blue-card answer. – My colleague is embodying exactly what I have just said. I worked for a British consultancy as a freelance contractor, which she well knows later folded into the American company Cambridge Analytica. It is funny; she could contact me in person to ask about this rather than taking her information from conspiracy theories on Twitter and FBPE hashtag people who want to stir up misinformation. I am proud of the work I did for a progressive African president. That work is on record with the European Parliament. And, can I just say, if that is not for political ends, why didn’t she knock on my office door?

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Mr President, democracy implies and promotes freedom, tolerance and pluralism of opinions. However, when we try to replace democracy with other authoritarian forms of government or change the geopolitical orientation of a sovereign state, the tolerance limit appears to have crossed.  Paradoxically, unlimited tolerance sooner or later leads to the disappearance of tolerance. I here I would ask the paradoxical perhaps question: if we vote in this Parliament whether democracy means freedom to lie or is lying not part of freedom of opinion, what would be the result?  We must not be naïve and must be clearly aware of the seriousness of threats from third parties. Bulgaria is only one of the countries that was attacked in 2015 during the last local elections, the sites of the Central Electoral Commission and other key institutions in relation to the elections were attacked.  But this is far from exhausting only the destabilising attempts of third countries in our societies to wedge into the unity of the European Union. In my country, hundreds of anonymous sites without clear ownership, organizations without clear funding, thousands of fake social media accounts are waging a coordinated information war against the European Union, abusing people's most sensitive topics, such as religion, traditions and values. Democracy must have the tools to defend itself. I welcome and call for serious resources to protect and address this type of hybrid threat. The Speaker agrees to answer a question on the Blue Card procedure (Article 171(8) of the Regaent)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, come from Bulgaria, I come from Romania. Of course I totally understand what you said. The theme is very important. My question is: as an old MEP, do you see solutions in solving the problem at issue? On the other hand, freedom of expression, the elimination of interference in the electoral act. What would be your concrete proposals to be able to adopt them, because if we debate and we do not find solutions it means that we will find ourselves in the same situation next year.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, this is a general question about what we are going do together. Only with coordinated actions, together with the Commission, the Council and the Member States, can we achieve some limitation of this disinformation campaign from third countries, but also from inside the European Union. The right step forward is to ask the platforms to follow codes of conduct, to support good objective journalism, for journalists to have professional training on this, and many things, but we also need resources. Democracy needs to have an immune system.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Mr President, today we call for tougher action at European level to defend our elections against foreign interference and manipulation and to win the fight against offline and online disinformation. We are doing so because the facts indicate that it is actually happening. And I should indicate to everyone in the House, including new Members, that we have been doing this for some months now. The Commissioner indicated that action is already being taken, the Presidency is joining us, and what we in our group want to happen today is a call for a special committee to deepen this action. We are doing this because our Member States are not resilient enough. We have two big problems, which in the next few seconds I will explain. Our citizens are voting in elections where we have far—right parties – I see it in my own country – who are being funded and receiving loans from foreign state actors. Secondly, we have deep electoral interference. Offline electoral safeguards are needed, and the banning of profiling for electoral purposes, social media platforms shared by bots need to be removed and fake accounts need to be removed. These practical actions need to happen and need to happen now.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: – Mr President, indeed, the interference of foreign actors in democratic elections today is nothing new, it is not a new threat;  This does not mean that we can accept this, and I am pleased that both the Finnish Presidency and the Commission are going to continue to work with this. Because it really is something that threatens the very essence of democracy, because without meaningful debate, a debate based on facts, there is no democracy. At the same time, however, it has to be said that this real risk is not only a few conspiracy websites or Russian money, but also politicians who work purposefully with disinformation, use these tactics and this emotion, or in my region, in Central Europe there are even some prime ministers who publicly repeat conspiracies, work with them and attack political rivals, or minorities, or the European Union, and that is even more toxic to democracy.

name: Scott AINSLIE
text: – Mr President, freedom, fairness and transparency: these are the foundations on which democracy is built. But in recent years these principles have come under attack. Big money and the digital age have particularly fuelled the far right, unleashing propaganda campaigns that have no place in a modern, inclusive and progressive society. Electoral interference and disinformation have poisoned our political discussions. Groups have spread messages of hatred with the aim of dividing our communities and eroding trust in our political systems. These untruths have plunged my country into a constitutional crisis, putting the rights and well-being of millions of people in the UK and beyond on the line. The Chair of the House of Commons Digital Culture, Media and Sport Committee has said that – I quote – ‘our democracy is at risk and our electoral regulations are hopelessly out of date for the internet age’, and this from the so-called Mother of all Parliaments. We can’t sit in this elected chamber and turn a blind eye as the very fundamental values of this institution and all our parliaments back home come under siege from characters who want to disrupt our democracies for their own political or financial gain. We need more robust, legally binding protections so that citizens are empowered to decide their own fates, not external powers or those with the deepest pockets. (Applause) (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Belinda De Lucy)

name: Jean-Paul GARRAUD
text: Mr President, the Commission's code of good practice against misinformation is intended to pay attention to freedom of expression and an open internet. That is what is written in the text. This code of conduct has been approved by Facebook, Twitter, Google. These hosts are held responsible for the content of Users' posts. They do not hesitate to censor comments that may be considered misinformation. We all know that the internet is somehow capable of the best and the worst. Except that in this case, under the pretext of combating misinformation, we no longer count the considerable number of Internet users who were censored from one minute to the next and without any warning because they had spread, not "fake news", but because they had expressed divergent and critical opinions towards, in particular, the Commission's Europeanist and immigrationist ideology.  Even news newspapers are censored, such as, in France, Current Values, against which Facebook has authoritarianly deleted an article about French public television propaganda in favour of migrants on the grounds that its content was allegedly hateful.  Hell is always paved with good intentions, the best thoughts can lead to the worst results. In trying to combat false information, we must not lead to the establishment of a kind of ministry of truth as defined by George Orwell in his novel "1984". In 2019, the temptation is great for the proponents of the system in place, followers of globalization and its considerable financial means, to stop by all means the rise of what they call with disdain, the populists. Censorship of the means of communication has been used since the dawn of time by all totalitarian regimes. For the proponents of globalist ideology, all those who oppose it must be blocked. Here in this Parliament, a "sanitary cord" has been used to remove from all responsibility all Members defying this ideology. Nevertheless, we will continue our fight in connection with the deep aspirations of the peoples we respect!

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – Mr President, as you know, the party you represented —Vox — is radically against any foreign interference in the internal affairs of our country. We believe— obviously — in the sovereignty of nations and Member States, and I am glad that, even if only for once, in this Parliament, other political options come to defend sovereignty and consider it untouchable. While I do want to point out that, until proven otherwise, the Treaty on European Union does not speak of European sovereignty, but exclusively of the sovereignty of the Member States. Like many of you, we do not like Russia to be entangled in electoral processes, but we also do not like that Mr Macron or 52 Members of the French National Assembly get tangled up in the electoral decisions taken in Spain, deciding to support or criticize one or the other country, one or the other party in my country. Ladies and gentlemen, we do not like foreign interference, but we also do not want this to be the excuse for the creation of a truth commission, like that of Orwell in 1984 and to tell us from supranational institutions what should or should not be said by the nationals of each of the States.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Mr President, we are in this House at the moment to debate fake news, at the moment you have just indicated that the members of the Brexit party would be part of the Identity and Democracy group. That is not the case. I believe that, above all, in order not to debate false news, we should be careful to respect ourselves. At no time are these parliamentarians in our group and therefore I consider it a denial of democracy not to have given the opportunity to accept or not the blue card.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr! The president decides on the blue cards. There are clear rules for the flow of the blue cards. That is why I rejected it.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, free and fair elections are the foundation of our democracy. We must cherish and protect them. Anyone who tries to damage that foundation must be hard-hit. And we will have to step up a notch if we want to be prepared for a future in which our social interaction will take place even more than it is now online. To a future in which new technology such as deep fakes makes it increasingly difficult to truly distinguish between fakes and a future in which – if we do nothing – people will consume more fake news than real news by 2021. There is quite a lot at stake and companies like Facebook and Google play a crucial role in this. Or rather, they should play a crucial role. Because I don't feel like that cooperation is going well at the moment. It reminds me a little bit of the way I used to do my homework at school: just enough not to get any penal work, but certainly no more than that. You may get away with that in high school math, but in our fight against disinformation, we will fall short. That is why my question is: should we not make much clearer that penal work in the pipeline, do we want these companies to cooperate? Shouldn't we be moving towards a system of regulation, rather than the current half-hearted self-regulation? My question is also, Commissioner King, you have already noticed that: in many European countries legislation is being legislated, legislation is being considered. How do we ensure that this legislation is also coordinated so that we do not have to deal with 28 different rules in 28 different countries?

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, the manipulation of public opinion by circulating fake news on social media, with increasingly sophisticated and covert means, is one of the most serious threats to our democracies and an instrument of obscure political interests, sometimes based abroad.  The European Commission's disinformation plan is taking its first steps and is a good initiative. Just as social media management platforms need to be called to their responsibilities, and journalists must fulfil their role of accurately reporting and reporting false information, these threats require a response to the circumstances, and in this Parliament we also need a special committee to strengthen the defence of our democracy. That is what this report provides and that is why we will vote in favour.

name: Fabienne KELLER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen Commissioners, you mentioned the last elections, have been the subject of unprecedented attempts to destabilisation and interfere with state and non-state actors, as several colleagues have spoken of it.  Mr. Julian King, you pointed out that there are tens of thousands of fake accounts in support of extensive disinformation campaigns. You took an initiative with the Member States in September 2018 with the Member States to arm Europe against misinformation and cybercrime, but that is not enough.  What are the next steps, the next initiatives to strengthen the convergence of national strategies? How can we also strengthen the role and means of the European Cyber Security Agency to create a European shield? Finally, our group supports the creation of a European agency to protect democracies from attack. Are you prepared to support such an initiative?

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Mr President, far from me the idea of wanting to go back on the prerogatives of the presiding officer, but you explicitly based your decision to refuse the blue card on the fact that this parliamentarian belonged to our group. At least admit that it was a mistake, otherwise it is again false news as we participate in an anti-false information debate.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: I have already commented on this issue and I have been informed of it in this way. It may also be that the questioner was a misunderstanding. But let us now move on to the agenda.

name: Markéta GREGOROVÁ
text: – Mr President, disinformation campaigns, hybrid threats, information warfare: the modern conflict is being led in new fields, and liberal democracy and our free and fair elections are being used against us by foreign forces with an increasing intensity and efficiency. We must create a functional system of deterrence as part of our defensive strategy. However, we must remain equally wary of measures that can also destroy the very foundation of our democratic societies. Free speech cannot be defined by commercial monopolies. It is far too valuable to be defined by online platforms and upload filters. Lawmakers must be in the lead on combating election interference and propaganda. Equally, technologies that allow behavioural prediction and manipulation on a mass scale are threatening the very basis of free and fair elections, and we must update our legislation to safeguard European citizens but with regard to the very democratic principles we are trying to protect. Let’s finally step into the 21st century.

name: Christine ANDERSON
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has Today we are talking about the European Commission's action plan against the spread of disinformation. Is that actually a joke? The EU Commission, of all people, therefore considers itself suitable to fight fake news – it is the headquarters of all fake news production sites! In the brochure "60 Reasons for the EU" published by the European Commission, the peoples of Europe are given 64 pages to explain the benefits of the EU and the euro. As page 16 states: "Thanks to the ECB's monetary policy, Member States have saved EUR 50 billion in 2016." This is fake news! For it is a deliberate misrepresentation of the peoples of Europe to conceal the fact that this much-hyped saving is in fact an expropriation of their assets. Is this a tragic case? No, not at all. When the President of the Commission writes in her own agenda for Europe – and I quote: 'For my generation, Europe stood for the promise of peace, prosperity and unity, and we made it a reality through our common currency, through freedom of movement and enlargement' – it is the mother of all fake news campaigns. We were promised peace and prosperity. We have preserved the EU, a bureaucratic madhouse in which a political elite, completely alienated by the citizen, is peddling and harassing the peoples of Europe through the madness of regulation and regulatory madness. What the peoples of Europe think of this great EU coercive community can be seen wherever they are asked: in France, in the Netherlands, in Greece, and the British have expressed their particular displeasure. But the Commission's action plan is right and important, so we will support and prevent it. I'm starting today! (The speaker tore apart the brochure 'A Union that wants to achieve more – My Agenda for Europe')) (The speaker declined to answer a question about the procedure for Lukas Mandl's 'blue card')

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the On a point of order, Mrs Anderson has just called this House 'a bureaucratic madhouse'. This is an insult to the European Parliament. I would ask you to study the Minutes and to respond accordingly.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: For this suggestion and for watching it come up, thank you, that will happen in this form.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Foreign interference in democratic processes is reprehensible. It is reprehensible when the Kremlin tries to buy influence through European parties, as well as when they hire former Socialist heads of government to lobby for Nord Stream, for example. But it is also reprehensible when the EU uses tax revenue to influence the outcome of the European Parliament elections. This leaked document from the leadership of the European Parliament shows how it planned to spend SEK 350 million to sponsor, for example, lobbies and campaigns such as 'This is what europe is doing for me' in order to get EU federalist voters to the polls and reduce the influence of voters if they preferred a nation state over federalism. So let us work against undue interference in democratic processes. But let us be consistent.

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This is my inaugural address in this House, so I am very pleased that I have been given such an important subject, because I myself have been a victim of the Fancy Bears group. I got the same emails that Mr. Podesta then got in the United States, and we know how that affected the election campaign there.  There have already been examples of external interference in politics in France, in the United Kingdom, in Italy. Also in my country, a book by a renowned journalist, Mr Grzegorz Rzeczkowski, entitled "The Foreign Alphabet", was recently published in my country, and I wanted to call on our public prosecutor's office in Poland to take seriously this very disturbing information about foreign interference in Polish politics.  What to do? First of all, what not to do? I believe that politicising the media, which should be public, making them more trust-free and making it easier for those who want to influence elections illegally. We should increase the budget to combat disinformation, we should build opportunities for traditional media, and therefore support the Creative Europe programme, and finally we should regulate the activities of social media.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr! I must ask you not to hold any rallying of applause from the gallery. That is incompatible with the Rules of Procedure of this House.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner King, Finnish Presidency, if ten years ago, when the Lisbon Treaty came into force with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, we would have been told that the threat of trolls, bots, non-State or state actors and non-State groups linked to States would have been a priority subject for this European Parliament , as is the case in Russia, against democratic processes through interference and poisoning, we would not have believed it. But the threat is real. And it is neither neutral nor harmless nor can it be underestimated. It is not neutral, because it favors the dispersal of extremist and populist discourses. It is not harmless, because it is often ousited with minorities and vulnerable groups. And it cannot be underestimated, because it affects not only the Member States that suffer from it, but the whole of the Union. And it is the Union that has to provide the answer, with adequate regulations and resources. That is why we demand investments to eliminate false accounts and to articulate a response of European meaning that strengthens democracy and the rule of law. And the instrument is a special commission that thoroughly investigates and extracts the consequences and lessons, and brings them to this House as recommendations.

name: Bernard GUETTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, freedom of expression is the pillar of democracy, as we all know. But its downside is known: misinformation, which has taken on a new dimension thanks to the perversion of the internet and social media. We may have seen only the beginning of this phenomenon, which is urgently opposed. Thank you to the Commission for starting the battle. But how can we control the veracity of the information without reconnecting with the offices of censorship? We are walking there on eggshells, but after all, democracies have long since learned to fight defamation without undermining freedom of expression. The same task awaits us today: to define the crime and punish it by law, which is applied by an independent justice system. That is our duty as legislators. But journalists - I am one of them - have to reinvent a press whose commitments, vigour and clarity leave no room or seduction for organized destabilization from abroad (or not).

name: Annalisa TARDINO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we all agree that fake news and disinformation constitute a real risk, capable of influencing the conviction of citizens in electoral contests by those who are constantly campaigning, as they are trying to do in this House too, by reproposing manipulated news such as that on Russian funds, on which the courts will express their views. In demonising the adversary, as is unfortunately customed, great care must be taken not to harm the great democratic value represented by the network and the free movement of ideas, the foundation of knowledge and the emancipation of man. On the other hand, it seems that the Commission, on the pretext of combating disinformation, is further encouraging censorship of dissenting opinions, as is already the case on social networks. I wonder, therefore, whether it is appropriate for a private operator, such as Facebook, to have the authority to censure a citizen without any intervention by a public third party that can protect him. I think we should take serious action.

name: Lucia ĎURIŠ NICHOLSONOVÁ
text: – Mr President, it does not matter what faction we come from. I think that the same task lies ahead of us all, and that is right to identify who the aggressor is, who is repeatedly resorting to disinformation campaigns that undermine democracies in our nation states, but also within the European Union. And we all know that these disinformation anti-capitalisms do not arise on Mars, either in Bolivia or in India, and I therefore think that we should stick to the facts, and those facts make it clear that behind these disinformation campaigns is clearly the Putin administration, Russia under the Putin administration. For example, a Czech team of experts on countering hybrid threats published figures that between 2014 and 16 elections and referendums within the European Union were directly influenced by putin's administration, either through state media or through various trolls on social networks. Worse, those trolls are getting into our national governments and our national parliaments. I therefore call on all of you to put aside political correctness and to make it very clear that the aggressor in this case, when it comes to disinformation, is the Putin administration.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: –Mr President, hybrid warfare, and the spread of disinformation and fake news in particular, threaten our democratic institutions across Europe. We need free and fair elections, just like we need free and fair referendums, and since the bulk of political campaigns has moved to social media, we have to ensure that the internet is able to face up to the spread of disinformation timely and effectively. As just the most recent hybrid hacker attack on Austria illustrates, smaller European democracies are especially vulnerable to foreign interference in national elections and, I should add, the subsequent spread of disinformation as we see it in Austria today. At the same time, smaller European democracies possess more limited resources to communicate effectively with global internet platforms about how best to fight against disinformation attacks. Therefore, in order to protect democracy across Europe, we need a strong and common European political approach in managing our communication and cooperation with social media in our struggle against disinformation campaigns. I therefore urge the Commission and also the Finnish Council Presidency to take up this issue seriously. We have to be united in this.

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yes, our democratic way of life is under threat, but no, it is not threatened by the exiles we let die in the Mediterranean. It is threatened by the forces that interfere in our elections and in our public debates. Strache case, In Austria, case of financing the Lega, in Italy, Cambridge Analytica case, case of the Russian banks of the National Front... All these cases show the financial ties and the relations of vassal that the extreme right, here present, has with the regime of Vladimir Putin. They also show the vulnerability of our democratic systems to external interference. Instead of inventing imaginary enemies, let's deal with this very real threat. That is why I solemnly ask you today, ladies and gentlemen, for the establishment of this special committee to shed light on these interferences and their relays and to define the means to counter them. It is about the very survival of our democracies. Let's not let ourselves be trampled on, it's time to react.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: – Mr President, just before coming here I had a short exchange of views with Jessikka Aro. Jessikka Aro was the Finnish journalist who revealed what was actually going on behind the walls of a Russian address, 55 Savushkina Street in St Petersburg. What she experienced thereafter was something terrible because the family of trolls, Russian or their friends, actually tried to do something nobody in this House would like to experience, because they were trying to destroy her as a personality. She was too strong for that, but she had one question for you: give Interpol enough money to be able to fight this sort of criminal act.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I think we can agree that the interference of third countries in internal EU electoral processes by disinformation is a great threat to the democratic process, to fundamental rights of citizens, to freedom, to reliable information and to sovereignty, above all to the sovereignty of the Member States. We must also agree that it is no coincidence that we are talking here mainly about one country – Russia. And certainly not only the Countries of the European Union, but also the Eastern Partnership countries are victims of such campaigns. We should help them in the fight against this kind of disinformation.  However, two more things need to be said. Firstly, that, of course, other actors, other states, non-state actors, as well as Member States and their media trying to interfere in the democratic processes of neighbouring countries are also sources of disinformation and 'fake news'. I also wanted to say one more pathological effect, namely that today it is clear that those who fought the theory of conspiracy are themselves succumbing to conspiracy theories today. They see Putin and his trolls everywhere when they are dealing with election results that don't suit their tastes.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, I would like to make one point clear essentially: the work we have to do against manipulation and misinformation, particularly on electoral issues, is not a job to do only on the eve of the elections. It is a continuous work, not least because the manipulation of public opinion is often done with time and is done with insistence on social networks, technology platforms, conventional media, and so we have to have an answer that is a continuous response. On the one hand through the European External Action Service, where I think there is much to improve; on the other hand through technology platforms, not only their spontaneous cooperation but their collaboration with European bodies and national bodies; and also through the training of citizens, and this is the point that seems essential to me: the training of citizens. And here I say: formation of politicians, because politicians contribute to "fake news". Formation of religious leaders and opinion leaders, because they contribute to credibility of "fake news". Training, in particular, of journalists and journalists from all existing media. The training of these operators will be essential to detect the "fake news", the instrumentalization and to prevent the other risk, the risk on the other side that is censorship, and which we also want to ban.

name: Carlo CALENDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, liberal democracy is under attack and will remain under attack for the next ten years. It is under attack from within, by parties such as the League and the 5 Star Movement in Italy who want to demolish it, and this attack is met with elections, because democracy defends itself with democracy. But it is also under attack from abroad, and this attack from abroad is accompanied by parties attacking it from within and, in this case, democracy cannot be enough to defend democracy, we need a special committee to ascertain how there has been very heavy interference by those parties that claim to defend the national interest but sell the national interest to foreign countries. This cannot be tolerated and Europe must be able to defend itself! Democracy is respectful, democracy is open, but democracy is not weak. Democracy is strong and it knows how to respond. I will conclude by saying that the speeches on the other side of the House look very much like that Latin saying 'excusatio non petita, accusatio manifesta'.

name: Klemen GROŠELJ
text: – Honourable President-in-Office, Commissioner, the implication of foreign, whether state or non-state actors, in elections and, in particular, pre-elections and others for democratic societies, key processes in the European Union, in the Member States and beyond, has been given dimensions that undermine the foundations of our democratic regulation. The scale of thoughtful, targeted and very well-organised and coordinated activities is becoming a threat to which we must respond more decisively. It is a combination of the abuse of new technologies and the associated access to our homes, on the one hand, and the information needs, modern, democratic, open and real freedom of speech-based societies, on the other.  This uses a range of propaganda methods and techniques, but even more often sophisticated methods that distort truth or create a false impression of the reality of the information and data transmitted, which undermine democratic elections or direct public debate in our societies. Responding to this threat is necessary because our core values are at risk, but at the same time it must be thoughtful, based on strict respect for the rule of law and democratic values and standards.  Above all, it must be based on proactive action against this threat by providing credible and verifiable information that will frustrate the manipulative activity of foreign actors.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: – Dear Presidency, Commissioner. In fact, the threat we are talking about is much deeper than just disinformation, and we must remember– whether or not to like it – that the European Union as such is not a global leader in data collection, in the development of artificial intelligence, or in the sense of combating disinformation and other methods that undermine the foundations of democracy.  What should we do in this situation? I see that we should concentrate the resources that we have and improve cooperation. The question is whether we are doing this. We have heard here about the call for a new European agency for democracy, but we forget – and there was no one here – that we even here, in European capitals, have a NATO Centre for Strategic Communication in Riga, we have a NATO Cybersecurity Excellency Centre in Tallinn, which is with our own experts, there are most of these national experts, and their work is much, much deeper. We look at it and use this resource. Although the public information on the dangers of elections is the experience of Finland, Sweden, Latvia, Estonia, and it should be used on these pages.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council and the Commission, fake news really has a harmful effect on liberal democracies and is one of the most important challenges we have to face as a society. This kind of news—fake news—creates confusion among citizens, erodes trust in institutions, and induces citizen deception and, more importantly, creates political instability. The truth— and we must not deceive ourselves — is that fake news is the instrument of the enemies of open societies, they are the instrument of authoritarian regimes that direct public opinions from power or from populist forces seeking to condition public debates to achieve their objectives. Two clear examples of this are what we have recently experienced with Brexit or what happened recently, what we suffered in Spain, during the crisis of the secessionist challenge that occurred in 2017. On that occasion Catalan independence showed its mastery in the use of propaganda, manipulation and the dissemination of falsehoods, trying to project a negative image of Spain that in no way corresponds to reality. This whole situation is not solved eer by censorship or by limits to freedom of expression. What this phenomenon highlights is the need to have, now more than ever, a media that guarantees the quality of the information they offer to citizens. And, likewise, we have to influence education, training responsible and critically spirited citizens. It is also necessary to influence the humanities and the formation of the capacities of young people. This is a long-term approach, it's an ambitious approach, but I think there's the key to confronting the phenomenon of fake news rigorously.

name: Sven MIKSER
text: – Mr President, while I think it is important that we hold this debate today, I believe that this alone is not sufficient given the magnitude of the challenge. Therefore, I strongly support the proposal to set up a special committee tasked with looking into external interference in our democratic processes and elections. Russian attempts to meddle in our elections and engage in other malicious influence activities have been well documented, and some have been mentioned here today. The regime in the Kremlin, as well as other illiberal and non—democratic regimes, have made no secret of the fact that they detest our core European values and our representative democracy. So it should not be entirely surprising that they support, financially or otherwise, political forces in our countries that share their disgust of liberal values. It’s not, however, limited just to that. Perhaps even more importantly, they want to undermine the trust of European citizens in our democratically elected institutions and to discredit the whole concept of liberal democracy. This is an existential threat to our Union and must be treated as such by us. Setting up a special committee is therefore a step in the right direction.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, despite the efforts to darker this subject by watering down the debate, I will focus primarily on the role of Russian propaganda, because, as we know, Kremlin propaganda has a very significant influence in the role of fake news and, of course, has also improved significantly over the years, even embeing extra budget resources. After all, we have significant experience with Russian disinformation in the Czech Republic and formerly czechoslovakia, when, for example, the invasion of 1968 was impersonated as brotherly help. Or, most recently, we have a dispute over the monument to Marshal Koněv, which is purposefully only thumed as a purely positive historical figure, and we know that this is not the case, for example, in the suppression of the Hungarian uprising.  Russian disinformation should definitely be confronted, if they are improving, we must also improve. We have already done a lot in this regard, this year voluntary reporting of online platforms on disinformation was introduced. And a rapid alert system has also been set up to facilitate, firstly, the sharing of member states' knowledge of these disinformation campaigns and also to coordinate responses to them, which is very important. But what matters now is how we can put all this into practice and work with it effectively. I have high expectations of the newly appointed Vice-President of the Commission, Mrs Jourová, who is currently in charge of the fight against disinformation and fake news, so I will keep my fingers crossed for her. (The speaker rejected the question Anna Bonfrisco wanted to ask by raising the blue card.)

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Dear Chairman, thank you. With the development of digitalisation, information is expected to become increasingly accessible to communication platforms. Of course, that's legal.  However, the developed interaction is not accompanied by an adequate level of protection of private information or a verification of the veracity of the information being placed. The Cambridge Analytica scandal has demonstrated how personal information is misused, used for propaganda purposes and for shaping political campaigns. The Eurobarometer from November last year points out that almost two thirds of citizens are concerned about foreign influence and the possibility of manipulating the election results . The Commission's preliminary review of the European elections shows that groups linked to third countries and various non-state actors have worked to undermine the credibility of the European Union through social media. There is enough evidence to make this topic one of our priorities and that is why I support the creation of a special committee. I also believe that it is necessary to extend the debate to the financing of political parties, those directly related to third countries, their impact on the content of campaigns and thus on the results of elections.  Thank you.

name: Mónica Silvana GONZÁLEZ
text: – Mr President, we need a Europe that protects people, and protecting people means strengthening, and this Parliament should send a very clear message to the Commission to protect European societies and institutions. The content of misinformation, polarizing and based on nationalisms, religious feelings, are ousted with certain groups ⸻colectives such as migrated people or people of different religious orientation, LGTBI people, etc⸻, promoting a discourse of hatred that, unfortunately, is widespread, and to Spain has also arrived. And in recent elections we see how this discourse of hatred has become a political apology, becoming enticed with LGTBI people and migrants, with falsehoods such as ending the end of Christian identity, etc., etc. Scapegoats are sought and scapegoats are sought in those of us who defend these people and their rights. We're labeled enemies. These populses are obviously funded by foreign entities. That is why we need a strong resolution to protect people out of this Parliament and, in particular, the collectives have been included. We want to create a special commission just for research and for more coordination between States.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, for a moment I invite you to imagine the European Union, which is known for setting global standards of quality of life in democracy, falling into the following situation: less independent and no investigative media, our citizens living in a post—truth society and dangerously exposed to outside manipulation and national populists are generously financed by foreign subjects. As a result, we’re living according to the national interest of such countries as Russia, China or probably any extremist group. I am convinced that none of us wants this, and it is high time to review the EU and national legislation in regard to foreign financing of political parties campaigning or individual candidates, and also to install screening mechanisms for strategic foreign investments. This is how I imagine the European way of life can be sustained.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Madam President, I have listened attentively to the Commission and I have heard that it is particularly satisfied with itself in its fight against false information. However, the reality is very different. I hear countries or political parties pointing the finger, but what about its own interference with the member nations of the European Union? The British have made the choice to leave the European Union; everything is being done today, including by false information, to block this sovereign decision. In Italy, the road to democracy would be a return to the polls: again, the Commission encourages false news, false rumours, an unnatural political union. The Commission spends its time, against the advice of the people, interfering in the affairs of the nations of the European Union on matters outside its competence, thus flouting our treaties. Once again, today, our assembly is waving great ideas, but not sweeping at its own door.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, I find a real irony in the idea of electoral interference in the democratic processes of the European Parliament when we all know the democratic deficit that exists, and you’d wonder why anyone would bother! But the reality is that foreign electoral interference has been going on since there were elections. The USA has been interfering on a grand scale not just in South America or the Middle East but actually in the heart of Europe itself. And the only reason we’re now invoking the spectre of Russian interference is to blame somebody for the catastrophic electoral failures of the establishment parties in Europe and the failure of neoliberal policies that have left millions of European citizens behind, have left them demoralised and disillusioned. These are the real reasons for the election of Trump, for Brexit and for the rise of the far right, but of course it’s far easier to pretend that it’s a conspiracy by an official enemy and that citizens are too stupid to know what’s good for them.  If we’re really concerned about electoral interference, let’s address the vast and constant interference in the democratic process by lobbyists, by billionaire newspaper owners, by transnational corporations. Fix that and you won’t have to worry about internet memes and Facebook ‘likes’ that nobody outside this bubble cares about.

name: Marina KALJURAND
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioners and the Finnish Presidency and I would like to express my hope that we will negotiate and adopt a strong resolution on this important topic. Foreign electoral interference attacks one of the most sacred and universal principles of non—interference articulated in the UN Charter. This interference has different aspects, as we have already heard, and I would like to underline the importance of tackling attacks against technical infrastructure essential to democratic processes, in other words, attempts to hack democracy. In order to tackle these attacks, we need strong national measures as well as EU—wide and international cooperation. Here the EU should be a leader: vocal, united, strong and committed. We should be crystal clear that foreign interference is not acceptable and that appropriate measures will be taken against those who violate it.

name: Julian King
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank honourable Members for this important and timely debate. As a number of you have underlined, disinformation campaigns are designed to hamper the ability of our citizens to make informed choices, to divide our society and our communities, and to call into question the outcomes of our electoral processes and the integrity of our democratic institutions. I don’t think that we can accept this as a new normal. We must be ready to do more to counter it.  Part of the problem comes from outside of the EU. A number of you have mentioned Russia. Let me be clear: there is a team – it’s been referred to in the institutions – whose job it is to monitor pro-Kremlin disinformation campaigns, and they report – this is publicly available – that, over a recent period when they checked, the amount of pro-Kremlin coordinated disinformation across our Member States had doubled compared with a year ago. So this is a real problem, and we should not duck that. Let me also be clear that others have learned from the Russian playbook, so we have to build our resilience – we have to build our counter-measures to resist and counter disinformation, wherever it comes from.  That’s why we’ve put in place – from the Commission’s side, working with the Member States and with civil society – a series of measures. But I am not pleased, and we are not resting on our laurels: we say we need to do more. We need to do more on tackling online disinformation, and we need to do more on reinforcing the resilience of our elections. In the coming weeks and months, we will review the Code of Practice on Disinformation to ensure that we can do better to protect the integrity of our democratic societies, and we will report to you on this by the end of October. Let me just say, in response to one or two of the comments, that this Code of Practice on Disinformation which we are pursuing with the social media platforms has absolutely nothing to do with censorship. It has absolutely nothing to do with the idea of a Ministry of Truth. It is not about determining that a particular political comment is good or bad, true or false. It is about shining a light on the provenance of political debate. It is about transparency, so that our citizens know when they see information where it comes from, who’s paying for it, and whether it’s a human or an artificial machine that is circulating that information. I think that is essential, if we’re going to be able to equip our citizens to make good choices. We will also come back to you to report on the conduct of the European Parliament elections and the implementation of the election package of measures on free and fair elections. Again, we will work on a European democracy action plan to build the resilience of our democratic systems, and we expect to put forward – subject to confirmation – legislative proposals to ensure greater transparency on paid political advertising and clearer rules on the financing of European political parties. Alongside this, at the same time, we will continue to work with fact—checkers, researchers and civil society, as well as the Member States and online platforms, so that together we can make the progress we need to ensure a prosperous, safe and democratic future for Europe and our citizens.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to participate in this debate. It is on a very topical issue and one which is a priority for our Presidency. I would like to thank Members for their very active participation.  The resilience of our Union is based on unity. The more united we are, the better we can withstand the spread of disinformation. It is our obligation to spare no effort to protect our elections and more generally our democratic systems from foreign interference, and we have to do it in full respect of fundamental rights such as freedom of speech, the media and association.  We will continue working horizontally across sectors, across borders, learning from each other through the exchange of information and best practices. And progress has been made. However, as Commissioner Jourová and Commissioner King and many of you here said, we must remain vigilant, and as I reiterated, the Presidency has placed significant emphasis on hybrid threats.  We also look forward to the new initiatives announced by the Commission. And let me once again point out that general awareness of the hybrid threats among our citizens is essential. While open societies and public administrations provide correct information, there won’t be lasting room for disinformation. So thank you again for this interesting and important debate.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Motions for resolutions tabled pursuant to Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure shall be announced at a later date. The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the next part-session. (The sitting was suspended for a moment) Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In today's debate, we are talking about the importance of maintaining and defending the sovereignty of our countries, including the right to free elections that we make in the countries. Manipulating public opinion is a huge threat to the democratic process. We are concerned about whether a number of non-EU countries have influenced the election results or public opinion. There are fears of such actions – but we have no certainty, no one has been proven.  On the other hand, we know examples where people who should never have done so because of their office have repeatedly and actively been involved in the last election campaign. This is none other than EC Vice-President Frans Timmermans, who actively participated in Poland in the conventions of the elected parties a few days before the MAY EP elections. And none other than the Vice-President of the European Commission, the Commissioner for Better Regulation, the Rule of Law and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Similarly, The President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, took part in the election campaign, also actively participating in the Campaign of the Citizens' Coalition.
