He is another person who, by his or her role, should remain apolitical and represent all EU citizens, not promote the elect.  It is therefore important to combat the camouflaged actions of third countries, but it is equally important – if not more important – to maintain due standards on our internal soil in the European Union.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Writing. "It is astonishing how rationality on Earth has been taken over by tempers, fears of nonexistent things, hatred of one other within certain nations. One of the disadvantages of technical progress is the systematic misrepresentation and manipulation of societies, the means by which states aspiring to increase their power deceive, push them into fear, and thus blackmail citizens. While this is increasingly a global problem, see Putin's Russia having a smaller or more successful influence on the decisions of previously glistening democracies in accordance with its own interests, whether I am thinking of the US presidential election or Brexit and many other similar cases, this disinformation is increasingly burning on our fingernads here in Europe.  Moreover, it seems that good European states here are struggling with the elements that affect democracy, while the reality is that there is an EU Member State that produces fake news on its own, spreads it by all means of public life, creates fear in the electorate and then generously offers their protection if they vote for it. I am saddened to inform you that this EU Member State is my own country, Hungary. I support the proposal. But how can Member States be called upon to act when a Member State is a major offender? The fight against fake news can only be successful if we take action against the strongest perpetrators, such as the Hungarian government.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Written. In recent years, several choices have been subjected to external manipulation, and electoral rules have been broken in a number of Member States. In 2020, more than 50 different elections will be held in EU Member States and foreign influence will continue to be a challenge. In addition to disrupting elections, disinformation erodes confidence in public and public debate. Studies show that manipulation is often used to sow division in society, by identifying certain groups as a threat. Minority groups are particularly often attacked. These disinformation campaigns not only come from outside, but are also used by far-advanced groups and parties within Europe to strengthen their positions. In the long term, this threatens democratic society and I believe that more needs to be done. I support the Commission's action and believe that online giants need to take greater responsibility for how hate, threats and false information are spread on their respective networks.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: in writing. – The European Union 's (EU) obsession with the possible interference of third countries in the democratic processes of its Member States is, more than anything, an exercise in cynicism, when it is known that it is itself, the EU, a constant source of interference in the sovereignty of other countries. It is not strange, therefore, that this resolution is the use of unsupported and ever-supporting accusations in supporting organisations aimed at destabilising third countries, controlling citizens' personal data and information, affirming the military and geostrategic interests of an EU that is ever more concerned with markets than democracy. Fake news, information quality and information literacy should be issues that concern us all. But we must recognise that it is often the EU and the European institutions that promote fake news. Facing this problem is not done with the invention of an external enemy; it is done with the democratization of the media, with the end of the concentration in large groups of the media, with the end of the submission of the contents to the interests of the major economic groups, with the strengthening of the public media, with the valorization of the working conditions of professionals in the sector.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on forest fires in the Amazon region (2019/2811 (RSP)).

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I believe I am not alone in saying that the matter that is before us today, the forest fires that are currently ravaging the Amazon region, is deeply worrying for us all. The fires are a tragedy, not only for the people directly affected but also, more broadly, for our planet and the climate.  It cannot be overstated how important preserving the Amazon rainforest is for effective global climate action. The Amazon rainforest is also uniquely rich and diverse. It is home to one in ten species on Earth. Deforestation, mainly caused by human action and climate change, is a serious threat. It causes a drastic loss of species and tropical rainforest.  These fires are directly related to intentional deforestation. Unfortunately, we note with concern that they have been even more severe in recent days in the rainforest of Brazil and across the border in Bolivia and Paraguay. These fires are severely polluting the air, they are killing many species of rainforest plants and animals and they are expelling indigenous people out of their territories.  The EU’s leadership in global climate action and the protection of forests are among the priorities of the Finnish Presidency. Forest fires have devastating consequences for human and animal life. We depend on forests to preserve biodiversity, to limit global warming and to provide people with jobs and livelihoods. Forests will also make an essential contribution to the EU’s aspirations of achieving climate neutrality by 2050. This House discussed the preparations for the UN Climate Action Summit this morning and our debate this afternoon is very relevant to this indeed.  Despite the actions taken so far at EU level and the commitments undertaken at international level, deforestation and forest degradation remain on the rise. The devastating fires in the Amazon region have made the need to step up this effort even more pressing.  In April 2019, the Council adopted conclusions on the progress made in the implementation of the EU forest strategy. On that occasion, the Council stressed the importance of the strategy to ensure the coherence and coordination of the EU and Member States’ policies affecting forests and to promote further the sustainable management of forests. The Agriculture and Fisheries Council will hold a debate next month on the need for a new strategy beyond 2020, building on the same principles but also considering the new policy developments at Member State, EU and international level.  The Council and Parliament have recently received a long—awaited communication from the Commission on stepping up EU action to protect and restore the world’s forests. We will examine in detail the list of priority actions proposed in this report and we look forward to your ideas on this matter. The Council is working to provide some feedback to the Commission’s communication in the form of Council conclusions that we hope to adopt in December 2019.  Given that drivers of deforestation go beyond the forestry sector, our intention is to involve, in this exercise, policy experts from connected areas such as environment, agriculture and trade. We look forward to your reactions to this communication too and trust that they will make a valuable contribution to the future course of action.  Let me conclude by underlining that the forest fires in the Amazon region are an urgent global crisis which requires an effective international response. Close cooperation with the countries of the Amazon region is crucial. These countries, such as Brazil, have the full right to lead the response but they need to live up to their commitments. I strongly appeal to the countries in the Amazon Basin and their leaders for urgent action. We are ready to work together with Mr Bolsonaro and others. The EU is ready to support but we need action now.  As the Council Presidency, Finland stands ready to support the EU’s reflection on how it can best contribute. On Finland’s initiative, the EU Foreign Ministers discussed the issue at their informal meeting in Helsinki at the end of the August. The Foreign Ministers agreed on the gravity of the situation and stressed the need for a coordinated and comprehensive EU approach to address the crisis. As the Council Presidency, we will continue to do our best to contribute to ensuring united, consistent and effective EU action on this matter.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, today we are facing a global biodiversity and climate crisis which is affecting our lives, it is affecting our economies, and it is also affecting our future.  Current forest fires across the globe are releasing great amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, deepening that crisis, not only in the Amazon, but also in other parts of the world, such as Siberia. But the Amazon is a unique forest, unique for the oxygen that we breathe, unique for the biodiversity that it hosts and unique for the health of our planet. I am, therefore, grateful that you have put this issue high on your agenda. Halting deforestation is key and is essential for three main reasons: to stop biodiversity loss, to address climate change and to achieve the 2030 agenda for sustainable development and our commitments under the Paris Agreement.  The degradation and loss of forests have major consequences on stability and security, on human rights, the climate, biodiversity and the health and livelihoods of both local communities and the wider planet. The European Commission is helping address the situation in the Amazon countries affected by forest fires, and is in regular contact with the relevant authorities, including those in Brazil. A number of operational instruments have already been activated to improve the current situation. Following Bolivia’s request, the Emergency Response Coordination Centre has already sent a team of fire-fighting experts to the country. Such assistance could be provided to any affected country upon official request. Also, the Copernicus emergency mapping system has been activated and maps are being produced for the fires in Brazil, in Bolivia and affected parts of Peru and Paraguay. These are in the public domain. The European Union is already financing development projects which are related to forest and land use in the Amazon basin, including in Brazil – for a total of EUR 128 million – and is planning new actions for a total of EUR 28 million. We are in close contact with the Chilean authorities and the Colombian authorities who have been active in coordinating regional efforts to address the situation. At the recent G7 summit, we were engaged in the preparations for a high—level meeting on the Amazon region on the margins of the United Nations General Assembly. While the immediate priority is fighting wildfires, it is necessary to address the underlying structural causes, such as agricultural expansion. In July, the Commission adopted the communication stepping up EU election to protect and restore the world’s forests. The communication outlines a comprehensive set of actions, including support for sustainable land—use practices. This entails working with partner countries to reduce pressures on forests and to encourage forest restoration. For the European Union’s part, we are addressing our consumption footprint on land; we are assessing additional demand—side, regulatory and non-regulatory measures to minimise the risk of importing products associated with deforestation and forest degradation. We are also working to improve the availability and the quality of information on forests and commodity supply chains, inter alia, by establishing an EU observatory on deforestation and forest degradation. Sound scientific information is an important element of the EU’s strategy; collaboration with partner countries is also key, inter alia, to identifying the long-term economic consequences of further deforestation. The Commission is committed to sustained action against deforestation and we stand ready to assist those affected by the recent forest fires in the Amazon and across the globe, in any way that we can, and in close cooperation with these countries’ authorities.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I want to thank in particular Ms Tuppurainen. She has particular knowledge on forests so we are very happy that under her Presidency we’re having this debate, and indeed the detail which the Commissioner has delivered to us.  I dare say many of the visitors in the Chamber will have seen the forest fires in the Amazon. It’s what motivated me to hold this debate and I am glad that the Group supported us talking about this issue. It really is a question of how globally we can work together, because no nation on its own can solve this problem. But at a time when nations want to be sovereign, is it possible for multilateralism to be strengthened rather than weakened? And pointing the finger at countries doesn’t help. We have to show where the failings are but also acknowledge where progress has been made. So to Brazil, for example, there is action recently around the Leticia Pact with seven other South American countries, Operation Law and Order Guarantee and Operation Green Brazil, but this comes after pressure from the international community. We will all suffer if the Amazon dies and it is already under threat. You have outlined that in great detail.  I was pleased the Commissioner mentioned the need to look at policy coherence around the fact that land is being, if you like, brought into production and forest destroyed for agriculture reasons, and we’ve signed a deal, the Mercosur trade agreement, and we must make sure that the climate and biodiversity commitments contained in that deal with our Mercosur counterparts are honoured. I think that for us in this House will be key.  We do need a carrot and stick approach to this issue. We should also as Europeans put our own hands up and say that we have not always valued forests or biodiversity or done the right thing for the environment, and perhaps in that place of humility we can work better with our colleagues in South America and elsewhere, because in the Arctic, in Indonesia, in the Congo Basin, there are fires burning, turf fires which are releasing massive amounts of carbon. This debate is timely and I thank all those who take part in it.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, fires in this summer's Amazon rainforest have been a real tragedy, an event that has saddened and mobilized the international community. The environmental, social and economic impact of this tragedy goes far beyond the Amazon basin. The Amazon is the earth's lung, produces 20% of our planet's oxygen and hosts more plant species than any other ecosystem. In addition, it is the home of more than one million indigenous people who have been living there sustainably for generations, and now their natural heritage has to be defended. And I know this reality perfectly, because I had the great opportunity to volunteer for a month with non-governmental organizations that support these indigenous communities, who need to have sustainable alternatives to their livelihood. I can't imagine how you'll find yourself today after seeing this tragic situation. This is not the first time the Amazon has been devoured by flames, it is true, but this year they have increased by more than 80% compared to last year and in protected areas it keeps increasing. The search for gold increases the deforestation and mercury used contaminates the water, air and food of people and animals. This catastrophe responds to irresponsible policies, driven by climate change denialists, and we know it perfectly well. Mr Bolsonaro is promoting a new gold rush, supported by land hoarders, while ignoring environmental protection. In order not to have to listen to the truth, Mr Bolsonaro has dismissed those responsible for the Brazilian Space Research Institute and the Institute of Environment and Renewable Resources. Mr President, it is the point of non-return for the Amazon and almost 20% of the Amazon has already been deforested. Because, beyond environmental drama, the Social Democrats are also very concerned about the fate of indigenous peoples and their lands. We are witnessing an escalation of violence in indigenous territories throughout Brazil, the killings of indigenous leaders and activists, such as Emira Waipi, Dilma Ferreira Silva and Claudionor Costa da Silva. From the European Union we closely follow regional efforts to find solutions and protect both people and the environment. They have the full support of our group and we will continue to collaborate. We call on Mr Bolsonaro to comply with the international obligations of the Paris Climate Agreement and the environmental clauses set out in the Agreement with Mercosur. If the government turn a deaf ear, it will isolate Brazil from the rest of the international community. And I think it comes very much to tell in this debate to remember an Indo-American proverb: "Only when the last tree is dead, when the last river is poisoned, the last fish is caught, will we realize that we cannot eat the money".

name: Martin HOJSÍK
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, this summer was a summer of horror with regard to forest fires. We all stood in shock as we watched the Amazon burn, but the shock got even bigger when we heard Brazilian President Bolsonaro blaming it on the NGOs who were trying to protect the Amazon rainforest, when in reality it was his reckless policies that contributed to the havoc that we saw.  But let’s be honest: the forest was not burning only in the Amazon. This summer, we saw forests burning from Siberia to Alaska, destroying precious habitats and, effectively, the Earth’s lungs. We have to be clear: forest destruction is a global problem. But it is also time for us to admit that we are part of the problem – that not only our contribution to greenhouse gas emissions, but also our own policies, our own trade and our own law enforcement are to blame.  It is time to change that. It is time for this House to act. We need to say that the Mercosur Agreement is a bit problematic as it stands, but it would be very cheap to say, ‘let’s just shoot down the Mercosur Agreement and everything is solved’. We need to go much deeper. The new incoming Commission claims that the European Green Deal is the top priority. It should not be only about Europe; it needs to go beyond that. It needs to impact the entire world. If we are serious about saving our planet, and indeed our civilisation, we need to ensure that our agriculture policies do not contribute to deforestation, because right now they do – also in the Amazon. We need to ensure that our trade policies don’t contribute to deforestation, because right now they do. We need to ensure that our energy policies don’t contribute to deforestation, because, also, right now they do. What we need is to change all this – for our own sake, and for the sake of our children.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the mostly intentional forest fires in the Amazon have been a wake-up call and now we know better that they are happening elsewhere, to mention the hot spots: Central Africa, South-East Asia, just to mention the most important ones. We also know that to tackle climate change, we need to capture carbon dioxide with all possible means, and the only viable large-scale way available is with the help of forests. However, forests are being converted to agricultural land and – let us be clear – the Mercosur agreement is intended for exports of beef, soy, coffee and other forest-risk products that drive deforestation and endanger the Amazon region. The Mercosur deal currently does not have a viable mechanism to ensure that the Paris Climate Agreement and other international environmental commitments would be respected. It has no teeth. There are no sanctions in that sustainable-development chapter and let me say that, as I understand it, the Commission’s communication on deforestation and forest degradation contains one promise and that is to look into regulatory measures on the demand side, because we need badly European legislation which makes it sure for the European consumers that they are not buying deforestation. We are also complicit, and I would like to put a question to the Finnish Presidency because I know that it has now been decided that the Agriculture Council will deal with the communication on deforestation and forest degradation. How come only the Agriculture Council? Why not the Environmental Council, for instance?

name: André ROUGÉ
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Amazon rainforest is burning, causing the ecological catastrophe we all know. Through the voice of President Macron, France was moved, and we all join in this emotion. However, the national rally would have liked President Macron to be moved in the same way by the fires at least as serious that are devastating the forests of sub-Saharan Africa. After a passing of playground weapons, unworthy of the heads of state of the sixth and ninth world powers, Emmanuel Macron threatened not to sign the Mercosur. Everyone knows that slash-and-burn farming is used to feed Canadian livestock to CETA, a catastrophic treaty for French livestock producers.  The National Rally and its president Marine Le Pen opposed CETA, just as we are opposed to Mercosur, because it is a disastrous treaty for French farmers. President Macron eventually made the same observation and, in the most cynical way, seized on the Amazon disaster and threatened not to sign mercosur. No one will disagree here, ecology and the environment are too serious and engaging subjects for the future of the planet to be used for internal political maneuvering.  In this regard, a well-ordered charity starting with itself, we would like President Macron to put an end to the dismantling of the NFB, to be concerned about the treatment of waste on Reunion Island, to be concerned about the rising waters in Mayotte, to be concerned about the radioactive risk induced by the American dome of the Marshall Islands threatening our compatriots of French Polynesia. , that he is more concerned with the environment of our compatriots in Guyana by preserving the French part of the Amazon as best he can, that he is finally concerned about the environmental disaster of seaweed in Martinique and Guadeloupe.  Unfortunately, after all this turmoil and all these effects of sleeve, Emmanuel Macron will do nothing on these subjects and will eventually sign the Mercosur.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: ECR Group. – Madam President, I am hearing a lot here about Bolsonaro. Bolsonaro is being blamed for all the tragedy that's going on. And we are forgetting - I think there is a kind of one-eyed man in this Parliament - the things that are really going on. Because what is being talked about, for example— the Spanish Socialists were talking about now — is the search for gold and the devastation of the search for gold. This is happening mainly in the Amazon of Venezuela, it is taking place under the control of Mr Maduro, under the control of the Colombian ELN guerrilla groups, which are there thanks to the communist regime of Mr. Maduro and chavismo. We are currently burning in Bolivia, two and a half million hectares have already burned; Bolivia, not Brazil, Bolivia. No one is talking about Bolivia, because Mr Morales, who has increased and shot coca cultivation for cocaine manufacturing, has begun to burn the stubble, and that's where much of the catastrophes come from. And here it seems that we only think of Bolsonaro.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, what the Council and the Commission have told us, but also what the scientists are telling us and the reality itself requires us not only to say words but also to take action. A conversation is not enough. We need to reach conclusions. Let's take action. To exert pressure to stop the deforestation of the Amazon and the destruction of the world's largest lung. And that is why I believe that, when the figures show that in Bolsonaro's term of office the deforestation of the Amazon has increased by 80% in one year and when within a few months the Amazon has been de-de-taxed more than in the last three years, we need to do more. And it is a disgrace to the European Parliament that this debate will not result in a resolution under the responsibility of an alliance of right-wing and far-right political groups. I believe that we must come up with measures and use Mercosur's tool to put pressure on the far-right Bolsonaro.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the enormous environmental disaster in the Amazon forest-global lung is the result of the raid by large capitalist agro-industrial enterprises, mining activities, timber groups, and financial institutions that finance them. The reactionary Bolsonaro government has escalated the anti-environmental policy of previous governments, having handed the region over to business exploitation for biofuel production, agro-industrial chain products, mining and uncontrolled logging. The deforestation of the Amazon also bears the stamp of Eu-Union monopolies. That is why the concern of the European Union and its governments, which also has to do with contradictions with the free trade agreement between the European Union and Mercosur, is hypocritical. It is indicative that, despite the thick talk about the climate situation, the European Parliament – and with the vote of the European People's Party – has even refused to adopt a resolution on the Amazon. We support the fight to make available all the necessary resources, infrastructure and resources to extinguish fires in the Amazon, repair disasters and reforest burned land. Stop, immediately, in the area any business activity!

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The forest fires in the Amazon are a huge disaster. I would just like to make this clear by way of example: in the Paris climate agreement, Brazil did not commit itself to substantially reducing emissions from industry or other sectors, but Brazil's essential obligations in the Paris Agreement are in the area of forest protection and reforestation. And if that doesn't work at all, then that's a big problem for the global climate as well.  But there are also forest fires elsewhere, and we should talk about this at least as intensively. The fires in Siberia and Alaska pose a huge threat to the climate, as large amounts of methane also escape there, which is even more harmful to the climate than CO2. So now no primitive discussion: some are calling for Mercosur to stop – in theory, we could stop all trade with these countries, but are we going to go a step further? Do we then have a means of exerting pressure? Do we then have control over what China and others are doing? I believe that the path of dialogue – of course, exert pressure and also not wave through Mercosur uncritically, but deal with it openly and see how we can really tackle the problem at its root. And we must also take responsibility ourselves. Yesterday we talked about forests in the European Union. We need to protect our forests, perhaps even in Europe, talk about reforestation, and we need follow-up for both. It is perhaps a good thing that we do not have a resolution today on both issues – forests in Europe and forests internationally – but on both issues we must act, carefully consider what is right, and then decide, and we should do so together in the coming weeks.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Madam President, what we are speaking about today is the world’s largest rainforest approaching the point of irreversible destruction. The Amazon matters to us because it matters to the global climate. It’s a carbon sink that can mitigate global warming. If the Amazon rainforest were to die, the large amount of greenhouse gas it would release would speed up the climate change process. Of further concern are the hundreds of fires that have been recorded this year in the Arctic and subarctic. It is estimated that these fires alone have produced about 100 million tonnes of CO2.  But this is a vicious circle: if the international community and the European Union does not step up its work to cut greenhouse gas emissions, the rate of global warming will not slow down and these fires will continue to spread. Provisions to protect the Amazon rainforest are part of the agreement reached between the EU and Mercosur, and it is in everyone’s interest that such provisions are enforced. In the same spirit, rich signatories of the Paris Agreement who pledged to pay developing ones to plan and plant carbon—consuming trees have to do so. Finally, all of us have a responsibility in helping to change current consumption patterns, which are harmful. It is strong European global collective action that is required.

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Madam President, the gallery, as you see, is packed with young people and they care more than all of us about climate change. Forest fires and natural disasters are no longer an issue for individual countries to tackle in isolation. Unfortunately, Amazon fires are part of a greater global trend. The number of global fires increased compared to last year and that has happened exponentially. August 2018 saw 16 000 fires, August 2019 saw 79 000 fires – that is an increase of more than 400%. Europe cannot be on the sidelines when other countries suffer from disasters and need help. No country in the world is immune to such disasters. No country in the world can handle them on their own. It is essential to have concerted action to stop and recover from these calamities. They accelerate global warming and increase the overall temperature of the planet. We need to strengthen our own civil protection response and boost our ability to deal with natural disasters. We have to be ready to complement national capacities when they are overwhelmed. I’m saying this because just now, the Council has cut these funds and we need to re—establish them. It’s not just about forest fires; it’s about people, it’s about their future. It’s about the future of these young people over there.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, there are two ways of dealing with this issue. The first, of course, is emotion and denunciation. How can we not mourn this magnificent forest that is destroying itself and the people who live there who are disappearing? How can we not denounce Bolsonaro, a climate sceptic who wants to sell his country and the Amazon to agribusiness, whose government as the previous one is corrupted by JBS, the world leader in beef, and who is xenophobic, homophobic, sexist? Then there is another way of approaching the issue, which does not suppress emotion or denunciation: it is to see what our responsibility is in these forest fires that are not cyclical. Commissioner, you have achieved the feat of not saying 'Mercosur' or 'common agricultural policy'. I have heard the representatives of the EPP, of Renew, even of the Social Democrats, say: it would be nice, however, to respect the Mercosur agreement.  But if you don't see that the Mercosur agreement - which Brazil signed because it will export soybeans and beef - is structurally destructive of the Amazon and structurally climate-defying, if you do not see that the proposal of the Common Agricultural Policy, carried by the Commission and which you support, will strengthen imports of Brazilian soybeans. , at that time, you do not see your responsibility, you do not participate in the cessation of forest fires, the destruction of the Amazon and the people who live there! So a little serious in this Parliament!

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The Amazon is on fire. These lungs of the world determine whether we will cope with the climate, or not. If deforestation continues at this rate, we will have an unstoppable warming effect. And it will be disastrous for biodiversity. Brazilian President Bolsonaro is complicit in this situation. He is not just in favour of a policy that is dangerous for women's rights activists, LGBTQ people, indigenous peoples and poor Brazilians. His policy is a danger to the whole world – his deforestation policy. It is therefore no wonder that there are many who have reacted and who demand that we act. I agree with the previous speaker. We need to act now. There are several ways of doing this, but one obvious way of doing so is, of course, to freeze the negotiations on the Mercosur Agreement. Freeze it and write in that the Paris Agreement must be respected, that it should be binding and the deforestation of the Amazon must stop. It's going to be binding. Now begins a week of action by young people. They demand of us that we do everything in our power. Well, at least we're going to do it.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we Europeans are jointly responsible for the fires in the Amazon region and the rest of the world. Our consumption of meat, palm oil, the import of feed for intensive farming, in particular soya and mast, largely GMOs, all this contributes to creating high pressure on forests in third countries and accelerates deforestation. The number one priority must therefore be to reduce the european Union's consumption footprint, which has a direct impact on deforestation, and it is not rhetorical to remember that there are 820 million people in the world who do not have food to eat and, conversely, until recently a billion people were overweight. Today the latest surveys tell us that there are two billion people who are overweight and 4 million die from too much food. In the world there is so much, too much unsustainable and unhealthy food, often wasted food, junk food that puts people and the planet at risk. The new Commission will have to tackle these root problems, in the EU's CAP and trade policy if we really want to make a serious effort to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals and the 2030 Agenda and if we really want to work to reduce poverty, hunger, inequality and indiscriminate exploitation of resources around the world.

name: Adam JARUBAS
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Amazon – the lungs of the world and the reservoir of biodiversity – is being cut down, falling victim to fires. Most of them are premeditatedly asked to gain a place for crops, including feed. This situation needs to change. However, until now, we have not been able to influence the countries where deforestation occurs.  The trade agreement with the Mercosur countries has already been mentioned today, which can be used to enforce their compliance with the Paris Agreement and to halt the deforestation of the Amazon. If the agreement is to be adopted and produce the desired results, the Mercosur countries must not only meet the climatic and sustainability criteria, but must also implement criteria equivalent to European animal welfare, food safety and food safety criteria to be met by a French, German or Polish farmer.  But this agreement is not the only form of pressure we have. We know that European banks are investing millions of euros in South American non-sustainable countries, leading to the deforestation of the Amazon for soybean cultivation. Without a lesson in our backyard, negotiations with mercosur countries will not be effective. We must stop the fires of the Amazon, but we must not allow unfair competition in agriculture to be allowed into Europe at the expense of allowing unfair competition into Europe and exposing the health of Europeans by marketing food of unproven quality.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, these horrible forest fires turned the spotlight on the plight of the Amazon basin’s 2.7 million strong indigenous population. These 350 ethnic groups – of which 60 remain largely isolated – strongly rely on the rainforest’s incredible richness, but their living conditions are in steep decline. Government—sponsored intruders looking to capitalise on the rainforest’s resources are destroying their ways of life through logging, fire and farming. These fires were not an accident: they were deliberately set to make way for agriculture, mining, and other developments. Neither is it accidental that the number of forest fires increased sharply since President Bolsonaro took office. His development policy rests on making indigenous people leave their ancestral lands.  The protests of hundreds of indigenous activists against these discriminatory policies have fallen mainly on deaf ears, and we must amplify their voices. We must therefore continue to use our economic power, but also our foreign policy tools, to defend human dignity, biodiversity and our planet. Let me end with a statement made by Marcos Mayoruna, leader of the Matsés tribe: ‘The forest isn’t just for us indigenous. It’s for everyone.’

name: Antony HOOK
text: – Madam President, the skies over São Paulo have turned black from the smoke of the Amazon rainforest burning. These rainforests are the lungs of our world, which we all need for an atmosphere to breathe. The indigenous people who live there want only the basic human right to be left alone, and these fires are destroying their homes. Many people in South East England have contacted me about this. The UK Parliament has been shut down, but this Parliament still gives us a voice. Brazil’s economy is growing – GDP per person has grown by almost a quarter in ten years – and indeed, whether the Mercosur agreement can survive this inferno will be in question. Mr Bolsonaro, if you burn this rainforest, you will burn Brazil’s chance for good relations with Europe. It is not necessary to burn the forest to make wealth; it is necessary to put the fires out to save our planet. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: blue-card question. – (inaudible) cross-party letter to Commissioner Malmström, signed by many people in this Parliament, and it drew attention to Bolsonaro’s ecocidal policies and said that we should not sign up to the trade agreement unless there were legally binding environmental and human rights standards. At that point, members of the Liberal Group did not sign up to that letter, and so I would like to ask Mr Hook: is he ready now to pledge to vote against the EU—Mercosur trade deal as long as it does not include legally binding provisions on environmental protection and human rights?

name: Antony HOOK
text: blue-card answer. – I’m afraid I do not know of the letter of which my colleague speaks. I think this is a matter that is too complicated to be reduced to a yes-or-no question or a single letter; it needs to be looked at in detail. But I’m certainly an advocate that our trade agreements in Europe should be used to promote human rights, to promote liberal values, and to promote fairness and indeed protection of the environment.

name: Anna CAVAZZINI
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Amazon burns, and every minute a piece of the planet's green lungs dies. Brazil's far-right President Bolsonaro's policies against the Paris climate agreement, human rights and indigenous people sit the fuse for the destructive fires in the Amazon. But European policy also bears responsibility. Last year alone, the EU imported 60 000 tonnes of ethanol, 70 000 tonnes of beef and almost five and a half million tonnes of soya from Brazil. For these insane orders of magnitude, precious rainforest is cleared every day. The earth is on fire and we continue to ignite, because the Mercosur Agreement is a fire accelerator. More beef, even more ethanol – that means even more deforestation and even more fires in the Amazon. And Bolsonaro and the agricultural lobby say thank you. We must now take responsibility for our planet and for our climate. The street protests, such as this week's global climate strike, show that we as a Parliament must take responsibility. We must stop Mercosur and we must keep our supply chains free from deforestation, human rights violations and exploitation. Here in Parliament, we have the opportunity to make globalisation fair. Now is the time for that!

name: Martin BUSCHMANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For weeks, more fires have raged in the Brazilian rainforest than ever before. The main reason is our excessive consumption of meat, for which these pastures and arable land are cleared. This criminal slash-and-burn has been going on for years; it destroys valuable animal and plant species as well as the habitat of indigenous peoples. The countless animals that died agonisingly in the flames, the burnt plants and the amount of CO2 that was released in the process are some terrible consequences. The significant damage, destruction or loss of ecosystem has a name: ecocide. Like genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity, the ecocide had been defined by the United Nations as a crime under international law, but the United States, England, France, and the Netherlands insisted on removing ecocide from the list of international crimes. The consequences are catastrophic: environmental sins are only punished with fines. However, the corporations like to risk them, because their overexploitation brings them many times over. This must stop!

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: – Madam President, this summer, our planet was ablaze. Wildfires wiped out forests in the Amazon, in Asia and in Africa. In Europe, three times more wildfires occurred than in every single year between 2008 and 2018. In the Arctic region, burning peat urges us to swift action. We need to tackle this disaster for all of humanity at global level. Rather than scapegoating trade agreements, as done by Mr Jadot, who has already left after having done his show, we should use this sense of urgency to advance the debate on how to better leverage trade policy to export our environmental standards and fight climate change on a global scale. The prospect of the EU-Mercosur Association Agreement is a unique opportunity to hold Brazil to its commitments under the Paris Climate Agreement, such as to restore and reforest 12 million hectares and to attain zero illegal deforestation by 2030, as already stated by my colleague, Peter Liese. Trade policy is no silver bullet for these problems, but it sure can be helpful. For example, through plurilateral agreements on trade in environmental goods, it now lies in our hands to work on the appropriate flanking measures, such as monitoring and certification schemes. Not blame games, but cooperation is the way forward. Not defeatism, but the conviction that this man-made disaster has man-made solutions should guide us.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent The forest is our green lungs. The world's forests play a crucial role for the future, for the climate, in our ability to switch to a sustainable future. We know that one lung is that the forest with its growing trees absorbs and absorbs carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and thus plays an absolutely crucial role in achieving the Paris Agreement's temperature targets. But we also know that the forest with the other lung can contribute with a new technology that is also very important for our transition. But right now, it's right about the Amazon rainforest, which is particularly important. It is not for nothing that the Amazon rainforest is called the lungs of the world. This forest absorbs two billion tons of carbon dioxide a year. You heard me right. This represents 5% of the world's total emissions. This is by far the most important source for us to be able to live up to the Paris Agreement, that we respect the rainforest. The fires in the Amazon are a threat to our future. We need to act responsibly and make sure to take the lead in defending the rainforest.

name: Stéphane BIJOUX
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I come from the French overseas and I want to raise here the alarm, as persistent as ever, of the peoples of the Amazon, still threatened by devastating forest fires.  All humanity is concerned, as we have said, but on the front line are almost 300,000 Europeans. They live in French Guiana, in the Amazon rainforest. France and therefore Europe, we have a common border with Brazil, which is burning, and this gives us legitimacy and even increased responsibility to act and to protect the Amazon.  As usual, there is of course the substance and the form. Acting quickly and well is an emergency issue, but acting within the framework of a procedure, a structured, determined, coordinated parliamentary approach, is a question of coherence and efficiency.  I ask us to use all the levers available so that in the Amazon we have a strategy and a requirement of respect, respect, of course, of the objectives of sustainable development, respect for the fragility of biodiversity, respect for the strength of local people and their ancestral cultures and respect, of course, the commitments that were made during the Paris Agreements.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Madam President, I think everyone was shocked to see what we saw this summer with the Amazon fires, and rightfully so. We have been discussing here the Mercosur trade deal, which is designed to improve and to enhance trade between, for example, Brazil, and Europe. This is not about a blame game. This is to my colleagues in the European People’s Party Group (EPP) – because I really would recommend you to read what’s in it. If you are looking at preventing deforestation, in the current Mercosur trade deal, you will only find it somewhere down the line in the trade and sustainable development chapter. The only things that are being said is to encourage trade in products from sustainably managed forests and to promote, as appropriate and with prior informed consent, the inclusion of forest-based local communities and indigenous people. That’s only talking about encouraging and promoting, whereas the rest of the Mercosur trade deal is very binding. This shows you that this trade deal has totally bizarre priorities: more trade and when it’s about sustainability, promoting and encouraging. That’s the language that we are having here and that’s the question to the Commission and to the Council: do you want to change this language in order to make sure that we have binding rules in place instead of these very weak chapters that we have now in the current Mercosur trade deal?

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Madam President, of course we are all appalled by the situation in the Amazon. But we cannot just deplore or condemn. It is necessary to know how to identify the causes and also to draw the political consequences. The first cause is Mr. Bolsonaro's criminal policy, which dismantles environmental agencies, destroys the habitats of indigenous peoples and uses more and more toxic pesticides. The second cause is also an economic model, that of Brazilian agribusiness, which is based on exports and which needs ever more surface area, especially for soybeans. But our responsibility - because we have to stop being a hypocrite, I heard the right-wing colleague say that Mercosur will incite Mr Bolsonaro to be virtuous. But finally, it's a joke! A bad joke, by the way. The reality is that Mercosur, it's written black and white, it's more ethanol, more sugar, more meat, so it's an incredible incentive for deforestation. It's a climate-icide text.  So, ladies and gentlemen, and especially from the right and From Renew, be consistent, be logical, if you really regret this situation, then reject Mercosur.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support We have been seeing the devastating impact of forest fires for years, of which the disaster in the Amazon region deserves special attention, which I consider to be an extremely serious matter. In my opinion, it is up to the European Union to provide all material and technical assistance to those affected and those in need. I believe that deforestation should be combated by trying to remedy the economic reasons behind deforestation. I was pleased to see that the new European Commission is prioritising increased protection of forests. I consider it important to implement the planned measures listed in the Commission communication currently under negotiation on this subject and to extend them with measures to eliminate the economic causes of deforestation.  Protecting forests and halting the loss of forests is a global issue. It is important that the European Union and its Member States encourage the planting of new forests in their own territories. In Hungary, the government sees support for afforestation as a key issue. This year, it has more than doubled the amount of aid that can be claimed for afforestation and increased the duration of their use.

name: Delara BURKHARDT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The fires in the Amazon are not just a disaster of nature. They are also the result of human action. Slash-and-burn is used for agriculture, purely because the protection of our natural livelihoods is less lucrative. Our consumption and our trade share responsibility, which the Commission acknowledged in its communication on the protection of international forests. Now, however, action must follow. If we are serious, we will not agree to an EU-Mercosur Treaty that does not contain binding, enforceable rules for the protection of forests, respect for human rights and the implementation of the Paris climate agreement. Mere declarations of intent – as the Bolsonaro case shows perfectly – are not yet having any effect. The focus must be on forests if we are to stop the climate catastrophe and the mass extinction of species. In 2020, the EU can show its pioneering role when an international agreement on the protection of species is negotiated at UN level and the further implementation of the Paris climate agreement. Hundreds of thousands of young people will be back on the streets on Friday, not just because they want to hear words from us, but they want to see action. Let us not disappoint them!

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Madam President, it is a pleasure to see you preside over this debate in particular, thank you also to Commissioner Vella for what may be one of his last debates with us.  The Amazon is burning, a fire that ravages the largest forest on the planet, inflames opinions and dynamites diplomatic relations. The burning Amazon is a whole region that is suffocating and the world is suffering. The responsibilities, it has been said, of the Bolsonaro and Morales governments in this disaster are overwhelming, because this vicious circle is terrible. From the carbon sinks these forests become emitting by releasing into the atmosphere the CO2 they have sequestered for centuries.  And we are one of the main importers of deforestation products: palm oil, cocoa, corn, wood, meat and of course Brazilian soybeans. In summary, one in 10 products is associated with deforestation and consumed in Europe. Our response must be up to the task and cross-cutting. Only one measure, since time is running out, is a label, create a label, a certification of the Union to identify and promote its zero deforestation products.

name: Marie TOUSSAINT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Amazon is burning and the fires that are ravaging it are burning our last barricade in the face of climate change. The increase in fires is not only related to drought. It is linked to economic interests that sacrifice the rights of nature. In the Amazon, we expropriate, we deforest, we burn in the name of the sole search for profit. Let us not look elsewhere, with the air of those who are not concerned. These agri-food or extractive companies are also European. These companies are now bound by no rules, no duty of vigilance. And among the world's leading polluters, how can we tolerate total and Shell, these two European oil companies, not even being required to comply with the Paris Agreement? It is time to act. When will Europe finally recognise the rights of nature, the planetary commons, the ecocides? You who talk to us about defending our way of life, I ask you: when will you defend a way of life compatible with our future? Responsible Europe is a Europe that respects planetary boundaries and living.

name: Sira REGO
text: – Madam President, the Amazon burns. The planet runs out of time. At this point, and with the serious ecological crisis, we need to act firmly. Some of the impacts of these fires have already been cited: loss of biodiversity, destruction of the forest to promote the interests of the meat industry, indigenous communities that lose their territory. And, moreover, we are seeing the incompetence of Bolsonaro and his far-right government, unable to deal with the problem seriously and responsibility and concerned only with spreading the cake among the oligarchies. However, with the help of EU trade policies. That is why it is not enough to allocate European funds, let alone allow a neo-phascist to manage them. We must bear the consequences of our economic model. A moment ago, the representative of the Council asked us for proposals. Here are some: the Mercosur paralysis, an agreement that is part of the problem; that we stop importing meat massively and sustaining models of production and consumption that exploit the planet's capacity. But above all, let us cease to be complicit in those who sow death.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: I'd like to report it now. We still have 20 requested speeches in this debate, which is very important, and it is important that we talk about this. We also have so many requests outside the speaking list, 12 paragraphs, that since we are lagging behind in the sitting, I cannot admit them all. In the interests of transparency, I now thought I would list those Members who will receive a speaking time outside the speaking list after the debate. They are members Arias Echeverría, Agius Saliba, Avram, Joveva, Kelleher, Chowns and Konečná. Unfortunately, the rest of you will be disappointed. That's all I can do about this right now.

name: Hildegard BENTELE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work she has heard from right now. The news and images from the Amazon are terrible; many people before me have already made this clear. When one considers that the forest is burning and being deforested on a large scale, not only in South America, but also in Russia, Canada and congo, and that even many forest areas in the EU are in a worrying state, then we in the EU must of course ask ourselves: what can we do to preserve these vital, essential CO2 storage facilities? My first answer to this is that the EU must speak with one voice. In the future, as with the negotiation of trade agreements, the EU will have to weigh all the weight of 28 Member States and show its face and profile when it comes to protecting forests. Secondly, we should make environmental and climate protection an integral part of our development cooperation and EU diplomacy. We are now at the beginning of a new legislature. A new Commission is taking up its work. And quite honestly, I am missing the topic of environmental and climate protection in the mission statements of Josep Borrell and Jutta Urpilainen. Climate protection must be international per se, and that is why a Green New Deal can not only be done within the EU, but we must push it forward worldwide and, in the case of forest protection, provide funds for certification, alternative acquisition opportunities and afforestation in the case of forest protection. In the coming weeks, let us seize the opportunity to align our new development aid instrument accordingly.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Madam President, the forest fires in the Amazon region have drawn our attention not only to the extent of the destruction of what is called one of the 'lungs of the planet', but also to the increasingly serious human rights violations in this region. We have witnessed an escalation of violence in indigenous territories and we cannot remain indifferent to the news of the murder of indigenous leaders, human rights activists and environmentalists. Example as the chief Emyra Wajãpi, murdered at the end of June, Dilma Ferreira da Silva, Claudionor Costa da Silva, here already mentioned, and so many others should serve as an alarm for what is happening. Threats, intimidation and harassment are increasingly common and must be determined ly addressed by the European Union. The announcements by Brazilian political leaders of the opening to a growing exploitation of the Amazonterritory by the agricultural and mining sectors have stimulated conflicts and disrespect for the basic rights and freedoms of indigenous peoples. The European Union must not - cannot - ignore its obligations as a global leader and should use the instruments at its fingertips in dialogue with governments to protect the forest, the environment, combat climate change and protect human rights.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The Amazon is on fire. It is an acute crisis and a concern for the whole world. The President of Brazil, Bolsonaro, has shown that he will not take the climate challenge and deforestation of the Amazon seriously. On the contrary, he has previously said that he wants to withdraw from the Paris Agreement in the company of Donald Trump, but protests from the outside world, including the EU, have made an impression. Do we really want to take responsibility for the climate? Do we want to work together to ensure that the Paris Agreement is complied with? If we want to save the Amazon, we simply have to use the best tools we have. The EU-Mercosur trade agreement is important both for us and for Brazil economically. But it also gives us a unique opportunity to both put pressure on and create incentives for the Brazilian Government to take climate responsibility. Modern trade agreements with clear requirements for sustainability are one of the very best and most effective tools we have. Let's use them.

name: Francisco GUERREIRO
text: – Madam President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, the data and facts are clear. The European Union is largely responsible for the destruction of the Amazon jungle. We are the largest importer of agricultural products from deforested areas and the second largest importer of Brazilian soybeans used in livestock feed in Europe. There is no denying that what we eat is devastating the Amazon and its indigenous communities. But another direction is possible if the Union has the courage to put its foot on the brake. So I question, Madam Commissioner, are you ready to freeze the agreement with Mercosur and halt imports of meat and soy from Latin America? We know that it is a difficult decision, but it is necessary to stop the agricultural lobby and to finally and definitely prioritize the protection of the biodiversity of the Amazon and indigenous communities.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, the production of beef is without question the biggest cause of deforestation in the Amazon, so it stands to reason that the quickest way to end deforestation in the Amazon will be to reduce demand for Brazilian beef. But now the EU wants to flood the European market with more South American beef every year through the Mercosur deal. You couldn’t make it up.  Nineteen per cent of all soy consumed in the EU comes from Brazil. Yes, there are restrictions on soy production expansion in the Amazon, but this has only served to increase pressure from cattle farming. Pasture land in the savannah has been replaced with soya bean plantations, and because of this, these beef farmers have moved to the Amazon.  It is estimated that nearly a quarter of total annual Amazon deforestation in recent years has been caused by these displaced beef farmers, so how in the name of God did the Commission come to the conclusion in March in its sustainability criteria for biofuels that soya bean production should not be designated a high risk factor for indirect land use change? It’s just madness.

name: Nathalie COLIN-OESTERLÉ
text: Madam President, through our trade we bear responsibility for these fires in the Amazon, because we import products from deforestation and forest degradation, including beef and soybeans. The European Union must not only make a strong speech, but also impose sustainable management of the forest by binding clauses in accordance with the Paris climate agreements. For, it must be remembered, there are no sanctions today for non-compliance. At a time of negotiations with Mercosur, this issue is absolutely crucial. We must also put in place this ecological barrier which we defended during the European campaign and on which President von der Leyen has committed, which we welcome. But how then can we promote this barrier, while moving forward on such negotiations? We must protect our consumers, support our industries, our farmers, protect the environment from foreign polluting producers. Today, however, the agreements negotiated with Mercosur do not meet these requirements. This actually makes us accountable for the situation in the Amazon.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, Dear Commissioner, I am pleased to see you again in this important debate. I am very much in agreement that across party lines in this European Parliament there is a unanimous outcry about what is happening in the Amazon. I therefore assume that unanimity can be sought and that the European Union must show its teeth in order to solve this problem. There are several ways, but one crucial way to deal with this is to drastically revise our trade policy, trade policy that actually takes the sustainable development goals and stops deforestation. There are two very important ways: you have the sustainability chapters, the TSD chapters that really need to become enforceable and become binding. But we in Parliament can also show that we have teeth, for example by saying before the discussion that deforestation must stop and the way human rights are treated in Brazil must stop. That must be the basis of a future trade policy. Let us sink our teeth into that in the years to come.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, the wave of fires that has been baited this year with the Amazon forest and its indigenous communities affects us all because of its human, environmental and climatic repercussions. Moreover, it is an economic aberration, because it seems to be confirmed that it is the result of a plan to promote unsustainable development. I would therefore like to value the Leticia Pact for the Amazon, signed on 6 September by Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Guyana, Peru and Suriname, which ratifies the commitment of these countries to the system of international treaties to protect the environment and especially the Paris Agreement. A movement that we must stimulate by verifying that prevention, extinction and reforestation policies are effective, supporting them only against results and preventing agricultural and livestock products whose production has damaged the Amazon, from entering any market and particularly in the Union. Credibility, in this case, means to primate values over interest.

name: Grace O'SULLIVAN
text: – Madam President, we all watched in horror this summer as the catastrophic fires raged through the Amazon, under the path of neglect and even perhaps the active encouragement of the Bolsonaro regime. None of us are blameless in this matter. Global demand for unsustainability, cheap and destructive beef production has driven the land clearance that is at the heart of the massive destruction. I endorse the resolution that has been put forward in response to this situation and I am happy that it is not shrinking from the issue of trade and the policies and politics that have led to the increase in deforestation recently. Trade deals with governments that violate the rule of law, that punish NGOs while encouraging illegal activities and that breach international agreements cannot be allowed to pass this House. There are arguments circulating with false narratives for the need for development clashing with the need to protect crucial ecosystems like the Amazon. These need to be rejected for the distraction that they are. We all know there are no jobs on a dead planet, but there are also few jobs on massive plantations, many under foreign ownership, designed to produce maximum short—term profit at the cost of the long—term health and well—being for the people of Brazil. I hope the Chamber will reject them and endorse the resolution in front of us.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against climate change must be taken on a global scale, which implies coordinated action. The forest is an essential element for this combat. Sustainability must be the key word, which also means solidarity. As far as the Amazon forest is concerned, we must not forget that its size is 5 million km2, 9 countries, it is not just Brazil, and if we talk about fires, we also unfortunately have them here in the European Union and we should be an example for the rest of the world. Fires that have even led, as in my country's case in 2017, unfortunately to the loss of more than 100 people in terms of human life. The European Union, in addition to example, must seek prevention - and that is the key - and it must cooperate, it must cooperate by funding programmes, funding funds so that, in the Amazon and other forests, there is respect for human rights, sustainability, which is a cause that concerns us all.

name: César LUENA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are actually facing a debate on the expoliancy of forests, forests, biodiversity.  And the Minister of the Council said so: leadership of the European Union. Let's not resign ourselves. Private interests, industry and agriculture interests can be reconciled with environmental conservation. It's sustainable development. Now, you were asking for ideas. I'll give you one. Follow the European Commission's forestry strategy, which says that there are some products that come from this authentic forestry expolium that we would not have to import, which must be restricted. Ladies and gentlemen, we're fighting a battle. This Parliament is waging a battle this afternoon against genuine denier predators. But we can win the battle with the leadership of the European Union. Without resigning ourselves and with coherence.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: – Mr President, the forest fires have also reminded us of the importance of the chapter on sustainable development contained in the Mercosur Agreement and of the Paris Agreement that is also included in the agreement. We really must ensure that the mercosur agreement is implemented in accordance with the principles of sustainable development and the agreed standards. We must create the conditions for trade that is acceptable to all parties. The EU can also set an example for Brazil. The recent Commission communication on deforestation shows that we in the EU are only increasing forest resources. It is due to sustainable forest management and the use of versatile wood. We can be very proud that our member states manage their forests mainly well and sustainably. However, the handling of forestry issues in this House is very fragmented and could use more coordination. Therefore, updating the forest strategy, for example, is more topical and important than ever before.

name: Pär HOLMGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Last week I had the opportunity to meet two representatives of the Huni Kuin tribe in the Amazon who had to watch their village burn down. Their fight against the fires must be our common struggle. The Amazon is still burning. At the same time, President Bolsonaro is threatening to leave the Paris Agreement and continue and even expand the devastation.  This devastation of the Amazon must be stopped now! It is one of the most sensitive parts of the entire climate system on our planet. The EU should not give priority to increasing imports of soya and meat when it affects indigenous peoples and rainforests. In the negotiations on a new major trade agreement, therefore, we must make clear tough demands on the Mercosur countries. What I would like to know from the Commission is how they can get these countries to choose from now on between acting to protect the rainforest or missing out on European trade?

name: Alexander BERNHUBER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Since the beginning of the year, 6,000 square kilometres of forest have been burned down in the Amazon. This corresponds to an area of about 8% of my own country, Austria. As you also mentioned, Commissioner, 80% of this rainforest deforestation area is already being used to expand agricultural production. This will create huge farms that are not comparable to our European farms. The link with Mercosur is obvious, and it is shameful that Europe is watching the rainforest deforestation system being supported here. We cannot expect to meet the climate targets in Europe while at the same time importing meat from Mercosur countries, when we European farmers actually produce enough regional products in sufficient quality and quantity. If these conditions of slash-and-burn continue to be followed by the Brazilian Government, I call for strong consequences and bans on the import of beef from Mercosur countries, as the Finnish Presidency has already proposed.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Amazon burns and, if the earth that produces 20 % of the oxygen we breathe burns, it also burns an immense heritage of cultures, peoples and biodiversity. Deforestation, as well as fires, are certainly caused by people, by leaders who endorse the exploitation of resources and people, an exploitation based on an old and wrong idea of capitalism, without sustainability that promotes the well-being of all. There is a phrase, an expression in the indigenous language that I cannot repeat, that speaks precisely of the "good living". Well, good living, that is, a harmonious relationship between man and creation, and this good life we should make our own, even in the policies to be re-thought of by the Union. And I ask myself, why should we not have the courage to review the Mercosur agreement as well in order to put more stringent environmental sustainability criteria in place? And why do we not have the courage to say that we cannot be environmentalists, as some say, with the forests of others, of countries that want to have a way of developing? This is also our problem and I think that Europe should contribute to a plan for reforestation.

name: Tilly METZ
text: Madam President, between 1990 and 2016, we lost 1.3 million square kilometres of forest. This corresponds to about 800 football fields per hour. This disaster is due to the global demand for food and feed. We import genetically manipulated soybeans by encouraging the massive use of pesticides to feed our animals. What is the European Commission doing? On the one hand, it proposes a strategy for forest protection and even reforestation, but on the other hand, the CAP encourages intensive agriculture and the massive importation of feed. The Commission is also proposing a free trade treaty, Mercosur, which will make the situation worse. The Amazon burned for weeks, on such an expanse that it could be seen from space. We also have our share of responsibility. Let us be consistent, stop deforestation products and stop encouraging President Bolsonaro to sacrifice the Amazon rainforest and its inhabitants to the agro-industrial sector.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, everyone here in this Chamber is urgently calling for measures for the sustainable management of the Amazon because, if the disaster exceeds 30%, the situation will not be reversible. Instead of continuing the sustainable management plan, which has existed since 2014, the Bolsonaro government has encouraged over-exploitation of land and is turning a blind eye to the disaster. In this context, the agreement between the European Union and Mercosur can be a powerful tool for the protection of Amazon forests. It is a fair trade agreement, it is an agreement linked to the Paris Agreement and in fact it admonies Brazil to reforest twelve million hectares. Fires, unfortunately, in the Amazon we have had many years now. But now, at least we have a means of pressure. And anyone who violates the Paris Agreement must also violate the Mercosur Agreement. However, we do not have pressure measures for Siberia or Africa or Indonesia. We need a comprehensive proposal for sustainable forest management and tools to promote it outside the European Union. Instead of exhausting the colleagues of the GUE Group for their sensitivity ... (The President removes the floor from the speaker.)

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, for the past few weeks, the world has watched in horror as massive fires engulf large sections of the Amazon, Siberia, Alaska, Greece – the list goes on. Against the backdrop of unprecedented climate change and deforestation at levels we have not seen before, the earth’s lungs are quickly filling with smoke. We have now moved from a climate emergency to a climate catastrophe, and the world deserves a better response than schoolyard political sniping games on Twitter. The entire system is flawed. Our habits and our throwaway society, coupled with populist political short—termism, will have tragic consequences on the lives and the health of our children and their children. When all the evidence shows us that the way we are consuming our natural resources on our planet is unsustainable, we have to have the courage to take the tough decisions we need. We did it with plastic. We managed to push through a ban of some of the worst products, but it is time to go further, and Europe can be the global leader in this. When Greta Thunberg, as the voice of her generation, asked politicians to panic, she was right and now it is up to us whether we panic by running into a wall or taking drastic action. That’s the choice we face.

name: Agnès EVREN
text: Mr President, the situation in the Amazon is catastrophic, but the scourge of deforestation is global, it is not just about the Amazon. Since July, for example, Indonesia has also been burning in unbearable silence. It is not only through trade agreements that we will fight this massive deforestation, let alone if they do not contain any binding measures, as with Mercosur. Let's broaden the debate. It takes years to conclude a trade agreement and put it into effect. We need to move very quickly. Development assistance is a more effective lever in the short term. It could be better used, especially as a means of putting pressure on states that turn a blind eye to deforestation. Finally, I would like to think of farmers who often have little choice but to spread their crops over the forest. Let us help them change behaviours, ensuring that virtuous practices provide them with a decent remuneration.

name: Jörgen WARBORN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Last summer we suffered from large forest fires in Sweden and the support from the Member States proved invaluable to us. Our Polish friends sent us 139 firefighters to the rescue. Just like forest fires around the world, it was a huge problem for humans, for animals and for nature. That's why I feel with the Brazilian people. But I also note that there was no campaign or debate in the world about stopping trading with Sweden, just because there was a fire in our forests. That is why it is wrong, as the left is now doing, to use this tragic disaster to stop the EU-Mercosur free trade agreement. So let me be clear. Blocking the free trade agreement will not put out any fires in the Amazon or improve the climate. On the contrary, the Mercosur Agreement binds Brazil and the other countries to respect and implement the Paris Agreement and to work towards sustainable forestry. We're going to use the trade as a carrot. Then we create sustainable development and prosperity through several jobs, through higher growth that makes both goods and services cheaper. I therefore call on all the governments of the Member States and colleagues in this House to contribute to ratification as quickly as possible.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: As Vice-President Hautala has already said, we have almost three times as many requests as planned for the following procedure of spontaneous speeches. We shall take into account seven requests to speak. Spontaneous speeches

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: – Mr President, I will start with some simple facts: the Amazon forest produces 20% of the world’s oxygen in our atmosphere. More than a million indigenous lives are currently in danger. Deforestation fires have burned the Amazon for decades; fires have increased by 85% under the current Bolsonaro Government. The Amazon is not the only region being destroyed. There are no ordinary fires; the destruction of the Amazon will rapidly accelerate global warming, increase the overall temperature of the planet, and destroy biodiversity and indigenous life within the forest. What are we doing while the Amazon forest burns to the ground? Are we just going to sit and watch in horror while our planet burns? No. We need to act, and the need to act was yesterday. I want to ask the Commission: what is the strategy here? What is EU doing to protect and tackle forest fires worldwide? What actions and financial support can be offered to stop and control these fires?

name: Pablo ARIAS ECHEVERRÍA
text: – Mr President, the European Union-Mercosur agreement is undoubtedly the best instrument available for the protection of Amazon forests. If the European Union really aspires to lead global efforts to combat climate change, it must certainly approve the European Union-Mercosur agreement. The protection of the Amazon rainforest belongs to all of us, as well as other forested areas in Africa, America, Asia and Oceania, as it contributes to several of the sustainable development goals set by the United Nations. I want to value the pact reached in the city of Leticia, in Colombia, by seven Latin American countries, including Colombia, Peru, Ecuador, Bolivia and Brazil, for the protection of the Amazon. However, I must say that President Macron's position, expressed during the last G-7 summit, is not appropriate because it is due to domestic policy issues that put many things at risk that have been achieved after twenty years of hard negotiation.
