The European Union-Mercosur agreement is an opportunity for all involved, not only in trade matters, but above all in environmental matters to comply with ... (The President withdrew the floor to the speaker.)

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Mr President, I have been hearing for some time about how the European Union must set an example in tackling climate change and how it is actually already playing a leading role in this.  All well and good, it is also true that we are on the right track, but the European Union cannot deal with what it wants to achieve on its own. Caring for the environment is a global problem and everyone has to be there.  That is why, in my opinion, not only the debate is key to Amazon, but the key actions are key. Brazil allows the destruction of the rainforest and, as long as that is the case, I cannot imagine the Member States of the Union ratifying the mercosur trade agreement.  I am not advocating sanctions – except as a last resort. But isn't this an extreme case? But let us watch the lungs of the world burn peacefully. The clear message of the Union must be that we care about what world we live in. And it can't just be a floss. The climate and nature are changing, and it is high time that people changed too. If we don't make it here, it's over.

name: Ellie CHOWNS
text: – Mr President, occasionally, an issue comes to public attention because it crystallises a big and complex issue in a way that hits home for all of us that we can all understand, and the fires in the Amazon are one such example. Yes, they’re not the only fires, yes, we need to plant more trees here in Europe, but concentrating on the fires in the Amazon brings home some really important issues for us all. People in Europe are passionate about the fate of the Amazon because we care about the climate crisis. We care about biodiversity and about the lives of indigenous people under threat. None of us is an island; we’re interconnected. Our choices here in Europe –consumption, trade policy – have an influence elsewhere in the world. Like many others, I’m fearful of the effects of the EU—Mercosur trade deal. I worry that narrow economic interests will trump concern for human rights and environmental protection. I’m not at all reassured by claims that the EU will somehow have more leverage than before over human rights and environmental protection after we sign the Mercosur trade deal. You only have to look at our record on this. It’s taken eight years to begin enforcement on the EU-Korea Free Trade Agreement. As it stands, the Mercosur deal is all carrot ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, it is not possible to play the unsained. We have been talking about deforestation here since 2017, when I presented my report on the subject and this Parliament adopted it. We've known for over a year that President Bolsonaro means the destruction of the rainforests. We also know that the European Union is part of the problem of deforestation, mainly because of its foreign trade policy. Therefore, faking shock is really not appropriate. It is appropriate to ask why we have waited so many years for the Commission's action plan against deforestation and why there is no resolution for today's debate. We're embarrassingly pretending to care, but that's about it. We must face up to the facts clearly – we are witnessing the destruction of forests and forests without which there is no life. And this isn't Notre-Dame. Let's put an end to the talk, put an end to deforestation, put an end to the devastating fires. And let's be part of the solution.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: – Mr President, we are here today, united from the left to the right, to condemn the dramatic fires happening as we speak in the Amazon rainforest. But why not stop crying and act – because today the European Union can do something concrete. We have trade tools to apply pressure and we should use them. The EU has just signed the Mercosur deal and insists that the deal does not lower environmental standards and that the precautionary principle ensures that the EU and the Mercosur countries can continue to protect the environment. Well, now we can see how Bolsonaro keeps his part of the deal. The EU says it is legally committed to respecting the environment and biodiversity. So, will it suspend this trade deal at least until the fires have stopped and the investigations into the causes of the fire are concluded? If the burning of the largest rainforest in the world is not serious enough, what does it take for the EU to suspend this trade deal and respect the sustainable chapter of it?

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Mr President, just to say at the outset that I welcome the opportunity, and I don’t think that this debate should be distilled down to an ideological debate about left or right. Let’s be honest, Bolsonaro is right-wing and is burning forestry, and Morales is left-wing and is equally burning forestry. We need to talk about it in ethical terms:  how we trade, and how we interrelate on the planet itself. And there is no point in saying it: it is profitable at the moment to burn the forests in Amazonia, it’s profitable to burn the rainforests across the globe, because we are trying to satisfy the commodity markets. Until such time as we accept this in Europe, and while we continue to import soy beans and coffees and beef from these parts of the world, they will continue to burn the rainforests.  Let’s be very clear: if the Mercosur agreement is ratified, it is Europe that will tear up the Paris Agreement, not the others. We have ethical, moral obligations to insist that any trade deals comply with the vigours and rigours of the Paris Agreement, and we should insist on that at the very minimum before we sign any Mercosur trade agreement.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I think we all agree that rain forests are a vital resource for the planet. This debate has reiterated that the ongoing fires in the Amazon basin are deeply worrying to all of us, all the more so against the backdrop of devastating fires raging in other parts of the world. Many have said – and I totally agree – that we have to tackle and we have to be concerned about all forest fires everywhere, whether it’s in Angola, Siberia, the Arctic, the subarctic region, central Africa, Europe, Southeast Asia or South America. All these fires once more underline the sense of urgency required in joining our forces to fight climate change. Forests are indispensable and are vital to our efforts to fight climate change. Protecting forests is a significant part of our and everybody’s responsibility to meet the commitments under the Paris Agreement.  Most of the speakers spoke about the EU—Mercosur trade agreement. In the trade and sustainable development chapter of the EU—Mercosur trade agreement, both the EU and the Mercosur countries, including Brazil, accepted an explicit commitment to effectively implement the Paris Agreement. Brazil’s nationally determined contribution under the Paris Agreement includes commitments on deforestation and reforestation. These are reinforced by private—sector initiatives, such as the Soy Moratorium or commitments by Brazilian meatpackers not to source meat from farms in recently deforested areas. In addition to provisions to promote sustainable trade and the trade agreement itself, let me note that the trade deal is part of an overall association agreement covering dialogue on human rights and cooperation in many fields, including the environment and climate change. It will provide the EU and, indeed, the European Parliament with additional instruments for dialogue and cooperation and help bring our markets and citizens closer together.  Many are concerned that we have to make certain that the commitments are there and that the commitments are honoured. The EU—Mercosur Agreement includes a comprehensive trade and sustainable development chapter containing legally binding commitments on environmental protection, as well as climate change, including a commitment to the implementation of the Paris Agreement. The Commission has a range of tools and mechanisms available to ensure that these commitments are respected. Where a party fails to comply with a commitment, we can resort to the dispute settlement mechanism, tailored to the specifics of labour and environment.  We trust and expect, but above all, we will ensure that Brazil will live up to its own commitments in the framework of the Paris Agreement, which includes a pledge by Brazil to reduce by 2025 its net greenhouse gas emissions by 37% compared to 2005 levels, and an action plan to stop illegal deforestation, including in the Brazilian Amazon. On our part, we also committed a pledge by the EU to reduce our domestic emissions by at least 40% by 2030.  Some MEPs commented that we should also tackle the demand side regarding the marketing of products associated with deforestation. A legislative framework preventing products associated with deforestation to reach the EU market is key. It is essential. The EU already has domestic regulations banning, for example, the sale of illegally harvested timber. The main objective of the regulation is to reduce illegal deforestation and give consumers better assurances about the products that they buy. When it comes to any future EU domestic measures relating to products associated with deforestation, let me refer to our recent communication on deforestation where we have announced a number of other measures in this regard. Those measures include reinforcing standards and certification schemes to identify and to promote deforestation-free commodities, exploring possible additional demand—side regulatory and non-regulatory measures to increase supply—chain transparency and to minimise the risk of importing products associated with deforestation and forest degradation, also, promoting forest-relevant considerations and activities to foster corporate social responsibility and responsible business conduct and, finally, establishing a stakeholder platform on deforestation allowing for discussions between government officials, NGO businesses, retailers, and so on.  To conclude, let me remind everyone that the final legal texts of the Association Agreement and its trade aspect will be submitted to the EU Member States and to the European Parliament for approval.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, to conclude I wish to thank you for this very useful debate on a pressing issue that concerns us all. We all share the view that we need to do our utmost to protect our forests. We need to improve the EU’s action on this matter and continue working towards honouring our international commitments.  Many of you referred to the Mercosur Trade Agreement. The trade agreement with Mercosur contains a robust trade and sustainable development chapter which lives up to the highest standards comparable to those in other modern agreements. The basic premise is that increased trade should not come at the expense of the environment or labour conditions; on the contrary, it should promote sustainable development.  The Mercosur Agreement contains a specific article on climate change committing the parties to effectively implement the Paris Agreement. There are also commitments on fighting deforestation. However, just like here in Parliament, discussions in the Council on the EU-Mercosur Agreement are still in an early phase. It is clear that sufficient time will be needed for a comprehensive examination of the negotiated agreement. It will be important for both of our institutions to have an honest debate on the agreement, based on facts.  I would also like to note that open, ambitious and rules-based trade policy which is value-based, sustainable and inclusive is a priority for the Finnish Presidency. Many of you also referred to the urgency of climate action. The time to act on climate change is now, not later. We believe that the EU can have an effect on others by setting an example. This is why it is crucial to agree on an ambitious target of climate neutrality in the European Union by 2050 as soon as possible.  We must preserve the Amazon rainforest for the generations to come. Huge damage has been done so far, which I deplore, but we need to focus on preventing further deterioration. We need to protect our forests in the Amazon and elsewhere because we need to protect our lives. Deforestation is a global challenge with many complicated aspects. For that reason cooperation within the Council configuration is an elementary part of successful work. The cooperation between the EU institutions is even more important and for that reason, we are all here today. Thank you very much once again for your active participation and for your attention.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171 OF the CRP)

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Writing. – Governments that favour the mass deforestation and burning of rainforests must also take into account the consequences. Public opinion in support of free trade with these countries may change. The fate of the Amazon rainforest affects not only Brazil, but the world. I therefore support the attention to the problem and the pressure on the Brazilian authorities.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – We express here all our solidarity with the Brazilian people and with the peoples of the other countries affected by the great amazonian fires, in particular with the populations that inhabit the Amazon Forest. These fires are a dramatic example of what can happen when, as in capitalist society, the goal of profit overlaps with elementary environmental and social concerns. The destruction of the Amazon has not begun now. Multinationals and other economic groups have long disputed the amazon's resources. This dispute finds expression in the economic, political and geostrategic planes, and involves the appropriation of land, raw materials, resources extracted from nature. Such objectives of appropriation and depredation of resources are found in the Brazilian Government, directed by Bolsonaro, ultraliberal programs that give free rein and enhance the health of large capital and economic groups of agro-business, which aim to sum up the great natural riches of the Amazon. The situation in the Amazon justifies international cooperation and aid in improving and more promptly dealing with the disaster. But this does not legitimize those who claim to favor plans and processes of economic dominance and, as well, ways of transferring costs to the peoples of the world of environmental degradation, erasing the responsibilities of the capitalist mode of production.

name: Giorgos GEORGIOU
text: Writing. – The "lungs" of our planet are burning and climate change is rapidly evolving into a climate crisis, leading us to an ecological nightmare. The Amazon is on fire because of financial interests. With the stamp of Bolsonaro's policies, the Amazon is sacrificed on the altar of profit in order to serve the interests of large local and foreign industries. The 40,000 fires caused this year in the Amazon were not an accident. It was the result of criminal policies. We demand the obvious. We call for the EU to take immediate initiatives to send aid to the rescue of the Amazon. Immediate measures should be taken in the EU to prevent and prevent illegal logging, arbitrary deforestation and the destruction and burning of forests. Let's leave the heavy-nosed statements. They don't do any good. We need drastic measures. We therefore call on the EU to immediately announce the allocation of a specific reforestation envelope to all Member States as an emergency. Because our planet, our home, is on fire, and we can't afford to fail!

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – The Amazon rainforests are on an unprecedented scale, with fires up by as much as 76% more than last year. Record-breaking fires that have increasingly been ignited deliberately, polluting rivers with toxic waste from illegal mines and invading indigenous areas to obtain mineral resources are destroying one of the world's largest tropical forests. It is important to continue and increase the work to preserve the rainforests, to ensure that the inhabitants and animals there are protected and that the use of natural resources is reasonable and not predatory. Serious steps must be taken to preserve the Amazon and also to extinguish the fires that are burning there. The EU must also contribute to this.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: in writing. – We are alarmed by the state and the recent spread of fires in the earth's two main lungs. On the one hand, the Amazon (the first lung on earth) has suffered a devastating wave of fires never seen before. These spotlights have increased by 83% compared to the same period in 2018. The main cause? Deforestation, which has also gained strong momentum with the current government. On the other hand, the second lung of the earth, the forests of the Congo basin, which recorded a total of 10,000 fire bulbs on the same dates.  These two continents on fire are a biodiversity sanctuary and are an essential tool in the fight against climate change. If the loss of the tropical tree cover continues, it will be impossible to keep warming below 2oC. We are concerned that governments, like Brazil's, have turned forest management policy around and undo all the progress the country had seen in recent years. Political irresponsibility and poor forest management pose a major threat to our ecosystems and our survival.

name: Sándor RÓNAI
text: Writing. The world has been struggling with forest fires more and more frequently in recent years. Let's remember California. This summer, Siberia and the Amazon basin suffered severe damage. However, we do not have to go outside the Union to find a similar tragedy. Recently, Greece and Portugal have had to make huge efforts to stop the flames, and this summer we had to continue the man-to-man struggle in the Canary Islands. It is terrible to see that while young people, celebrities, and ordinary people from all over the world are fighting climate change and the world is becoming more committed to stopping the climate catastrophe, there are still those who look the other way and wave away at the fact that 800 football fields of rainforest are dying every hour in the Amazon.  It is disappointing that, when it comes to contributing to the fight against global warming, there are governments that put their selfish political goals ahead of the lives of our children and grandchildren. Their political interests blind them so much that they don't realize they're digging all our graves. This is what happened when some Middle Eastern European leaders refused to commit to the 2050 carbon neutrality targets, or when, outrageously and cynically, the governing parties did not take part in the debate in the national parliament on climate change. A politician who waves at climate change is sentenced to death. We must do everything in our power to find the means by which we can fight climate change even without them.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. – After the meeting, we are rightly debating the situation in the Amazon. This is an area that describes itself as the lungs of the world (it produces 20% of the world's oxygen) and has a key role to play in managing climate change. Large-scale fires occurring there, on the other hand, have the potential to release large amounts of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. I would like to touch on this issue from the point of view of trade relations between the European Union and the MERCOSUR countries, namely Brazil. It is certainly a good thing that the proposed AGREEMENT between the EU and MERCOSUR contains measures to combat climate change. On the other hand, we have seen the Brazilian Government and the President approach a disaster of this size rather laxly. Also worrying is the fact that, under the current President of Brazil, deforestation in the Amazon has increased by 88% – regardless of fires. The draft agreement with MERCOSUR aims to develop common trade relations. It is clear that Brazilian producers need outlets. On the other hand, our farmers are rightly concerned about Brazilian production, which is massive and uses unacceptable methods. If this production were to be supported at the cost of destroying the Amazon rainforest, that would be absolutely unacceptable. We must look at the MERCOSUR agreement through this lens and demand clear guarantees that its implementation will not mean ruin for the lungs of the world and a reduction in the competitiveness of our farmers.

name: Monika VANA
text: Writing. Debates must at last be followed by action! We Greens very much regret that the European Parliament has not adopted a resolution on forest fires in the Amazon. The scale of the environmental disaster is clear: two weeks ago Mapu Huni Kuin from the Brazilian state of Acre warned us in the European Parliament: "The fires are destroying our livelihoods and our homes. We need the forest, it gives us freedom and our identity." At the political level, clear announcements are needed against Bolsonaro and a multilateral solution in South America to stop the forest fires permanently!

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. "The huge forest fires in the Amazon region, which have been going on for weeks, have rightly raised great international concern. It is particularly serious that the fires do not appear to have started accidentally, but have been started partly deliberately to clear the ground. Forests are vital to us for many reasons. They are vital from the point of view of biodiversity, climate protection and economic and social well-being. Brazil, too, must be made more committed through international agreements to the protection of valuable forests, sustainable forest management and the safeguarding of biodiversity. In future, we may have better instruments in place for this if the trade agreement reached in the summer on a preliminary political agreement between the European Union and the Mercosur region can be successfully implemented. I therefore believe that the agreement should not be rejected, even though, when the Brazilian leadership is returning, the Brazilian leadership has looked downright scandalously reckless. It is important to note that all new EU trade agreements, including mercosur, now include figures on sustainable development. It gives us the back seat to demand from our trading partners the maintenance, cooperation and dialogue of international agreements, including on environmental protection. When mercosur is discussed and worked on in the coming winter, it is really important to ensure that these objectives set out in the agreement are properly monitored and that they are also implemented in practice.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the security situation in Burkina Faso (2019/2812(RSP)).

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, over the past months we have seen a continued and dramatic deterioration of the security situation in Burkina Faso. I would like to start by expressing our solidarity with the people of Burkina. More than 200 people have been killed so far in 2019, including 60 victims in the last month. This insecurity climate puts more pressure on already overstretched social services. The number of internally displaced persons is now reaching 300 000 people, posing a serious challenge to the delivery of food, health or sanitation services, but also in terms of social cohesion. That Jihadist groups are now targeting both security forces and civilians, with a clear strategy to force local antagonism and create a circle of vengeance between different communities. They are trying to incite a war of religion in a country that has a long history of peaceful coexistence between faiths and communities. The European Union is today closer than ever to the people of Burkina Faso. The country is currently at the heart of our action in the Sahel. In the last seven years we have mobilised more than EUR 1 billion for development programmes in Burkina. High Representative Mogherini was in Ouagadougou over the summer, on the occasion of the fifth annual ministerial meeting between the EU and the G5 Sahel. During the meeting, she announced an extra EUR 138 million in support of the joint military force of the G5 Sahel, which has an important role in fighting terrorism and organised crime across the region. Our military and civilian missions in the Sahel are also working more and more across the region, alongside France’s Operation Barkhane. Coordination between security and development policies is one of the essential challenges, and this was one of the main messages that the High Representative delivered during her visit. We are glad that the G5 countries have committed to adopting an integrated, strategic framework precisely to synchronise their efforts on security and on development and to identify priority regions for their actions. The Government of Burkina has also extended the emergency plan for the Sahel to its eastern regions, which is a positive development. During her visit, Ms Mogherini called for urgent progress on security-sector reform. The fight against terrorism can only bear fruit if security forces respect the rule of law and human rights. This is the only way to build trust between state authorities and all sectors of the population. The recent national dialogue is an important building block for national cohesion. It is crucial that all ethnic communities in Burkina feel that they are part of a common national family. As the terrorists incite hatred and inter-ethnic tensions, the state should push in the opposite direction and invest in a shared sense of belonging for all its citizens. Security is vital but it is not the only answer to the challenges that the country is facing. Linking political, security and development issues will be more and more essential. Let me just mention that during her trip to Burkina, the High Representative also visited an EU-funded school, because education is the foundation of any country’s strength. International coordination is also crucial and the EU is willing to engage even more with the whole region. This is the reason why we took the opportunity of the Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) extraordinary summit on terrorism in Ouagadougou last Saturday to discuss with countries of a wider region how they can contribute more to counteract terrorism and how we can coordinate our respective actions. Since 2015, a peaceful country like Burkina Faso has had to face unprecedented violence. We Europeans have stepped up our support to stop this escalation, to stabilise a crucial region for our own security and to help the people of the Sahel take their future into their hands. We will continue to be a strong partner for Burkina and for its people.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. The mass-killing terror group Islamic State is pursuing a new strategy after its retranch in the Middle East. Let's be clear and clear. Today, the caliphate is expanding its wings in the sahel, which is in a weak security situation, and burkina faso is considered a bridgehead in this process. In Mali, Niger, Chad and the bordering Region of Burkina Faso, 1.2 million people now need urgent humanitarian assistance due to religious and ethnic conflicts. Nearly 500 people have been killed in Islamist terror attacks in Burkina Faso since 2015. These targets included city centres, army buildings, embassies, and educational institutions. Almost 2,000 schools, I repeat, had to be closed, causing 300,000 pupils to fall out of education.  In 2019, attacks with a specific religious hue increased dramatically. Christian communities are at particular risk. In February, terrorists shot dead Spanish Salasian monk César Fernández. A total of 57 Christians have been killed in attacks on churches this year. From Europe, we must help the region to preserve what we have heard before, ethnic and religious diversity. For a good solution, we need to see that churches have a crucial social and security role. I think it is essential that the European institutions must end extreme neutrality, on whose behalf we regularly, systematically, together ignore attacks on the denominations. We need to understand that the persecution of religious communities, such as large numbers of Christian denominations, leads to the dismantling of the social structure and the increase of emigration. After all, without safety, there is no sowing, no reaction, so people migrate. I know it's simplistic, but that's the way it is.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the group, Mr President, since 2015, as you said, extremist groups have been proliferating in Burkina Faso, with increasingly numerous and increasingly violent attacks. This Sahel region is particularly vulnerable in terms of security, and the G5 Sahel is obviously useful in combating these armed groups. But, as President Kaboré said, Burkina Faso is also vulnerable by its poverty. Fighting terrorism is not just about the military response, but about robust strategies that are development strategies. It is in this context that Burkina Faso has taken measures to protect production sectors, such as the production of food oil or sugar which, when produced by The Burkinabe, produce employment and are cheaper for Burkinabe. So what is the union's coherence when it promotes agreements such as the free trade agreement with West Africa, which destroys local employment and generates poverty for local populations, and then sending military contingents to fight Boko Haram? Wouldn't it be smarter, more coherent, more structuring to ensure partnerships that protect local economies rather than weaken them? Let us not forget that agriculture accounts for 82% of Burkina Faso's labour force. It is with free trade agreements that we destroy Burkina's agriculture and thus 82% of the working population. I think it is time for the European Union to review the economic partnerships it has with Africa, so that it can really have a development policy on the substance and not just on the protection of security and military action.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the The situation in Burkina Faso is an excellent example of how our policy in the fight against Islamist extremism has failed in Africa, in the Middle East. I think it is probable that the chaos that is now raging in this country could lead to mass migration if the population seeks security– whether in neighbouring countries or in Europe. Burkina Faso was a peaceful country; It is now being overrun by al-Qaeda and Boko Haram extremists, inlanded from Mali, fighters trained in Afghanistan and armed with weapons from Libya. Initially, the killing in Burkina Faso was arbitrary, it was terror against the civilian population, but now the killing is more targeted: they are attacks on Christians. Indeed, for example, it was possible to conduct interreligious marriages, anyone wearing a crucifix can now be killed, churches are attacked and burned down. We cannot stand idly by as another country is cleansed by Christians. We must take measures to stop this dangerous ideology of Islamism.

name: Assita KANKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the dress I am wearing was made by a girl in Burkina Faso. When we were her age, we had so many dreams. Who doesn’t, when one is 20 years old? But what future is being shaped for her, on her motorcycle in a village in Burkina Faso, or for our kids here in a global world where Jihadism is allowed to grow here and there? As the world looks away, Burkina Faso – my country of birth, where I played and ran barefoot in the then safe fields – is sinking far away in Jihadist violence today, after so many other places. Didn’t the world look away too long when the same problems occurred in Iraq or in Syria? Islamic State, Al Qaeda, Boko Haram and other Jihadist terror groups are now growing up again in this area. In the meantime, there are plenty of meetings, but isn’t it about time for more action and concrete results?  The impact of the growing insecurity is a very concrete fact in the daily lives of people like that girl. School doors are more and more often barred by violence, leaving them without the education they need and with the increased risk of recruitment by armed groups, exploitation by human traffickers, abuse by child marriage and teen pregnancy. The number of displaced grew from 50 000 to 300 000 in less than a year. Health centres are closed. Freedom of the press was also affected by a legal ban on reporting on military operations. Businesses, including Western ones, move out – I just spoke to a business leader yesterday in Brussels. We need less meetings and more actions and results for the girl I just told you about.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, the reports coming in from Burkina Faso are extremely worrying. In this country, and in neighbouring countries, the humanitarian and security situation is deeply degraded. We are witnessing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis with 1.5 million people in vulnerable situations and in need of urgent humanitarian assistance. Thousands of displaced people and more than 300,000 children are without access to the school as the establishments have been closed for safety reasons. Terrorist attacks have claimed hundreds of lives in recent months. The government has tried to circumscribe Islamist terrorist groups to the north and east of the country, on the borders with Mali and Niger, so as not to allow its action to spread to the rest of the country, but the action has been criticized for the uncoordinated and ineffective way it has been done. The fight against terrorist networks, which spread chaos and harass civilian targets in a cross-border and indiscriminate manner, must mobilize the governments of the affected countries, but it does not dispense with clear solidarity from the international community. It is crucial that the Government of Burkina Faso strengthens counter-terrorism actions and that the European Union, as it has done, remains steadfast in its support in order to ensure peace and security ... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker).)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, almost 300,000 displaced people, 2,000 closed schools, Christians or teachers whose only crime is to teach in French targeted. This is the tragic reality of a Burkina Faso plagued by Islamist terrorism, with the key to a risk of famine.  Who's to blame? The sacrifice last May of Cédric de Pierrepont and Alain Bertoncello painfully reminds us of France's commitment to the fight against terrorism since 2013.  But as a summit was held in Ouagadougou on Saturday, it is urgent that the aid pledges, especially from the 2018 Brussels conference, are finally honoured at European and global level and meet the needs of local armies in equipment and training.  On the economic front, I welcome the region's ambitious solar electrification project. Energy and road infrastructure, support for pastoralism, the economic challenges in Burkina Faso and the Sahel are immense. The response we will provide depends, for us Europeans, on a large part of our security and migration future.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Minister, i would like to thank you very much for Burkina Faso has been the site of more frequent and bloody attacks for four years – mainly jihadists – on clerics, especially Christian, but also Muslim. Half of the 20 million inhabitants live below the poverty line and cannot spend more than the equivalent of one dollar on their livelihood. With the help of the Polish government only in 2018 – we believed that it was necessary to reach directly with humanitarian aid to the poorest and those who suffered as a result of the actions of the jihadists – we built more than sixty social housing for the poorest families living in extreme poverty. We believe that, in addition to the actions that you have presented, the right action is to provide even more humanitarian aid on the ground for these people. And these efforts by the European Union should, in my opinion, be increased along the lines of those countries that are helping directly on the ground. And thank you for today's debate. She is extremely important from the point of view of danger and those conditions in which people live in Burkina Faso.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first I would like to stress that this discussion was very relevant for our current and future actions. I would like to thank the honourable Members for their interventions. The EU has built a very high profile in the Sahel where we have really succeeded to implement an integrated approach as an illustration of how global strategy. Next week High Representative Mogherini will have the opportunity to share these achievements in the margins of the UN General Assembly during a special event on Mali and Sahel. As coordination remains an important challenge, I will take this opportunity to welcome the recent G7 Partnership on Security and Stability in Sahel initiative as a contribution to support an integrated approach based on long-term vision and to avoid overlap. As a follow-up to the recent contacts we have had with our local counterparts and, based on today’s debate, be reassured that we cannot, and we will not, leave Burkina Faso alone in facing the challenges the country is confronted with.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on current developments in the political situation and the implementation of the peace process in Colombia (2019/2813 (RSP)).

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, three years ago, Colombia demonstrated to the world that even the longest and most violent of conflicts can come to an end. No one imagined that building peace would be easy but, three years on, the great majority of Colombians would never go back to the dark years of their country’s history.  High Representative Mogherini was in Colombia last week and she saw a country that looks forward, not backwards. President Duque has confirmed his willingness to keep implementing the peace deal. The leadership of the FARC as a political party and the vast majority of former fighters remain committed to the agreement. It is true that a small group of FARC dissidents have decided to take up arms again. We have strongly condemned this announcement because more violence is simply not the answer to the challenges that the country is facing. But we must not forget that this is only a small group of dissidents. This doesn’t mean that we do not see the challenges the peace process is facing. The killings of local leaders, human rights defenders and ex-FARC members are alarming and unacceptable. As the local and regional elections next month approach, we also see assassinations of candidates.  The High Representative has welcomed the actions taken by the Government to ensure protection of those under threat, to bring the perpetrators to justice and to dismantle these criminal networks. But most importantly, she also offered the European Union’s practical help. We are complementing government efforts through support to civil society, and have supported a special investigation unit in the Prosecutor’s Office and, together with the EU Member States, the campaign ‘Defendamos la vida’ All in all, this was the main message that she delivered to the Government and the people of Colombia: the European Union is with you. We want to help Colombia win the peace.  During her visit to Bogotá, the High Representative announced a number of measures to step up our support to the peace process. She met with the top officials in the three main institutions of the transitional justice system: the Truth Commission, the Search Unit for Missing Persons and the Peace Court. She announced EUR 4.5 million in support for the Truth Commission, which adds to our support for the Search Unit, and we are also planning to support the Peace Court. So far, the EU has invested around EUR 645 million over these last years to support peace in Colombia, including through the creation of a specific Trust Fund. The European Union is also the largest foreign investor in Colombia, with a special focus on sustainable development in the areas that were most hit by the conflict. On top of this, the High Representative also announced a new package to support Colombian solidarity towards refugees and migrants from Venezuela. We are putting an extra EUR 30 million on top of the EUR 120 million already invested.  There are now 1.4 million refugees and migrants from Venezuela who have found refuge in Colombia. Columbia’s generosity in welcoming and hosting these people sets an example to the region and to the world. However, to praise is not enough. Columbia and the countries from the region need more international support and the European Union is doing its part, leading the way among the international community.  The Colombian people know that they can count on the continued commitment and support of the EU in their daily work to win the peace. Since the peace deal was signed, the European Union and its Member States have invested EUR 1.5 billion in support of peace in Colombia. The people of Colombia are showing an amazing courage and perseverance in seeking the mediations that are essential to build a truly inclusive and peaceful democracy. We believe in them. Europe believes in Colombia and we will keep supporting all of Colombia’s peace builders.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Madam Representative of the Council, the implementation of the peace agreement with Colombia requires a long-term vision. It is, of course, a path full of difficulties and constant risks. That is why we need this vision and that horizon in a long perspective. I would like to stress the importance of the European Union's financial support, in particular that aimed at the areas of reintegration and rural development, and I also welcome the announcement by the High Representative of a new programme to continue to financially support those who have decided to leave arms and have been firmly maintaining that commitment. On the other hand, as the Colombian Government is doing, it is essential to strengthen measures to ensure the security of political and social leaders who are now being threatened and to bring forward and to justice those who violate peace and the law. Colombia has our full support. It is a very important trading partner for the European Union and, of course, an essential ally in the fight against climate change and the additional protection of the environment. The Security Council and the High Commissioner hem have said ⸻ and I also believe that⸻ despite all the difficulties, the implementation of the agreement is progressing. He moves forward and he does it solidly. From here I would like to congratulate and publicly acknowledge the enormous effort that President Duque and his Government are making. Colombia counts and will continue to count on all our commitment. In conclusion, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, I would like to draw attention to an important matter which you must deal with with the High Representative, who is not in this House today. Yesterday, the dialogue facilitated by Norway with a new ruse by Maduro, which has had only one insignificant faction of the opposition, ended in Venezuela. It was said that if that happened there would be sanctions. It's time to make that decision. It is time to increase sanctions against this corrupt regime that relentlessly violates human rights. If that were the case, the Mogherini period would certainly not be a bad legacy.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I think it is very opportune for us to meet here in the European Parliament today to recall and underline our absolute support for the peace process. We do it now that we start the legislature; we do it now that the high representative has been in Colombia, sending this message, reinforcing this message; and we do it now too because we see with concern things that are happening in Colombia: difficulties in the implementation of peace agreements and backward steps that some want to take with the return to violence. We want to shed light on the difficulties in implementing a very complex process, something we recognize: the need to provide security to social leaders in the country; the need for budgetary support; the need for land restitution and also the implementation of transitional justice, a central element of peace agreements. To do this, the Government of Colombia has our support, but we need to take steps forward and remind Colombian society that this long and complex path has no turning back.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, the return of a FARC mini-resistance to armed activity should encourage us to redouble the efforts and support we, from the European Union, are offering to Colombia's peace process. Despite the difficulties in its implementation, Colombia today works to ensure that nearly fourteen thousand former guerrillas complete their return to ordinary civilian life. In the face of the killings of this and other groups, which must cease and be thoroughly investigated, there is already a protection plan that must replace the measures so far insufficient, for them and for human rights activists and journalists. Its content and early results I hope will certify that there is, on the part of the authorities, a sincere commitment to correct a problem on which the credibility of all actors depends. Colombia is also better today because, in the diagnosis of the problem and in the measures to solve it, there is a social pillar, a package of measures that articulates the 2018–2022 Plan for Equity, which is underevirated previously separate actions in various programmes and attacks one of the roots of conflict: poverty and inequality. 36% of Colombia's area housed more than three million multidimensional poor people and two and a half million victims at the beginning of the process, who added chronic public service neglect to their status. Correcting this inequality and fostering sustainable and cohesive development is another key to the success of the process. The output is complex. Unforeseen situations are added to it, such as the mass exodus of Venezuelans fleeing the Maduro regime, on whose territory farC dissidents appear to take refuge. That is why, more than ever, the European Union's political, financial and human support for peace in Colombia must be redoubled. In the European Union we know about rural development, public-private partnerships, mediation. Continuing to provide this and other useful knowledge and learning from this experience is the best complement to the trust fund, diplomacy and bilateral cooperation programmes, which make the Union's words of support for peace in Colombia fact.

name: Diana RIBA I GINER
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the human rights situation in Colombia has worsened in recent times. According to the Somos Defensores programme, 155 human rights defenders were killed in 2018 and 25 in the first quarter of this year. Colombia is also the second most dangerous country in the world for environmental activists, all in a climate of impunity and increased internal displacement. So, and under the responsibility of the European Union as a participating player in the peace process in Colombia, can the Commission confirm that it will keep its special representative? When and how often will the Commission convene the human rights dialogue between the European Union and Colombia? From the Verts/ALE Group we believe it is also imperative that the European Union support mechanisms such as Special Justice for Peace and the extension of the mandate of the United Nations representative for human rights in Colombia, which will expire next October. Finally, we believe that greater transparency is needed in monitoring European funds in Colombia, which should be subject to human rights in the country.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: ECR Group. – Mr President, we all agree that Colombia is currently in urgent need of help. It needs urgent help not only because there is a part of the FARC that has broken the ceasefire, that have been withdrawn and are protected in Venezuela and that will try to return to open terrorism, but also because there are all THENs, which is another of the terrorist organizations. They are in Venezuela, they dominate, they control several states in Venezuela. They're protected there. They participate in the exploitation of gold that is causing devastation in the Orinoco, with indigenous tribes largely fleeing to Colombia as well, adding to that immense exodus that has gone to Colombia and which is also a factor of destabilization and concern. There are now more than 1,400,000 Venezuelans in Colombia, there are 4,200,000 or 4,300,000 Venezuelans fleeing Maduro's criminal regime, and I think it's time to support Colombia, to support the Government of Colombia, to persecute criminals and, of course, to also put pressure on those who really have something to do with Colombia's destabilization , who are in Venezuela and who are also in Havana, where Mrs. Mogherini has been last week, giving a speech in support of the communist regime, to the communist dictatorship, which was a disgrace. The pressure on Havana and Caracas is also critical to Colombia's stability.

name: Manu PINEDA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini has just returned from Colombia and knows full well that the Duke's Government deliberately fails to comply with the Havana peace agreements. The delivery of land to the peasants has not occurred. Multinationals and landowners continue to violently displace the peasant population, relying on narcoparamilitary groups. The substitution of illicitly used crops has been paralyzed and the leaders of these programmes are being killed. And the ex-guerrilla reintegration program is not being implemented. But the most worrying thing is that the Duke's government has decided to end the Special Jurisdiction for Peace, and this is causing a trail of deaths: more than 700 social leaders and more than 150 former guerrillas have been killed since its signing; and, at the moment, in the midst of the election campaign, more than 30 candidates have already been killed. Despite everything, the FARC is complying. The only guarantee for non-repetition of conflict and peace is the effective implementation of the agreements. The European Union must require the Government of Colombia to also comply and condition any type of economic, trade or political cooperation on such compliance.

name: Robert ROWLAND
text: – Mr President, I declare a personal interest in connection with Colombia, given that my third son has got a Colombian godfather, as well as having two friends who are sporting heroes: Robert Farah and Juan Sebastian Cabal, who have both won a back-to-back in the men’s doubles in tennis.  Another great achievement delivered three years ago was President Santos, who signed the peace accord with the left wing terrorist militia group known as FARC (Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia). After decades of violence, it took real courage and leadership to bring FARC to the political process and give them ten elected seats in Congress. We now see a peace agreement under threat as elements of the FARC renege on the accord and call for a new armed struggle. Aided by the thug Maduro in neighbouring Venezuela and funded by narco—trafficking, there is a real danger that Colombia could lurch back into the dark days of the past, so it is now imperative that President Duque remains resolute and does not buckle to the threats of renewed violence from FARC. Of one thing I am certain, though: the EU has no right, moral authority or treaty obligation to interfere in the affairs of Colombia. It is an independent sovereign state, and EU foreign policy mission creep is neither necessary nor desirable.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by pointing out that the journey of the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, to Bogota last week has seemed very useful to me. I believe that the European Union must continue to express its solidarity clearly in these difficult times for Colombia. Difficult for the neighborhood with Venezuela, which has experienced an exodus of more than four million people fleeing the Maduro regime. Colombia is home to the largest number of displaced persons, as has already been said, almost one and a half million. This migratory pressure will be reinforced by the recent establishment of visas by Chile, Peru and Ecuador. That is why I welcome the mobilisation of the New Aid of the European Union, but it is only thirty million euros aimed at identifying migrants and their socio-economic integration. I hope this amount increases. More international humanitarian aid is needed. At the moment, humanitarian aid from the United States is greater than that of the entire European Union— to Colombia, I am referring. On the other hand, it has also been said, it is very worrying that a small group of guerrillas, led by Iván Márquez, recently announced their intention to return to arms. This initiative is dangerous and totally wrong, especially as the peace process is progressing, is making significant progress and already has almost twelve thousand people in the phase of active reinstatement. There is the new support of the Security Council just yesterday, or the statements of leader Timochenko himself, the leader of the FARC, who said yesterday in a Spanish newspaper that the peace process is irreversible. Well, both the European Union and the rest of the community — and I am done, President — must continue to support Colombia in the face of the many serious challenges. A friendly country with which in recent times we have greatly strengthened our ties.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, the European Union and Colombia have engaged in a political dialogue in favour of human rights and the peace agreement. Despite some improvements, which we have highlighted today, the situation of human rights defenders is alarming today in Colombia. Since the signing of the peace agreement, 462 community leaders and 164 environmentalists have been killed by paramilitaries. Of the killings, civil society reports that only 8% of them have been prosecuted in Colombia. In 2016, a trust fund was set up with the European Union. The first question is: among the projects that have been funded by this fund, can the Commission tell us which ones are specifically aimed at the issue of protecting human rights defenders? The second question concerns the trade agreement with Colombia, which provided for a human rights assessment mechanism: where are we now in relation to this assessment?

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, the 2016 deal brought fragile peace to Colombia, a peace that is more and more under threat. Iván Márquez’s video was the most recent blow. While most leaders of the FARC condemned this return to war, we cannot underestimate the potential risks. Venezuela is another thorn to stability in Colombia. Not only is the crisis in Venezuela exerting pressure, with more than 1.4 million migrants fleeing over the border, but it also constitutes a safe haven for guerrillas to operate. The EU has been committed for decades now to supporting a peaceful solution in Colombia. The Colombian Government needs our support now more than ever to continue implementing the peace agreement and we need to continue to actively find a solution to the crisis in Venezuela, which is clearly having spill-over effects in the region.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, three years ago we concluded the peace agreement in Colombia. Today we regret the continuation of violence. In these three years more than 500 human rights defenders, 175 ex-combatants and family members and several political leaders have been killed. We regret that some FARC members, three years later, take up arms, but we also denounce the Colombian government's unwillingness to implement the peace agreements. Not only have paramilitary groups not been dismantled, but allegations of their ties to the Government and the Army have even increased. While agribusiness entrepreneurs are favored, land reform remains paralyzed. From the European Union we are giving millions to support the implementation of unevererated agreements. Where are the results? What has been done, for example, to dismantle paramilitary groups? Our commitment to peace requires ending political violence, implementing agreements and resuming negotiations with the ELN. Without guarantees, there will never be peace.

name: David BULL
text: – Mr President, Colombia has been in a state of continual conflict since before the 19th century, involving many parties with vested interest. Therefore, the revised peace deal brokered in 2016 between the Colombian state and FARC is extremely welcome. FARC was made to cease parliament military activity and became a mainstream party. But the legitimisation of one group has left a power vacuum; other militant groups and factions have emerged keen to exploit the gap in the market, particularly in cocaine. It is estimated by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime that there has been a year-on-year rise of 31% in cocaine production, estimated to be worth USD 2.7 billion. This provides almost unlimited capital for these groups, further entrenching their positions, provoking further conflict and crime in the region. So the revised peace deal has not brought peace. It has merely removed one group and replaced it with others. As a medical doctor, I know the cocaine industry has a very real impact on people’s lives, not just in Colombia or South America but here in Europe too. So we must find permanent solutions and revisit drug policy to tackle this exponential growth.

name: Leopoldo LÓPEZ GIL
text: – Mr President, the European Union must be involved in the threat posed by the return to armed struggle by a split of the FARC guerrillas. The peace process, which has been at the heart of this Union's commitment to Colombia, is the only way to resolve this conflict that has jeopardized the stability of this region. It is Venezuela's dictatorial regime that offers support and encouragement to these guerrillas. This fact has been well denounced by the Colombian authorities. This dictatorship has made more than four million Venezuelans have to leave their country, a figure that increases daily, and already about two million have settled in Colombia. That country has taken care of supplying health, housing and food needs to people who have been forced to emigrate. That is why I welcome Mrs Mogherini's offer last Thursday to President Duque to provide financial aid to programmes that facilitate the integration of these migrants and promote the peace process and agreement through the reintegration of guerrillas. The source of the crisis affecting Colombia must be paused. That is why the European Union must already apply strong sanctions to human rights violators in Venezuela, who are the true destabilizers of this region. Mrs Mogherini said that if she did not see concrete results after the Barbados negotiations, the European Union would impose them without a dilation. Colombia needs and must stop suffering from the collateral damage caused to it by the Maduro Government.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, this Parliament has strongly supported the peace process that has begun after decades of civil war in Colombia, precisely in order to guarantee respect for and protection of human rights in the country. However, the news that has been reaching us lately is not encouraging. After a period of reduction in violence, there has been a increase in attacks, human rights violations, acts of discrimination and serious acts of violence against women. In the last year alone, 2018, there were about 350 children who were victims of malnutrition and diseases, although treatable. Children are the most vulnerable in crisis situations such as the one colombia is experiencing. As the European Union, therefore, we must use all the resources, all the instruments at our disposal and the agreements reached to defend peace in Colombia, to guarantee respect for human rights, security, justice and social equity and to give children a better future throughout the country.

name: José Ramón BAUZÁ DÍAZ
text: – Mr President, we all agree that the priority must be the safety and well-being of our brother Colombian people. In this sense, we must take into account and well present a matter which we must not set aside, which is memory. Ensuring peace in Colombia cannot and should not serve as an excuse, under any circumstances, to rewrite history, nor to whiten terrorists. Only with justice will we ensure that peace is guaranteed. The signing of the peace agreements, unfortunately, has not meant the end of decades of suffering from terrorism, and this is said by someone who has unfortunately lived in a country that has suffered in its own flesh the attacks and pain of the victims of terrorism. That is why we ask you, and I personally ask Mrs Mogherini, not to confuse, not to think that this is a conflict between two sides, quite the opposite. This process must have exclusively, as a basis, the resignation, the surrender of the murderers to the killed. This is very important that Mrs Mogherini understands.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, the situation of non-compliance with the peace agreement in Colombia and the resurgence of repression and persecution, such as the wave of hundreds of murders of social and political leaders and activists, including former members of the currently demobilized FARC and their families, takes on dramatic contours. The non-implementation of the peace agreement by the Colombian State, in particular with regard to the disarticulation of far-right paramilitary groups and the elimination of the statute of impunity enjoyed by them, is a determining factor in the worsening political and social situation in Colombia and the violation of the guarantees and democratic rights of the Colombian people that compromise peace. It is time to demand respect and full implementation of the agreement signed in 2016 in Havana, and its fulfillment, ending the campaign of violence and oppression. It is time to meet the just and legitimate aspirations and demands of the Colombian people for democracy, social justice and peace.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, political relations in the north of South America are uncertain. In Venezuela, a dictator who tries to export his supposedly blessed regime to neighbouring countries such as Colombia reigns. A peace agreement has been reached in Colombia with the FARC insurgents, but several FARC leaders, stirred up by Venezuela, want to fight again. That would mean that the entire narco industry would also be back in high gear, because the FARC was living off the drug revenues. It is very important that we in the European Union support the efforts of Emilio Archila. That is the man who must implement the peace agreement to prevent us from returning to death and violence. However, too many Colombian farmers are still waiting for money that was promised to them to compensate for sowing alternative crops. What can the High Representative do to improve and support that?  It is of strategic importance for the European Union to balance the precarious relations in Latin America, so commitment to peace in Colombia and, above all, to curbing the devastating effects of narco-industry, an industry that runs into the millions here in Europe. Think of the people who are unfortunately addicted. But also think of the many violence associated with this. The violence and the drug wars that also occur in our European cities such as Amsterdam. That is what we are talking about when we talk about peace in Colombia.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Mr President, 260,000 dead, 83,000 missing, 7.4 million displaced, are the estimated black figures of 50 years of conflict in Colombia, which came to an end three years ago with a peace agreement and to which the European Union has made an important contribution. We can't go back. Colombia can't go back. That is why the recent announcement of a minority's return to armed struggle is a cause for great concern for all of us in the face of the threat of destabilisation in the country and the region. The peace agreement is not a point of arrival, but the beginning of a collective construction where everyone's effort is needed in the political and social integration of combatants and in pursuing higher development goals, promoting access to transitional justice, respect for human rights and activistaction. In view of the situation in Colombia, the European Union must continue to support and monitor the implementation of the peace agreement, as well as in the current government's demand for compliance. Dialogue and political action are the only avenues for progress and peace we all want.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: – Mr President, since we welcomed the signing of the peace agreement in Colombia, not only have the agreed commitments – commitments that led to the end of one of the world's oldest guerrillas – been implemented, but we are experiencing a serious step backwards in that development. Part of that guerrillas—the FARC—have decided to return to arms. The rulers are also being faithful to their commitment to erode the peace process, an element that is precisely reinforced by the dissent of the FARC. Of course, we must continue to support - all Members have said this - in the European Union the process. The minister said she needs international support, but she also needs political will in the country; a political will that cannot be replaced by a financial injection. They have commented - I will not insist – on the importance of Colombia's stability in the rest of the region, because in the end we talk about Colombia and we always talk about Venezuela and I do not want to insist on it. But the European Union has to review and update its position in Colombia, because things are happening that were not planned in the programme of our work there. And I believe that, in the first place, what the European Union has to do is to appoint a new person as soon as possible to represent us in the peace process and to continue eamon Gilmore's work. Because I think this kind of fact is how our interest is demonstrated.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, the 2016 peace agreement created real hope for Colombians and it was a great achievement, but violence remains rife. Human rights activists and trade unionists are still assassinated every year with impunity. The Colombian Government’s policy of greater militarisation and a piecemeal approach to the peace agreement’s implementation is also endangering the fragile peace process, and we have a role to play and we must play it. We must keep a special representative for the peace process and support the extension of the mandate of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights in Colombia. We have direct leverage through the human rights clauses within our free-trade agreement with Colombia and we must use them, and we must also boost our support for transitional justice and engage the Duque administration towards full truth and reconciliation. Without more international engagement, there can be no peace in Colombia and we can’t shy away. We have to engage with all the tools that we have at our disposal. This peace agreement is too important.

name: Ibán GARCÍA DEL BLANCO
text: – Mr President, the peace agreement is just that, a peace agreement. It is an agreement between two different and this is not a surrender, as some part of the right of my country has not just understood— as I have just heard here. And what it's all about, it's true, it's about fulfilling what was set out in the peace agreement. It has not been easy for a country with hundreds of thousands of dead, with a great history of violence and hardship, and it will not be easy in the future, no matter how political will there is, to finally reach an agreement. Someone has said it here: the peace agreement was a starting point, but it was not the final agreement. However, I believe that this Parliament and the Union and the Commission and the high representative who is coming have to take into account that there is a humanitarian emergency situation as well, which has to do with the refugees who are moving from Venezuela and that it has to do with the closure of the borders around, and for what the country , Colombia, it also needs humanitarian aid, for the attention at this time and for the attention of what will come in the future, because it does not seem that this jet of people who are crossing the border will end. We must be extremely demanding with these additional funds that are devoted, with the aid that continues to be devoted with all the will to the peace process.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Mr President, I wish we had a peace process in Colombia, but it exists now really in name only and not because of Venezuelans – who, incidentally, are leaving Venezuela not because of Maduro but because of the economic stranglehold being applied by the USA – nor because of the FARC (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia), who have largely held their peace, despite not having much to show for it, but precisely because of the Government’s failure to honour the Peace Accord. Land has not been distributed; there has been a deepening of the extreme social inequality; and hundreds of activists are being systematically murdered by right-wing paramilitaries who know that they have the Government on their side. This is a reign of terror, and we, as a European Parliament and a European Union, can use the leverage that’s at our disposal. Despite our explicit formal responsibilities in the peace agreement, our trade relations with Colombia run contrary to that peace. We import palm oil and coal under the EU—Colombia/Peru/Ecuador trade agreement because money is to be made. There’s leverage in that. Environmental rights and workers’ rights are being trampled on. Title IX of that agreement is supposed to protect those rights, but there are no legal mechanisms to enforce them, so they are being ignored by the Government. We’ve got to act and use our leverage.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, allow me to say that this exchange of views was very useful and very timely. I would like to take this opportunity to thank honourable Members for their interventions, comments and suggestions. Out of the many valuable remarks, I would like to respond to MEP Arena’s question: what is the EU doing to protect human rights defenders and indigenous and social leaders?  The EU, in coordination with Member States, supports actions to help ensure that human rights defenders are protected and respected and can operate in a safe and enabling environment. Assistance is provided to defenders at risk through protection programmes such as ProtectDefenders.eu On 11 June 2019, the EU delegation together with several Member States launched the campaign ‘Defendamos la vida’ to protect and give visibility to human rights defenders and social leaders. On 10 July, the EU launched the project strengthening the Special Investigation Unit of the Office of the Attorney General of the nation, EUR two million. The Special Investigation Unit aims to implement a secure judicial investigation system able to prevent, react, control, prosecute and seek criminal punishment for grave violations against human rights defenders and members of social and political movements perpetrated by criminal organisations. And in addition, the EU will continue to provide financial support to organisations working with human rights defenders in Colombia.  From this debate I conclude that the only path towards lasting peace in this difficult context is to continue implementation of the peace agreement with full support of the EU and international stakeholders. This is our message to the government and the people of Colombia. But I would like to remind us that while the peace process remains at the heart of our engagement with Colombia, our relationship has deepened and broadened in recent years with the implementation of the free trade agreement, cooperation on security and defence, and on the environment, to mention just a few key areas. The current challenges are very serious and we will continue supporting Colombia in addressing them, but the overall relationship and perspectives for the future are very positive.  Allow me to express my appreciation for your attention and support in maintaining this important file at the top of our agenda.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Kashmir (2019/2815(RSP)).

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the tensions in the region have increased following the announcement by the Indian Government on 5 August of the revocation of Article 370 that grants partial autonomy to the state of Jammu and Kashmir. This step has been accompanied by restrictions on fundamental rights and freedoms.  The Indian Government has deployed a significant number of additional military and paramilitary troops in Kashmir and along the Line of Control. The action was presented by the Indian Government as a means to prevent violent protests. Pakistan has also deployed additional troops on its side of the Line of Control. On both sides, the issue of Kashmir resonates strongly with internal political dynamics.  While some of the restrictions are reported to have been lifted, the situation has not returned to normalcy. There have been arrests of political leaders, activists and human rights defenders. The European Union has been following the situation closely since the early days of this escalation of tensions. In early August, High Representative Mogherini spoke on the phone with both her Pakistani and Indian counterparts. In both conversations, the High Representative underlined the importance of avoiding a further escalation and stressed that dialogue between India and Pakistan through diplomatic channels is crucial.  Our position on Kashmir remains unchanged. We encourage India and Pakistan to seek a peaceful and political solution, respectful of the interests of the Kashmiri population on both sides of the Line of Control. This remains the only way to solve a long-lasting dispute that for too long has caused instability and insecurity in the region.  We remain concerned about the situation on the ground with its restrictions on fundamental freedoms. It is crucial that freedom of movement and means of communication are fully restored, as well as access to all essential services. The High Representative conveyed these concerns to the Indian Minister for External Affairs, Mr Jaishankar, during their meeting in Brussels on 13 August. The Minister debriefed the High Representative on the state of play and on the security situation. Ms Mogherini reiterated the call to avoid an escalation of tensions and stressed the importance of steps to restore the rights and freedoms of the population in Kashmir.  The EU has also raised the situation in Jammu and Kashmir at the Human Rights Council meeting in Geneva in an Item 2 Statement on 10 September. In the Statement, we encourage the lifting of the remaining restrictions temporarily imposed and to maintain the rights and fundamental freedoms of the affected population. We continue to urge both parties to engage in direct dialogue with a view to a peaceful solution in full respect of their international human rights obligations.  In a moment of rising tensions in different regions around the world, no one can afford another escalation in Kashmir. Regional cooperation in South Asia is now more essential than ever and we will continue to encourage India and Pakistan to resume dialogue and find a peaceful solution to their disputes.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Minister, the situation in Kashmir is definitely alarming. I would even say unacceptable. Continuous human rights violations, street violence, political disputes and, above all, two near-conflict nuclear powers. These are the parameters in which things are evolving in Kashmir, without at this moment having the hope of a quick solution. I have taken note of the position of the rotating Presidency of the European Union, and I find it wise and effective. I would, however, like to make an observation about us Europeans. In this session we discussed Hong Kong, the fires in the Amazon, Burkina Faso, the situation in Colombia, the situation in Kashmir, but we are not talking about our problems, sometimes quite difficult to solve, problems that have often displeased the citizens of the European Union.  I am referring to the security and inviolability of the borders of the European Union. I am referring to migration, to which we have not yet given an answer to the 500 million citizens. I'm talking about terrorist risks. I am referring to the lack of cohesion between Member States when talking to China, the United States, the Russian Federation, which makes the European Union's external position vulnerable. I am referring to the abandonment of countries that have recently become members and which are simply delaying the integration process, although the Accession Treaty is obliged to join the euro. I am referring to the story that was launched and uncleared about the creation of the European army. I am referring to the need to make the arms industry compatible in (the President interrupted the speaker)...  the Member States of the European Union and, last but not least, I am referring to the lack of audacity that we have...
