(The President has withdrawn the speaker's word)

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr. President, since 1950 the Indian constitution has granted a special regime to Jammu and Kashmir. Article 370 provided for greater autonomy for Indian Kashmir by giving it wide leeway and limiting the involvement of Indian legislation in the management of Jammu and Kashmir. Defence, foreign affairs and communication were the only matters under the central government of New Delhi, the rest was administered by a local legislature. Article 370 also gave the federal state a separate constitution.  Since 5 August, when India revosaes Kashmir's autonomy status, more than 3,000 people have been arbitrarily arrested, including politicians, activists and academics. All means of communication, telephone, internet, have been suspended. Emergency services and hospitals are facing a shortage of equipment and personnel. Foreign journalists and NGOs no longer have access to the territory and this situation is deteriorating with the curfew blocking the movement of premises, especially patients and doctors. Tens of thousands of soldiers have been sent to reinforce the region, which is one of the most militarized in the world with more than a million troops on the territory.  Already the UN reports published in 2018 and 2019 reported serious human rights violations against civilian populations: kidnappings, assassinations, forced displacement, sexual violence. But of course these violations were perpetrated by both Indian and Pakistani forces. The Indian Prime Minister's unilateral decision of 5 August only exacerbates this situation already on the brink of explosion.  Europe cannot remain inactive, it must advocate for an independent and transparent international investigation into the violence in Kashmir. Europe must exert its full weight in its relations with India in order to restore Kashmir to the status of autonomy that the region has enjoyed since 1950. But Europe must also support the steps of the United Nations in the search for dialogue between India and Pakistan, because it is in dialogue that the solution will be found.

name: Shaffaq MOHAMMED
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by declaring an interest: that I was born in Kashmir, and moved to the United Kingdom at the age of four. However, it pains me to see what’s happening in Kashmir. Kashmir is in crisis: an international and human rights crisis. The people of Kashmir have suffered, and continue to suffer. The EU is an organisation which proudly stands for human rights, right across the world, and we must stand today with the people of Kashmir.  The ongoing crisis in Kashmir threatens the peace and security of the wider region – one of the most volatile in the world. It’s our responsibility to do something. The recommendations of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights (UNCHR)  offer a good starting point for their actions. We must support them and implement the findings of their reports, which they published last year in June and this year in July.  The institutions of the EU and their Member States exist not only to protect the human rights of citizens in the European Union, but they must also be defenders of human rights across the globe. The situation in Kashmir will not improve by trying to blame either side: all the while people try to apportion blame, the people of Kashmir are suffering and deserve better. The people of Kashmir should be the ones who decide their fate and their future. Self—determination and upholding human rights are fundamental values in our European Union, and we should demand no less from others around the world – particularly those that want to trade and have relationships with us.  The fighting in Kashmir has been going on for decades, but, in the end, the crisis is going to be ended only when people sit around the table and talk. The EU can be a natural facilitator in this role, and that allows both sides to talk. The people of Kashmir are crying out in the darkness. The EU must help them provide a light in that darkness.

name: Gina DOWDING
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, reports of serious human rights violations have been coming out of Kashmir for more than a month now. The accounts of raids, arrests, clashes and unlawful detentions are truly appalling – and all of this while mobile phone networks are still largely under lockdown. We UK Green MEPs demand that these human rights violations stop – not only for the sake of the population of Kashmir, but also for the hundreds of thousands of British citizens who are of Kashmiri origin.  No peaceful resolution to the Kashmir conflict is conceivable while these abuses continue. We demand that the Indian authorities restore the basic freedoms of the Kashmiri population, and we urge continued EU attention to this crisis.

name: Bernhard ZIMNIOK
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The EU wants and should contribute to the resolution of the Kashmir conflict – a conflict that has existed for 70 years, which has become entrenched, has triggered wars, a conflict with countless deaths, acts of terrorism, reprisals and much suffering. However, this problem cannot be solved by the EU, but only by the parties to the conflict itself. As outsiders, we can only accompany this process, as neutral mediators. If I now have to tell the press that Members of this House are taking sides and even going so far as to call for boycotts against India, then they themselves are becoming part of the problem and are no longer honest brokers. All I can say from experience is that it does not work. As soon as we sit on one side– whether it is the Indian or pakistani ones, we lose the reputation of the honest broker. All serious efforts on our part to resolve the conflict are running out of steam and are being undermined.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Kashmir is one of the most beautiful areas of India and with security and stability could be so enormously prosperous, but for over 70 years it has had an unsettled status and has been under threat, afflicted by externally sponsored terrorism and extremism, and at last there is an opportunity to rectify the situation.  Legally, the whole territory should have been part of India from the start but instead it was invaded and partly occupied by Pakistan, which then allowed its special services to support subversion and terrorism, costing thousands of lives across the Line of Control into India. Tourism dried up, the economy was put in jeopardy, and under the temporary Article 370 of the Indian Constitution people lived under different locally imposed rules. Now the changes brought in by Prime Minister Modi will give the same rights to the people of Kashmir as those in the rest of India, and we should look at what’s happening in Pakistan if we really want to see abuse of rights, women, religious minorities and transgender people, and all the difficulties that they face in that country.  Our governments and the European Union support dialogue and constructive engagement between India and Pakistan. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: "blue card" question. Mr Van Orden, I agree with what you have said and I would like to ask you whether you have read the threat that Pakistan has made to use nuclear weapons, because that is the real issue that the European Parliament should be dealing with: pakistan's use of nuclear weapons and, above all, the fact that Pakistan is a territory that has bred – and history says so – over all these years many terrorists. , which carried out bloody attacks in Europe, not to mention all the human rights violated in Pakistan.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: blue-card answer. – Pakistan has been a source of nuclear proliferation. It has given sanctuary to terrorist organisations and terrorist leaders, and it promotes terrorism across the Line of Control into India. Yes, we are talking about two nuclear-armed states, but I don’t think that is relevant to this particular matter at this time. If the European Union wants to be helpful, it should not be carping. The High Representative should listen more closely to Foreign Minister Jaishankar and what he had to say, because you are getting a very distorted picture from the contributions we’ve heard in this Parliament so far.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we cannot frame the situation in Kashmir as an internal conflicting issue of India, but in the nationalist resurgence embodied by Modi in connection with Trump, Bolsonaro and the reactionary international. Modi has reached the government by attacking NGOs and closing public freedoms. In the face of this, the European Union cannot continue to make policy as usual. We need to position ourselves with an alternative discourse, open, based on human rights and act by conditioning external action and bilateral relations on it. Today that means conditioning the strategic agreement on a substantial change in human rights in Kashmir, betting on a peaceful solution to the negotiated conflict between India and Pakistan. If we do not do this, Kashmir will be a new example of the limits of The European Union's voluntarism. Today we need to define the kind of global actor we want to be. We are committed to being an independent political actor, with autonomy, that can dialogue on an equal footing on human rights, multilateral governance, trade and technology with large countries.

name: Milan UHRÍK
text: – Mr President, since this is an issue of foreign policy I’m going to speak in English. Many of you are talking about violations of human rights and some other bad things happening in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. However, we are once again relying only on secondary information because no one here really and truly knows what is happening in India.  When I had a debate with the Indian ambassador in the Slovak Republic, I asked him how many times had the Indian Parliament interfered or condemned any European country for its internal policy. It had never happened and we should do the same. We should respect the sovereignty of India because it’s not our task to interfere in the internal affairs of countries 6 000 kilometres away. We are here to solve the problems of Europe, so please, let’s do that.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, let me also declare an interest, in that I visited Azad Kashmir last month.  The unilateral action by India revoking the autonomy that it granted to the part of Kashmir that it controlled – splitting the territory into two, sending in thousands of extra troops, instituting a media shutdown and arresting many local politicians – has inflamed an already volatile situation. This conflict has gone on for nearly 70 years now. It cannot be in India’s interest that it continues. It costs India a fortune. It’s a stain on its international reputation. It’s time to press for a solution, but frankly there is only one viable long-term and peaceful solution and that is self-determination for the people of Kashmir. That is what the United Nations laid down in 1947, when India took the dispute to the UN Security Council. It’s time to implement that, and the EU should use the combined diplomatic leverage of its 28 countries and its own powers on trade, and so on, to press for that outcome. It’s not too late.

name: Phil BENNION
text: – Mr President, Kashmir joined India only on the condition that it retained its autonomy, and this included a clause denying India the right to change that arrangement unilaterally. The Indian Supreme Court has upheld this principle in previous judgments, and it’s interesting that opposition politician Shashi Tharoor has today described the actions of the Indian Government as unconstitutional.  I do not deny that there have been terrorist problems, and that has provoked some action. In Geneva last week, I took the trouble to discuss this with Pakistani Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi, and I asked him that Pakistan do more to clamp down on insurgents. Others have described the situation on the ground, and I think it’s important to know that I’ve been discussing this with people who were in Srinagar at the time.  What should happen now? Well, the curfew should be lifted, the Kashmiri Regional Government reinstated and political prisoners released, and UN observers should be allowed access. For the long term, we call on Pakistan and India to agree on an independent mediator to facilitate talks that includes Kashmiri people from both sides of the Line of Control.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Bernhard ZIMNIOK
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would just like to ask the Speaker briefly how he enimagines autonomy under his own direction, under the administration of the Kashmiris, because this country would certainly be hanging on to the drip of the Community. They have nothing to offer economically; they must join India or Pakistan or divide, whatever the solution. Everything else is an illusion. Even the Kashmiris themselves would not want this solution. I worked there as a diplomat for four years. I have travelled to the region dozens of times, and I do not believe that you would find any majority in favour of it.

name: Phil BENNION
text: blue-card answer. – Certainly we don’t know whether there would be a majority, because it hasn’t been tested. But I think the assertion is that this is a very undeveloped and backward area. Despite the fact that this has been an area of conflict for 70 years, and we know that conflict actually does depress the economy, if you actually look at the indicators – and I have actually looked at virtually every indicator in terms of well-being, incomes, literacy; virtually every indicator you can think of – Kashmir comes out better than the rest of India, and as one of the top areas of India.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The reports on Kashmir are all too rarely reported on the massive human rights violations committed there by both sides – Pakistan and India. This must not leave us cold. But we are also on the brink of war between these two nuclear powers. In my opinion, there is only one way to prevent such a war and also to prevent human rights violations: that is the enforcement of the UN resolutions on this issue – admittedly, perhaps somewhat optimistically on my part. But we simply cannot let this go on, and that means that the UN must act here, that it must go there, including with a peacekeeping mission, if necessary, in accordance with both sides, which is difficult, I admit. But there is only this solution. We cannot allow things to continue in this way. I therefore urge the High Representative to take action here.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Kashmir was difficult even before, there are situations of violence known over the years. I find this debate a little unbalanced: I think that dialogue is done by not attacking one side or speaking in favour of the other. We are talking about a region of the world where there have long been terrorist groups linked to Islamic extremism, where there are absolutely worrying radicalisation phenomena. ISIS flags have been seen in this area and there has been violence for too long. Then perhaps we should analyse the historical context, rely on truly authoritative sources and information and, in general, support those who fight terrorists. Hundreds of thousands of Indians have left the region since the 1990s as a result of the violence. I wonder why we are not discussing the many victims of attacks and clashes and why we are not talking about pakistan's threats and religious discrimination. In general, I think that we, as Europe, should respect the sovereignty of states and respect and be close to those who carry out security measures to combat terrorist phenomena.

name: Baroness Nosheena MOBARIK
text: – Mr President, we in the European Parliament uphold the principles enshrined in the Treaties. Therefore, I am ashamed by the lack of resolution on Kashmir. There will always be those who will support India in deflecting the world’s attention away from its shortcomings and placing blame on others, their perceived foes. But, on this occasion, India alone is responsible for revoking Article 370 and for the current deplorable, bellicose and destructive situation in Kashmir. If we profess our belief in human rights and religious freedom, then why are we silent? The most fundamental right, the right to self-determination, has been denied to the Kashmiris for more than 70 years. How long do we stay silent? How bad does it have to get? Let us put aside our apathy, or indeed our eagerness to conclude a free-trade agreement, and examine our conscience: democratic principles, peace and stability are ultimately in the interests of India too.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, to those Members who have spoken today of their indignation towards India, I am astonished by your partiality, oversight and lack of any real empathy with the Kashmiris. Why do I say partiality? When Pakistan took the same measures in Gilgit and Baltistan, we didn’t speak up. When they gave away territory that wasn’t theirs to China we didn't speak up. Or when Sikh and other minority women are abducted and forced to convert, we don’t speak up. The fact is that there are human-rights violations in Pakistan-occupied Kashmir and very many honourable colleagues look the other way. Let me be clear: the solution to Kashmir is not going to be found in this Chamber. The solution to Kashmir will come when state-sponsored terrorism and global misinformation by Pakistan ends, then dialogue will follow. Pakistan may talk the talk, but it does not walk the walk when it comes to human rights, and it beggars belief that it has GSP+ status. And I say to those colleagues concerned about the rescinding of Article 370, you are focusing on one part and ignoring the other issues that are dear to the hearts of many of us. Not only will this improve the rights of LGBT people, women and minorities, it will also improve environmental and other protection measures, and ban the outrageous ‘triple talaq’ divorce. Why should Kashmiris have fewer rights than those enjoyed by Indians elsewhere?

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi decided to revoke Kashmir's autonomy status on 5 August. This is because Indian security forces have recently been the victims of attacks by Islamist groups in Kashmir, mostly claimed from Pakistan. It is common knowledge that Pakistan, especially since imran Khan came to power, backed by Islamist parties, has a more than benevolent attitude towards terrorist groups in Kashmir, against the Indian government. Narendra Modi's willingness to take over is a testament to his willingness to fight Islamist terrorism and hold Pakistan, whose secret services have long been Laden's protectors, to account. In Pakistan, demonstrations were organized by all Islamist movements and promoted by the government, to protest against the Indian government's decision.  Kashmir, it should be remembered, is a region that is part of the Indian Union. Once again, the reaction of the Secretary-General of the United Nations, stigmatizing India's position, will be surprised. While this country, which has been the victim of terrorism in Kashmir, as in its entire territory, for example in Bombay in 2008, has never received any support in times when it has had to face the Islamist peril. As our colleague Thierry Mariani pointed out to the AFET committee, Kashmir is Indian. The issue of Kashmir is therefore an internal issue for the Indian Union and nothing more. It is hard to believe between these walls that Brussels can adopt the dialectic of Pakistan in this regard.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Let us recall an important fact – India is the largest democracy in the world. And also, in the context of our democracy, I will say that it is probably our only democratic ally in this part of Asia. I think it is necessary to look more broadly at the number of terrorist acts that have taken place in India, including jamming and Kashmir. And these terrorists, they did not fall from the moon, they unfortunately came from a neighbor. This should also be seen in this context.  In my opinion, we, as a European democracy, should support a democratic India. This court, which takes place here over India, I personally do not like. And Mr. Corbett, who had just left, said what he said, as if he did not remember that seventy years ago his country, Britain, had ceased to have an Indian colony. India is not a colony of Great Britain.

name: Giuliano PISAPIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Kashmir, like so many others in the world, requires intensive diplomatic work, based on international law and respect for human rights. On the one hand, there is a constitutional amendment, approved by a large majority in the upper house and the lower house. On the other hand, there has been a completely lack of consultation with the citizens of Kashmir. I recall the words of Jawaharlal Nehru: 'we have given our word of honour for a peaceful solution, it must be respected'. The first UN report on human rights in Kashmir provided for a commission of inquiry into violations committed by both sides. Human rights are the polar star that guides all the Union's initiatives. As the European Union and as the European Parliament, we have a moral and political duty to make our experience available in order to find a peaceful solution that promotes democracy and peace. I hope and trust that this will be the path we will take together.

name: Julie LECHANTEUX
text: Mr President, the criticisms of India, the world's largest democracy, heard in this Chamber are based on a mystifying representation of the facts.  We focus on constitutional reform, but we forget about the separatist push and the security issue. The situation in Jammu and Kashmir has worsened. A series of Islamist attacks took place against the security forces, such as on 14 February, when a car bomb killed 40 policemen, or on 2 August, with the discovery of an arsenal that should have been used to carry out an attack against the thousands of Hindu pilgrims who visit the sacred cave of Amarnath every year.  In this context, the security measures taken by Narendra Modi, the Indian Prime Minister, aim to guarantee the security of the country, the protection of his fellow citizens and the tightness of the border with the Islamic Republic of Pakistan, which, since 2018, has once again found itself on the American list of states with an ambiguous attitude towards the terrorist threat. Here are the facts.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: – Mr President, 43 days ago the Indian Government revoked Articles 370 and 35A of the Indian Constitution, removing at a stroke the guarantee of Jammu and Kashmir’s autonomy. We’ve seen a huge surge in the number of troops deployed there, a total communications blackout, curfews and house arrests. We hear continually of violations of human rights, including the use of shotguns against civilians.  Take the case of Asrar Ahmed Khan. Despite denials by the Indian Government, medical records released by the hospital present clear evidence that he died as a result of a shotgun pellet to the head. I visited Azad Kashmir last year and heard accounts of even infants being fired at with shotguns. There can never ever be any excuse for killing, maiming and blinding small children.  I really cannot understand why a great nation like India, which prides itself on the strength of its democracy, behaves in this way. India aspires to be a permanent member of the UN Security Council. Events of the past month are not the actions of a credible candidate.

name: Dinesh DHAMIJA
text: – Mr President, India is the largest functioning democracy in the world. There are 200 million Muslims who live peacefully with others in India, and it’s also a member of the G20. There are two Supreme Court actions going on: the continued stopping of mobile and internet services in 7% of Jammu and Kashmir, and the setting aside of Article 370 and Article 35A. The EU does not want to appear neo—colonial on matters that are sub judice. The Indian Supreme Court is independent and does a really good job.  According to Indians, there are 40 new laws that will now apply to Kashmiris: a ban on the triple talaq divorce that is terrible for women, prohibition of child marriage, protection of women from domestic violence, etc. – are these not human rights? There are 40 of them. So, please, look at the other side. There was a mention of the UN plebiscite that they asked for in 1947: I have a video to show the US State Department why this plebiscite didn’t happen – because the Pakistani troops wouldn’t move back from the Line of Control.

name: Søren GADE
text: Mr President! (microphone off) For the past 70 years, the Kashmir region has been plagued by violence and instability. Many of the progress india has made in the meantime towards modern democracy has not been followed by kashmir's special status. These include an independent rule of law, the protection of minorities, including sexual minorities, the safeguarding of the education of children and the safeguarding of women's fundamental rights. The substantial funds that India has been posting for years into Kashmir have largely been stolen by a corrupt elite, and this has happened under the noses of a poor local.  The iron grip that Article 370 has kept the people of Kashmir for years has never benefited them. I call on parliament, and as advocates of fundamental democratic values and human rights, to focus on the positive aspects of the people of Kashmir, of their women and of their minorities, which this new situation may also give rise to.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, the European Parliament has a reputation for discussing problems of flagrant human rights violations in latitudes that have never known or trace democracy. That's not the case with India. It is, as has been said, a constitutional democracy, with its 1950 Constitution, and happens to be the largest democracy in the world. It integrates the diversity of a federal order of great complexity and has ensured the coexistence of different minorities, including the Muslim minority, in a country with a majority of other religions. In the case of Jammu and Kashmir, therefore, I believe that the European Parliament is right to express prudent self-contention in assessing a suspension of autonomy, guaranteed by the constitutional order itself, in accordance with the Constitution itself , in article 370, and to the extent that it is also making an important effort to prevent the radicalisation of Islamism that lives and beats within the enormous complexity of the Indian puzzle.

name: Chris DAVIES
text: – Mr President, I really welcome the words of the Minister in her introductory remarks. We know we have a divided house but I think the position taken by the High Representative in expressing concern for human rights is the right balance.  India is a great country, a great democracy, but you can’t ignore the fact that Kashmir is a disputed territory, recognised as such by the United Nations. It’s effectively been under military occupation with an army that’s been allowed to maim and murder without any proper supervision or jurisdiction. And communication bans, loss of any sort of sense of self—determination must feed a sense of injustice in Kashmir.  It is because we are friends of India that we have to ask this great democracy – which we know, where Prime Minister Modi has the support of his country; he knows there is majority support for the actions he’s taken – but we have to question whether this is the right course of action and whether it will result in positive benefits.  So I have to ask the Minister: words have been very good, will there be any actions to follow them up?

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this exchange of views was very useful and timely. I would like to thank the honourable Members for their contributions, comments and suggestions. I can only conclude that the EU will continue to monitor the situation closely, with our key focus on de-escalating a situation involving two nuclear powers. We must make every effort needed to avoid an escalation of the conflict.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: Thank you very much, Minister Tuppurainen, and thank you for coming to Parliament especially at this late time in the day. The debate is closed.
